reviewText:
Absolutely everything I could have hoped for, this game was obviously made for the fans with a lot of love. It's not watered down to cator to the casual players in todays gaming market..it's for the long time fans. The graphics are astonishing..specially for a kickstarter project everything in this game is just breathtaking. The game has full controller support and also buttons so people who like to use a controller will be very happy.

Not gonna go into details about the story because I'd spoil the book..let just put it this way. The incredible stories the last 2 games were known for continue on in Chapters ;) even better in my opinion. The voice acting is some of the best I have heard in a long time, was wary about the replacing the actress for Zoe but I find myself liking the new one more. The script is extremely polished and there's still a ton of inside jokes xD

2 playthroughs so far and clocked in at almost 10 hours, working on my third playthrough now. There is so much to do and see :)

Edit: Been 4 days after launch and I'm still being drawn back into the game..there is just so many things that keep hooking me.

reviewText: I played Dreamfall: The Longest Journey and completely fell in love with that game, so I obviously had to get the sequel. I love these games with all my heart- favorite series of all time- but I found myself a bit bored at times in chapters 1-3. Do NOT let this discourage you. In chapter 4, I felt all the flood of emotions from Dreamfall flood back and wrench my heart. Chapter 4 alone makes this game entirely worth playing, along with the in-depth characters, originality, and beauty throughout the entire game. I cried several times. Also, the decisions I've made warrant another playthrough in hopes that mistakes will be fixed. In Telltale games, it appears to me that the game is decided no matter what choice you make because your choices never affect the NEXT chapter. Not so will Dreamfall: Chapters. Each decision you make will have an impact on future gameplay. I cannot wait for chapter 5 to see what I will regret and cry over next.

reviewText:
I love the story and atmosphere.

The action sequences range from hilariously bad to hilariously frustrating. The animations are stilted, the game/engine is clearly not suited for timed action events but does them anyway. There are stealth sections, ohnoes...

Ragnar Tørnquist has a bit too much confidence in my navigational skills. It's hard to find stuff. You will walk around a lot, not really knowing where to go. There are inworld maps but they don't display all the necessary data which kindof defeats the point of a map?

I will finish this game even if it kills me. I need to see this mad vision of Ragnar through till the end!

reviewText:
Ever since I played Dreamfall-The longest Journey, I've been a fan of this series. I played Dreamfall-The longest Journey before I played The longest Journey (I was too young to play games when The longest Journey came out in the first place^^) and I got obsessed with these games. I'm not exagerrating when I say that these games changed my life. The story and the world(s) it is set in are awesome, the characters are memorable and loveable and that's the reason why I - like so many others - waited eight years for the sequel to follow. And by far I am not disappointed at all. Dreamfall Chapters is AMAZING. I love it so much and after finishing the third episode lately I almost cried my eyes out after meeting an old friend...

I hardly recommend this game for everyone who enjoys an intelligent, inspiring story with political elements and overwhelming fantasy, but I would suggest to play Dreamfall-The Longest Journey and The Longest Journey, too, because there are so many details and hints in the story you might miss otherwise.

Anyway, I'm in love with the Dreamer. I love her new haircut ♥ And I freaking love this game!!!

reviewText:
It's a great game with wonderful characters and an interesting story from a talented, proven developer, but don't buy it.  It's been three months since the last episode came out.  The wait has been kind of insane for an episodic series, and at this rate, the finale will be some time in 2016.  Because of how much time has passed, I have barely any memory of what happened in the first episode (Something about a spicy sausage, a Muslim prison riot and a space baby...), and it will take some work to get emotionally reinvested in the game by the time chapter 2 comes out, whenever that is.

I'd say forget this is a thing, and just wait for 2016 to buy the whole thing on sale for ten bucks.

- Update 3/12/15 -

The second chapter is just coming out this week, making it nearly five months between two hour chapters.  No apologies or explanation from the developer, this is just how they've decided to do business.  They should have just called it an Early Access title.

reviewText:
TL;DR, Book 1 spoilers: You literally crap your pants. 10/10. Now for the rest of the review.

This is the greatest game I have ever played in my life. It is my all time, single most favourite game ever.

The writing is absolutely brilliant. The dialogue is filled with more salt than the entirety of the Dead Sea. The characters are incredibly relatable, incredibly funny and deep.

The game itself is only about ~4GB but it looks terrific. The environments are gorgeous. The gameplay has a great flow to it and at no point does it feel boring or forced. The controls fit like a glove.

Chapters is truly a perfect sequel and absolutely faithful to the previous entries in the series. Even if you haven't played the original titles, the callbacks bring you up to speed and help you understand what is going on.

I couldn't have imagined the next installment would be as amazing as this back in 2006 when I played Dreamfall. It doesn't just continue where the series left off, it builds on it in a fantastic fashion. I paid full price and I'd do it again. I love this game. LOVE IT.

reviewText:
For seasoned TLJ players, this is the game you've been waiting for, go play it. That's all.

If you have NOT played The Longest Journey and/or Dreamfall: TLJ, I highly recommend you do so. If this game looks at all appealing to you, or if you love a good story and have the time (first 2 games will probably run you over 50 hours, easily). Playing the first 2 games will make this one much more relevant. I can see that it may not be necessary, but the depth of backstory that's apparent in Chapters will make it worthwhile. (For instance, new players will not get the full emotionally crushing blow when they meet the Mole. And WHO really IS Lady Alvane? Man I can't wait to find out.)

While the graphics are dated (especially for TLJ), much of the original game art consists of hand painted backgrounds, so it's still lovely to look at (especially parts of Arcadia and April's dreams). I re-play both games about once every 1-2 years, and they're still worth it. They're like being inside a particularly good fantasy/sci-fi novel. Every character is relevant, loveable (even the villains) and authentic.

Favourite game series of all time. Would recommend 10/10.

reviewText:
I've played through the whole The Longest Journey series and just waiting for the final book to get a closure.
There are many questions one want answered.

The game is very well made. Story wise, voice acting, graphical and you find out things tying previous events.
You have great worlds to explore.
I did enjoy this game tremendously.

There are characters of all kinds in the game. From shy, corrupted, murderous, bots, devious, foul mouth and so on you will meet it all. Your decisions does affect outcomes so think about your decisions when you do and have the time.

I do recommend playing previous games to get the full enjoyment and understand all even thou you do not have to.

I do have restrictions usually when it comes to releases with chapters that take such time between release dates.
I was thinking of waiting but went ahead anyways as I had played the other games.
In a way I regret it but at the same time not.

I do recommend the game strongly.
Thou if you're one who doesn't like to wait for a part to finish it all and to get closure then wait until the date is known for Book 5.

Have a jolly good day!

reviewText:
This is truly wonderful.

I won't discuss the story in details. The only thing that really matters is that this is an adventure made with an incredible amount of love and care. Awesome, tragic, deep. Very consistent. All that's left is Book Five, which is, well, coming soon.

Graphical and sound design are executed very thorough. This is a very solid work, with the teeny-tiny exception of voicing for some characters, especially Reza. Voice volume levels are also tend to differ from chapter to chapter, but I can live with that.

As for technical realization, well -- as a Linux gamer, I'm quite used to all sorts of glitches. Fortunately, they are mostly visual, due to use of some shaders which are not available in *nix-version of Unity. Lack of optimization also shows, for I'm struggling at Arcadia with medium graphic settings set, on a rig running 2-gig GTX750Ti b\w AMD quad-core and 32 Gbytes of RAM. Propast, on the other way, runs super-smoothly. Dunno what I'm doing wrong, to be honest.

Nevertheless, ported version is, well, okay. It's stable, it's not crashing. And Linux is my personal choice, so I guess most people won't encounter these issues which I've mentioned.

To summarize: yes, this, in my opinion, is a good game. It does not feature complex puzzles. Sometimes it suffers from technical issues. But I do recommend it, for it's a game made with unbelievable amount of love & attention to details of the story (which is pretty much what you'd want from an adventure/quest), memorable characters -- and let's not forget great soundtrack.

So yeah, don't be a greedy ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ and buy this one already. We almost drove everything to hell once, with pirating The Longest Journey and everything. Let's not make the same mistake again.

reviewText:
Great game I recomend it despite the flaws.

reviewText:
I'll say this right now. If you haven't played the previous two games The Longest Journey or Dreamfall please go out and play them, even if you only play Dreamfall. This game references them heavily, requiring the player to have some prerequisite knowledge in order to put events in the game into context. Thankfully it doesn't sacrifice the pace of the story in lieu of accessibility.

It's a recurring theme actually. In a choice between story and something else, this game chooses the former. Every single time. You'll need to set your own expectations, if you come into this expecting something akin to a fantastic interactive story with some extremely well realised characters, you will not be disappointed. If you're the type of person that gets bored with dialogue and skips cutscenes to carry on playing then refrain from purchasing it.

Like Myst, Gone Home, and The Walking Dead, this is an experience that requires you to take a back seat, and just enjoy the narrative presented. After seeing a presentation from Red Thread a year or two back, I was worried that the new choice system would be a cliched binary save the puppy" or "eat the puppy alive" moral dichotomy
date: and that it would compromise the main characters' intended personalities. Thankfully that isn't the case. Choices never fall outside their conceivable paths of action
recommended: but there are clear distinctions between them. Neither do a lot of them centre on a moral choice

reviewText:
Since 2006, I have waited. I waited so ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ long. It's finally here, FINALLY, and I can say it completely goes beyond the standards of the others.

For people new to the franchise and long time fans, you can jump straight in and completely understand what's been going on (although I would definitely recommend playing at least Dreamfall: The Longest Journey/refreshing your mind on the events to get the full experience).

Red Thread have tried to do something new with the mechanics, making them like The Walking Dead with the decisions etc, and when you come across one of the decisions you can click the logo in the middle to see what other players have chosen - Which I thought was pretty damn cool.

Visuals are a huge part of this game, and they're ♥♥♥♥ing gorgeous. If you want something to go by then take a look at my screenshots on my profile here and you'll see. The way Storytime looks like the polar ice caps with the auroras is awesome, and the new cities are jaw dropping.

It has left incredible first impressions, more than I could have ever expected.
As for now, this has a 9/10 and is my personal GOTY, I can't contain my excitment fot the next parts to come out!

reviewText:
I loved Dreamfall 2006. It felt like the first AAA adventure game since Lucasarts decline, with graphics and audio that still hold up today. I guess nobody bought it since it took this long for the sequel to come out.

In many ways Dreamfall Chapters is disappointing to me, but it still manages to hit a good enough quality level across the board to be an acceptable sequel. There’s shortcuts all over the place in the production, like missing animations, simplistic audio design, clipping, etc. It’s clearly a mid-budget production compared to Dreamfall.

So far only “Book 1” of the story is out. It establishes the setting and the characters, without kicking off the story properly. This makes it a bit frustrating to play as you can feel it’s just about to get interesting when it ends. Time will solve this problem as more chapters are released. It shows a lot of promise! A few scenes in it are great. But then there’s a long slow bit that put a damper on my enthusiasm.

It’s missing much of what I admired in Dreamfall 2006 from a technical perspective. Like the audio design, which is still top of the class. Believe it or not, Dreamfall 2006 is a good game to test subwoofers with. It pumps out ferocious bass in one early game sequence. It also had a ton of one-off ambient sounds, like the sound of a riot. It was purely for mood, as the riot played no part in the story and wasn’t addressed by characters. Environmental storytelling through ambient sound design.

None of that is in Dreamfall Chapters. Everything is on an acceptable level, without pushing the boundaries. They should be able to keep this level of quality consistent across the entire game without going broke. Despite all my reservations I can’t wait to see where the story goes from here. The writing is of the same quality as the other entries, for good and ill. The style of humor, the same kinds of characters, the same type of story. It’s all here. If you liked the other games, you get more of it from Dreamfall Chapters.

reviewText: I really enjoyed this game and such a refreshing change from the blood and gore and violence of so many games today. This is a game I can share with my kids. We have played all the previous Dreamfall games and have been waiting impatiently for this one. What I like about it: the atmosphere of Propast is extremely well done and it was fascinating to just explore. I like that you can make choices that affect the way the game unfolds although it is not clear in what way it affects the game as yet. Kudos to the developers for doing some radical things including role-playing Saga, a toddler! It was so cute to listen to her babbling and giggling as I explored the house and tried to dodge Dad to get to the shiny sparkly thing!  The characters are not stereotypes, there is no gratuitous cleavage, what a change that is!  What I don't like about it: there is not much to get one's teeth into yet but hopefully that will come. Also the people of Propast: no kids (except one), very few old people, no fat people, body types are the same (i.e. ideal") (great that there is a lot of ethnic diversity though). But the main problem for me is that I have to wait for the next chapter!!!!!"

reviewText:
Over eight years have passed since Funcom published Dreamfall, a sequel to the acclaimed point-and-click adventure game, The Longest Journey. The sad news was that Dreamfall failed to sell enough to make any established publishers interested in resurrecting the franchise and all hope for a sequel seemed lost. With the advent of crowd-funding, Ragnar Tornquist (writer/director of all TLJ games) created a new studio (Red Thread Games), seized the opportunity and launched a Kickstarter to build the conclusion to Zoe Castillo’s story.

After smashing their initial target, ecstatic fans (including yours truly) settled into another long wait with excitement and enthusiasm, along with trepidation and fear that the game may not live up to nostalgic expectations. Red Thread Games have already proven these fears unfounded. If you loved Dreamfall, you will fall in love all over again with Chapters. I expect the reverse is also true though, and haters or non-fans of the former will not be wooed by the latter.

For those of you who haven’t yet played Dreamfall and the first cutscene of Chapters, I’d recommend exercising caution as spoilers are ahead.

When you launch Chapters for the first time, there is a newly minted recap of the previous game available; Highly recommended if it’s been a while since you last visited the worlds of Arcadia and Stark.

Upon beginning a new game, the prologue begins almost immediately after the final moments and frustrating climax (see: cliffhanger) of Dreamfall, refreshing us on the situations the playable characters are in.

We see April Ryan’s funeral ceremony, presumably indicating that she did in fact die, apparently ending the debates floating around various internet forums post-Dreamfall. That being said, let’s be realistic. There’s no way she won’t be featured at some point later on. Dreamfall may be Zoe’s story, but The Longest Journey is April’s – and it’s not yet complete.

Zoe is still in her coma, and has become a guardian to those trapped in the “Dreamtime”, within nightmares they can’t escape from brought on by using ubiquitous “Dream Machines”.Kian Alvane is languishing in prison with his execution looming, sentenced for betraying his kin during the latter stages of Dreamfall.

Chapters then gives first control of the player to Zoe, trapped in “Dreamtime”, helping others while musing on the state of her corporeal body. Book One offers the first two chapters of the overall story and a short interlude before coming to an end all too quickly.

The length of the episode is a double-edged sword: a cause for frustration and anticipation. After many years of waiting for any scrap of news about development, then development itself, Book One is then over in roughly four hours. However, given the developers have stated this is the shortest of the five Books, the game should be well over 20 hours by the time it is complete. That’s as much as I was hoping for – the length of a season of television or similar long-form storytelling.

The writing and dialogue are top notch in the given medium. The lines are snappy, and the characters themselves are ever relatable and unique. The Europolis portion of the first chapter is deeply political and although set far into the future, is (like much good Sci-Fi) more relevant than ever and tackles issues of authoritarianism and corporatocracy with Orwellian overtones.

As the player reaches certain junctions and crossroads during the story, you are given various choices with seemingly important and varying consequences. At this stage, apart from one fairly major branch in the initial chapter, how choices effect the game remains to be seen.

I imagine it’s causing many headaches from a design perspective to plan and write for all the different story branches that have already been opened up from the choices made (ideally moving away from norm in games whereby different choices ultimately result in exactly the same outcomes). I’m cautiously awaiting how these are addressed later on. I suppose my skepticism is due to the fact no game has so far accomplished what Red Thread are trying to achieve. Fingers crossed.

The core gameplay of Chapters is fairly similar to its’ predecessor, with third-person movement and control, interacting with objects in the environment and with the numerous, lengthy cutscenes rendered in-game. The combat and stealth sections of the original Dreamfall are gone, to the disappointment of absolutely noone who played the previous game. They were ♥♥♥♥ing atrocious and I breathed a sigh of relief to know they’re gone.

It’s hard to judge much of the gameplay of Dreamfall Chapters just yet, given that Book One serves as a tutorial and a foundation of what is to come. It would be unfair of me at this stage to level too much criticism on puzzle elements, but I’ll have more to say on these elements in future reviews. Book One simply gives the player a crash course with interacting with items, the interface and the game world. Given my past experience, all initial puzzles were a breeze and I was never stuck trying to figure something out. For the most part, I moved effortlessly from point to point eager to advance the story.

As far as the technical side of the game goes, it’s not always sunshine and roses. The Unity engine is at the core of the game, with awesome visuals thanks to the hard work of the Red Thread team, but with the warts and lesions of an emergent platform more suited to mobile games on a smaller scale. Especially in Europolis, performance issues plagued the experience. Even running a GTX 970 and a powerful Intel processor, I barely managed 30 FPS with dips below 15. The area looks nice – but not THAT nice.

Apparently (since I played) the developers have already made sweeping improvements to overall performance and stability, but as Europolis is the largest and most ambitious game area ever created in Unity it’s no surprise that it’s causing issues in playability and performance. This detracted significantly from my immersion during these sections, and I’m hoping that when we revisit Europolis in later chapters we can look forward to a much smoother ride.

On a lighter note, just as we’re accustomed to from previous games, the voice acting and music are superb. The actors do a fine job bringing the script to life, often times better than in previous games. My main gripe is that the characters in-game have poor facial animations and visual delivery of lines hasn’t improved much from 2006’s Dreamfall. I often found myself looking away from the screen during prolonged conversations and absorbing the material as if it were a novel or script, rather than subjecting myself to the uncanny-valley visuals of the stiff models in-game.

I enjoyed my time with Book One, although it was far too brief. If the developers can maintain consistency in writing and design interesting/challenging puzzles, I’ll be happy. However, performance improvements are vital to improve the overall experience and I’d love to see more attention given to facial animations and expressions. Dreamfall Chapters is approaching greatness but it’s not quite there yet.

It’s early days yet and I can’t wait for more.

reviewText:
Since the game is not complete, just pointing out this is a review regarding Book 1 of Dreamfall Chapters.

I believe it's safe to say that this game should be exactly what a Dreamfall fan could hope for. There's been so much hard work and dedication put into the making of it, I fail to see any cons. I put my faith completely blind in it and even though I am always sceptical in such situations I finished the game being absolutely mesmerized and hungry for more! It's a sequel with nothing ruined (that's a big deal these days...) : the characters, the plot, the choices, all live up to their past. There's also a thorough briefing for those new to the series and a cool new feature where you can (not necessarily) see what decisions other people made before you make up your mind. I finished the game twice and am still going for more playthroughs to make sure I have covered everything it has to offer.

TL;DR: Awesome graphics, engaging plot, decision making, easy controls but lacking in character animating and... a bit short. 9/10

P.S. The trailers aren't impressive. But a great game on the inside doesn't need a fancy ribbon.

reviewText:
if you like adventure games, this is a must have, however if this is the first time you hear about it, go play at least the previous one first. You will be disappointed with this if you don't. The game makes little sense on its own without it, you will feel majorly lost and won't understand why everyone likes this game.

Many people complain about performance issues, but I haven't had a single problem all game, and I am playing on maximum (granted I have an i7, 12g ram, and an r9 290). Thing is, this game was built with Unity3D, this is a general purpose engine that can produce very nice visuals, but since it is so versatile it cannot be optimized for everything, so there's a trade-off. Indie devs can benefit of the engine, making any kind of game they want, even cross platform, but that comes with performance overhead... you just have to live with it.

The only thing I can fault in this game is the length, I know this is only the first 2 chapter / book one at this point but it only just takes off the ground storywise when it ends after little over 4 hours of gameplay, so now I have to wait for the next one...

reviewText:
Over eight years have passed since Funcom published Dreamfall, a sequel to the acclaimed point-and-click adventure game, The Longest Journey. The sad news was that Dreamfall failed to sell enough to make any established publishers interested in resurrecting the franchise and all hope for a sequel seemed lost. With the advent of crowd-funding, Ragnar Tornquist (writer/director of all TLJ games) created a new studio (Red Thread Games), seized the opportunity and launched a Kickstarter to build the conclusion to Zoe Castillo’s story.

After smashing their initial target, ecstatic fans (including yours truly) settled into another long wait with excitement and enthusiasm, along with trepidation and fear that the game may not live up to nostalgic expectations. Red Thread Games have already proven these fears unfounded. If you loved Dreamfall, you will fall in love all over again with Chapters. I expect the reverse is also true though, and haters or non-fans of the former will not be wooed by the latter.

For those of you who haven’t yet played Dreamfall and the first cutscene of Chapters, I’d recommend exercising caution as spoilers are ahead.

When you launch Chapters for the first time, there is a newly minted recap of the previous game available; Highly recommended if it’s been a while since you last visited the worlds of Arcadia and Stark.

Upon beginning a new game, the prologue begins almost immediately after the final moments and frustrating climax (see: cliffhanger) of Dreamfall, refreshing us on the situations the playable characters are in.

We see April Ryan’s funeral ceremony, presumably indicating that she did in fact die, apparently ending the debates floating around various internet forums post-Dreamfall. That being said, let’s be realistic. There’s no way she won’t be featured at some point later on. Dreamfall may be Zoe’s story, but The Longest Journey is April’s – and it’s not yet complete.

Zoe is still in her coma, and has become a guardian to those trapped in the “Dreamtime”, within nightmares they can’t escape from brought on by using ubiquitous “Dream Machines”.Kian Alvane is languishing in prison with his execution looming, sentenced for betraying his kin during the latter stages of Dreamfall.

Chapters then gives first control of the player to Zoe, trapped in “Dreamtime”, helping others while musing on the state of her corporeal body. Book One offers the first two chapters of the overall story and a short interlude before coming to an end all too quickly.

The length of the episode is a double-edged sword: a cause for frustration and anticipation. After many years of waiting for any scrap of news about development, then development itself, Book One is then over in roughly four hours. However, given the developers have stated this is the shortest of the five Books, the game should be well over 20 hours by the time it is complete. That’s as much as I was hoping for – the length of a season of television or similar long-form storytelling.

The writing and dialogue are top notch in the given medium. The lines are snappy, and the characters themselves are ever relatable and unique. The Europolis portion of the first chapter is deeply political and although set far into the future, is (like much good Sci-Fi) more relevant than ever and tackles issues of authoritarianism and corporatocracy with Orwellian overtones.

As the player reaches certain junctions and crossroads during the story, you are given various choices with seemingly important and varying consequences. At this stage, apart from one fairly major branch in the initial chapter, how choices effect the game remains to be seen.

I imagine it’s causing many headaches from a design perspective to plan and write for all the different story branches that have already been opened up from the choices made (ideally moving away from norm in games whereby different choices ultimately result in exactly the same outcomes). I’m cautiously awaiting how these are addressed later on. I suppose my skepticism is due to the fact no game has so far accomplished what Red Thread are trying to achieve. Fingers crossed.

The core gameplay of Chapters is fairly similar to its’ predecessor, with third-person movement and control, interacting with objects in the environment and with the numerous, lengthy cutscenes rendered in-game. The combat and stealth sections of the original Dreamfall are gone, to the disappointment of absolutely noone who played the previous game. They were ♥♥♥♥ing atrocious and I breathed a sigh of relief to know they’re gone.

It’s hard to judge much of the gameplay of Dreamfall Chapters just yet, given that Book One serves as a tutorial and a foundation of what is to come. It would be unfair of me at this stage to level too much criticism on puzzle elements, but I’ll have more to say on these elements in future reviews. Book One simply gives the player a crash course with interacting with items, the interface and the game world. Given my past experience, all initial puzzles were a breeze and I was never stuck trying to figure something out. For the most part, I moved effortlessly from point to point eager to advance the story.

As far as the technical side of the game goes, it’s not always sunshine and roses. The Unity engine is at the core of the game, with awesome visuals thanks to the hard work of the Red Thread team, but with the warts and lesions of an emergent platform more suited to mobile games on a smaller scale. Especially in Europolis, performance issues plagued the experience. Even running a GTX 970 and a powerful Intel processor, I barely managed 30 FPS with dips below 15. The area looks nice – but not THAT nice.

Apparently (since I played) the developers have already made sweeping improvements to overall performance and stability, but as Europolis is the largest and most ambitious game area ever created in Unity it’s no surprise that it’s causing issues in playability and performance. This detracted significantly from my immersion during these sections, and I’m hoping that when we revisit Europolis in later chapters we can look forward to a much smoother ride.

On a lighter note, just as we’re accustomed to from previous games, the voice acting and music are superb. The actors do a fine job bringing the script to life, often times better than in previous games. My main gripe is that the characters in-game have poor facial animations and visual delivery of lines hasn’t improved much from 2006’s Dreamfall. I often found myself looking away from the screen during prolonged conversations and absorbing the material as if it were a novel or script, rather than subjecting myself to the uncanny-valley visuals of the stiff models in-game.

I enjoyed my time with Book One, although it was far too brief. If the developers can maintain consistency in writing and design interesting/challenging puzzles, I’ll be happy. However, performance improvements are vital to improve the overall experience and I’d love to see more attention given to facial animations and expressions. Dreamfall Chapters is approaching greatness but it’s not quite there yet.

It’s early days yet and I can’t wait for more.

reviewText: Scaled To Book 4 Review.\n\nI fell in love with the longest journey when i first played it many years ago. I was hooked into the colorful characters, the rich storyline, the beautiful art (yes even years later it still looks good). Then i played dreamfall, which wasn't received as well as the original but still brought me back to the world which had captured my imagination. of course ending on a cliffhanger, we were promised a episodic sequel. Then it was all just rumors in the wind, looking for any glimmer we would see the sequel happen. it's hard to be unbiased about this game having such a love for it, from a fans perspective, it does stumble quote often. since the update to the Unity 5 engine, the performance issues have been resolved and the game looks graphics were turned up to 11, also in this day and age we should have support for ultrawide resolutions. overall i enjoyed this game and have easily gotten my bang for the buck entertainment. book 4....wow....i can't begin to say how hard the hammer was dropped in this one. it's finally coming to an end. 16 years. i've waited a long time to see this end. to reach the end of the longest journey is kind of a joke. but truly is my favorite game series of all time. hopefully the last book will meet our expectations and i can finally see the end to this amazing story.

reviewText:
Continues from the great adventure game that is Dreamfall.  Hard to tell from this first part if it will live up to the high expectations.  As usual, great music.  Graphics are pretty but not always run smoothly. Not much gameplay though.  Don't bother if you haven't played Dreamfall (or didn't like it).

Edit: with Book Two (minor spoilers for Book One)
Where Book One feels like the introduction or opening chapter in a book where the scene is set, Book Two develops the story much further.  You are still playing Kian, the ex-warrior/'apostle' who's now working for the rebels in the parallel fantasy world 'Arcadia'; as well as Zoe who is trying to rebuild her post-amnesia life in 'our' future world 'Stark', but keeps getting drawn into intrigues and conspiracies.  The patches have improved the performances.  Like Book One, choices play a big part and the game sort of hits you over your head with 'Your Choices Will have CONSEQUENCES', repeatedly (not that it's necessarily a bad thing though).  NPCs are all well-rounded characters and believable.  Voice acting and music remains fantastic.  Some of the puzzles are not intuitive, but not nearly as difficult as 'old-school' adventure games like this game's predecessors 'The Longest Journey' or 'Dreamfall'.

reviewText:
Dreamfall is THE game of the year in my opinion. The script is well written, the visuals are effective and pretty, and the music is simply as amazing as I thought it would be. Simon Poole, the composer, does a great job with the score and it plays along effectivly with the visuals. In addition, Egil Olsen, a singer/ songwriter from Norway, is featured in the streets of Propast. In other words, Red Thread Games really pays attention to details.

I would say that this is one of the more successful Kickstarter games, maybe even one of the best projects in a while. The team delivers regardless of the delays they have had, inter alia the upgrade to the newer Unity 5 engine.

There is a lack of story based games that actually focus on the story rather than the fighting to create suspense and action. That is until Dreamfall Chapters came out.

10/10
/Lifecomplete

reviewText: I've waited a very long time to be able to write this review, and I was not let down. I was initially a little disappointed to learn that the original voice actors wouldn't be returning, but after the initial dislike of change wore off, I do like the replacements they've found.  I also had a bit of an issue getting the game to run initially - I have an older computer that generally has little to no issue, but it was extremely laggy even on the lowest setting. Once I switched to a newer laptop however, the issue was largely fixed, minus a bit of lag in certain areas, Europolis in particular.\n\nI'm in love with the story so far, as well as the answers we've gotten so far for some of the loose threads left over from the previous games. I can't wait to see how it's all going to play out in the end.

reviewText: My wife and I are big fans of the series, we are kickstarter backers of Dreamfall Chapters and we've been eagerly awaiting the release. It was a real let down to actually play it. Here's why: lots of choices presented with big letters saying your choice matters!" but options to choose from that are either almost identical or equally unsavory. So I have to decide whether to pause to kill the wounded guy who helped me or let him be tortured by the guards coming soon... really? The other really annoying thing is the completely unnecessary foul language. Beware: F-bombs galore in this game and plenty of others. It's totally gratuitous. I can only remember one really foul mouth in the previous 2 games (a guy named 'flipper'.) My wife said she doesn't want to play anymore
date: and I've got plenty of other games I could be playing. This game is a disappointing end to a great series."

reviewText:
One of the best games I have ever played. It has interesting characters, great story, choices that affect it, vast locations, good humour and graphics.

This is the third part of a trilogy: The Longest Journey -> Dreamfall -> Dreamfall Chapters. I didn't like The Longest Journey - too many puzzles, weaker plot - didn't finish it. Dreamfall and Dreamfall Chapters are completely different - more videos, fewer puzzles - more like interactive movies. I recommend to play Dreamfall before this one for better experience.

The pros are clear, the cons are: no good map (finding places sometimes takes much more time than it should), some puzzles (don't like puzzles). Though puzzles are not a big deal - if stuck I just read the walkthrough - that way they didn't bother me to much.

reviewText: I. LOVE. THIS. GAME. I was a fan of the classic 2d adventure, The Longest Journey, and really enjoyed Dreamfall as well. But even if you've never touched either of those games, I highly recommend you play this. Some of the best voice acting in games is included in Chapters, as well as some of the best writing. On top of that, the world the story is based in is intriguing and unlike anything you've seen before. Ragnar Tornquist has done it again, bringing an emotionally captivating, deep and immersive world and storyline that is perfectly suited to the interactive experience of a point-and-click adventure. A true testament to games as an interactive storytelling medium. Get it into you now.

reviewText:
I have been waiting a long time for Dreamfall to continue. if you like fantasy adventure with a captivating story then you will enjoy this. This lastest addition to the series is using the desicion making style of game mechanics to get you more involved in the story. I love these kinds of games because they mix up a bit of puzzle solving with good casual gaming. So far I am loving these books. Book one and two have only left me craving the next episode.
If you played the previous games is this series then you absolutely must play this. If its your first experience with these games then to be honest I recommend playing them in sequence because it will make a lot of sense but it is very playable as a solo title. The others can be played and prequels.

Episodes are a good length too with decent amount on content, unlike some other similar desicion based games where the episodes only last just over an hour this was a good 4 hours or so of game time, part of that was running around finding things and locations but thats what adventure games are all about!

reviewText:
After years of waiting whe can finaly continu our journy of Dreamfall.
If you loved the first and second game you will love this one.

The voice acting is amazing as always, The city looks awesome and feels like big a city. I think a walked around for a hour just to click on everything in the city and find some history about the city. It's also a good way to explorer and find your way around the city.
The voice animation is not that great but hey thats dreamfall but because the voice acting is so perfect you wont even bother.

This game will also have a big replay value because of the choices you make. And there are some hard choices to make, its not like you know the best choice because in most cases you dont know, you really have to think twice and make the choice you think is best. But it makes the story go completly different.

If you love a good story or you like The walking dead serie for example then this game is for you. If you dont like to watch alot of talking without any action then this game isn't for you.

If you did't play the first and second game i higly recommend playing it before you start playing on chapters or you could get a little bit lost in the story.

The only downside are the sepperate books and that you need to wait to continu you story. On the plus side the books are pretty long. I think i am almost done whit book 2 and i think il get to 14 hours whit just the 2 books. Not bad for a 30 euro game right?

reviewText:
Sok fajta játék létezik...

Van olyan amivel játszunk pár jó pillanattal gazdagodunk általa.
Vannak olyanok amiket kedvelünk szeretjük az általuk elénk tárt világot ami körbe vesz minket.
Vannak olyanok amiket kedvenceik közé emelünk évek után is betéve tudjuk mozzanatait főszereplőit vicces vagy épp sötét pillanatait.

S vannak a kevesek amik nem csak egyszerűen játszunk ha nem beleolvadunk a világába minden egyes mozzanatát apró rejtett titkát keresve kutatjuk miközben észre sem vesszük az idő múlását.

TLJ széria ezen kevesek közé tartozik a Dreamfall évről évre egyszer elő veszem ,hogy újra elutazhassal Arcadia és Stark az ikervilágok rejtekébe.

Féltem tőle hogy az újra rész mint az megszokott mostanság elszakad attól keserédes gyönyörű történettől amiben eddig részem volt szerencsér Ragnar T. ismét tökéletest alkotott az Első köny nyitánya tartja művészien lenyűgöző színvonalat amiért a KickStarter kampány is csak hála érheti ,hogy ez műremek folytatódhatott.

Maga történet fonalát nehéz felvenni a 3. rész elején rengeteg nehezen érthető és megválaszolatlan kérdéssel szembesül  majd a játékos de még így is könnyedén bele lehet merülni ebbe világba.

Mind April Ryan s Zoe Castillo talán a legérdekesebb karakterek akikkel valaha találkoztam a játékokban. The Longest Journey és The Longest Journey: Dreamfall ajánlom mindenkinek aki szereti a mély fordulatokkal teli történetek a színes érdekes karaktereket. S nem riad vissza némi szellemi kihivástól sem.

Csak a annyit tudnék mondeni a végére: Have a great journey! ^^

reviewText: I. LOVE. THIS. GAME. I was a fan of the classic 2d adventure, The Longest Journey, and really enjoyed Dreamfall as well. But even if you've never touched either of those games, I highly recommend you play this. Some of the best voice acting in games is included in Chapters, as well as some of the best writing. On top of that, the world the story is based in is intriguing and unlike anything you've seen before. Ragnar Tornquist has done it again, bringing an emotionally captivating, deep and immersive world and storyline that is perfectly suited to the interactive experience of a point-and-click adventure. A true testament to games as an interactive storytelling medium. Get it into you now.

reviewText: Dreamfall Chapters Book 2 is awesome. I love how my actions in Book 1 shaped my experience. It made me want to go back and play Book 1 and Book 2 in a different way to see how things would have turned out. The puzzles in this Book were a little more challenging. Not mind bending, but there seemed to be more thought put into them in my opinion. The story is getting better and better and man that cliffhanger. I have to wait 3 or 4 more months for the next Book and it will be the Longest Wait! I was hesitant to pay $30 for the season pass, but I am so happy that I did. It took me 3 hours to complete Book 1 and 6 hours to complete Book 2. That is almost the same length of time spent for the equivalent season of any telltale game.  Not only that but we still have several books to go before the season is over! Are there some graphical glitches? For sure, and I am pretty confident that in the near future, there will be patches to address these issues. Is the game flawless? No, but it is a deep engrossing and awesome story. You will not regret your purchase. I love each and every minute of my experience with Dreamfall Chapters.

reviewText:
The mere existence of this game makes me happy, but it is also actually a really worthy continuation of the Longest Journey franchise.
To think, the last game in this series came out around the same time as Half Life 2...I'd genuinely given up hope of ever seeing the story being resolved, but now it is happening. It makes my heart happy.

This is the only kickstarter game that I have ever backed, and I did so gladly.

It's a choice driven puzzle game in the same kind of style as recent Telltale games. The story has always been great, and still is. Runs really well on my system and the art style is also great.

One of my favourite game series that I have ever played. Might be difficult to get into if you haven't played the previous games, and they (particularly the first one) are starting to look pretty dated now. Dreamfall still holds up quite well though, and is worth playing just for the story.

reviewText: I had never even heard of this series until they ran the kickstarter for Dreamfall Chapters, but it caught my attention. I now own all the games in the series and love them. The only problem I have and it seems to be a common issue is that the game isn't optimized properly. Or so that is what I keep hearing. Personally the game runs fantastic for me on my pc at high settings, but for only 30 minutes or so. After that the framerate drops significantly. I can stop the game and restart and the problem is fixed. Sometimes I even have to logout out of my pc account. Trying to lower the settings does absolutely nothing. I am sure that Red Thread will address this situation at some point. It doesnt make the game unplayable and it is well worth this small inconvenience. It is a treat for the eyes and ears. The graphics wont blow everyone away but the art style really catches the eye. The story for all of these games is probably the best I have encountered in the video game industry and the voice acting from game to game is consistent as well. I think only one major character has a different voice actor in Dreamfall Chapters and it is a vast improvement. (I am a little biased due to the fact that this actor voiced one of my all time favorite video game characters of all time;  Sir Hawke, the Champion of Kirkwall. All in all this game is amazing so far and I am sure books 3-5 will be just as amazing, and I for one cant wait for them to drop. I give it a 9/10 only for the fact that the gameplay is a little soft. Even though its predecessor was lauded for its horrible stealth and combat mechanics, at least it had them.  There is no combat (so far) and there was one instance where you have to avoid a guard by making sure he is pointing in the oppsite direction. If he catches you then it places you outside a gate 20 feet from where you were. And you actually get an achievment for the quest called And you thought there wouldnt be stealth." Despite these minor flaws the game has me hungering for more and I cant wait to see how it all ends."

reviewText:
Amazing game. I played the 2 prequels shortly before beginning this one. They are a brilliant series. I recommend to play the 2 first games beifore this one, to fully understand the story, which can be very complex. Even if they are old games, it is really worth it.

I enjoyed playing choice driven episodic games like the Telltales' one or Life is Strange, but I really think that this one is the best I've tried in this genre. Your choices seem really to matter and the game is not just an 'interactive movie' where you make decisions. There are puzzles inbetween and the game is really a crossing between a point&click and choices matter game, which I enjoy both.

The universe is amazing (as I enjoyed the both previous games) and it has elements from both fantasy and sci-fi. The story is great and has a lot of plots. The characters are various and enjoyable. The graphics are beautiful and the music is nice.

I'm looking forward to playing the last chapter!

The story is great, however only episode 1 is out right now... and it is pretty much just an intro. It is a very good intro though... if you want to play them all at once you may have to wait a while. You do get the full game for the price, no paying more later, so thats good.

The only downside for me so far is that I crave the rest of the story and must wait. This first episode is about 3-5 hours long depending on if you stop and explore the incredible surroundings, so for me about 4.5 hours (I just have to stop and explore things).

If you have not played the first two games they are both on steam(at the time of writing) in a $25 combo pack. As a bonus to the first games being incredibly awesome on their own, maybe by the time you have finished both of them the next episode or two will be released!

reviewText:
This game really has the feel of an interactive novel with relatable protagonists.  Highly recommended.

Compellingly flawed and vulnerable characters explore and grow in this tale of disparate but connected worlds. Dreamfall mixes futuristic modernism with medieval fantasy in a melange of myths that will be sure to intrigue adventure game lovers. I was surprised at how the two (actually three) settings combined to make a narrative whole as the story progressed.

The voiceover acting for most of the main characters is top notch. (The sidekick character seemed to not match the volume and timbre of the other characters IMHO).  Each character is distinctively defined with his or her own motivations.  The choices you make playing the two protagonists are fraught with realistic angst and ethical challenges.  There is no right answer.

I liked the ability to click to see how other players decided to play each turning point--or to not click and go it without peer input.  However, I did not like that some of the decisions were timed with a very short countdown.  I was not aware this would happen at first, and some decisions were made automatically for me because I did not choose in time--not always the way I would have played it.

The game has good repeat play value because of the decisions.  If you'd like to play Kian or Zoe as harsher, more fearful, more selfless, or with a more black-and-white view of moral choices, you can do so.  The curious story of the third protagonist is a bit disconnected, but in a good way. It also has very few choices.  I am curious how she fits in with the other two in the next chapters.

I loved The Longest Journey but missed Dreamfall.  Dreamfall Chapters has massive spoilers for Dreamfall, since the story is continuous--that's a *good* thing.

A caution to those unfamiliar with games released over time: the end of Book 4 is not the end of the game.  The Steam release date for Dreamfall Chapters is listed as October 2014; however, Book 4 was released December 2015.  I bought 1-4 together thinking it was a complete set and was disappointed and surprised at the unfinished ending.  There is no epilogue to indicate when I might be able to get the rest.

Nonetheless, I would buy it again and can't wait for the next release.

reviewText:
A truly captivating story driven game that beautifully immerses the player into the lives of Kian and Zoe.

It starts off slow, running seemingly useless and boring errands, running from one side of the city to the other BUT it gets better.  It builds the foundations of each character so that the player gets a true understanding of what each character resembles. Reading the other reviews, I see that this alone caused many players to lose all hope in the game and give up after only just beginning Book 1. That's their loss.

Dreamfall chapters accomplishes something that many games cannot, to make unqiue, likeable characters. Sounds easy but it is rarely achieved. The choice factor in this game DOES MATTER. Sometimes its something silly, other times it can be the difference between your favourite character surviving or dying. It also strongly matters to the relationships between characters in the game which will further impact how the characters will interact with each other. Will they assist one another or choose not to. That is based on the players dialogue decisions.

Being such a long game, averaging around 20-30 hours for the first 4 Books it really draws out and explores everything that it can, without it seeming like a bland and boring story. The pace is just right.

SUMMARY
This is a beautiful adventure game with gorgeous visuals, logical and likeable characters, a stunning choice of music and a choice-consequence system that can advertently effect the future. Dreamfall Chapters clearly demonstrates that story driven games can still be masterpieces in todays gaming world.

reviewText:
I've really enjoyed this game so far, having completed the four episodes currently released. While Dreamfall Chapters is very much a slow-boil of a story, I also enjoy the amount of time I got to spend in the locales, just soaking in the lushly designed ambience. This is a great looking game. That said, the story is perhaps a little out of balance, with the game and puzzle moments often feeling detached from the ongoing narrative. That said, once you get to the Third and Fourth episodes (Books), the pace really picks up, creating a feleing of greater eveness between game and story.

The decision making moments are really the highlight of the game for me, though - there's a feel of ongoing consequence to the choices you make. Perhaps the story always ends up in a similar place, regardless, but the game does a much better job of integrating your choices into the ongoing narrative than something like The Walking Dead, where your decisions often feel peripheral and meaningless to the story. For anyone who likes a 'Choose Your Own Adventure' Dreamfall Chapters can't come more highly recommended.

For non-adventure gamers I would recommend the game with a few caveats. Obviously it's a beautiful production, but the mechanics of the game offer little flexibility in terms of exploration. Yes, the worlds can be big, but there's ultimately little to do in them besides complete tasks associated with story progression.

reviewText:
I played The Longest Journey and TLJ: Dreamfall and despite their faults I loved them. Though i only just completed chapter 4, so far I can say the same about Dreamfall Chapters. It is a beautiful and well written game that continues directly from where TLJ:Dreamfall left off.

Characters will sometimes remember conversations and decisions you make will have consequences later on in the game, ranging from meaninful to hardly mattering at all (I still don't know what all the consequences might be yet). It's a nice touch no matter how much impact this has ultimately on the story as i find myself thinking more about who Zoe and Kian are and who I want them to become, or at least how they get there (which when your telling a story is more important).

reviewText:
I've played The Longest Journey, Dreamfall: The Longest Journey and Dreamfall: Chapters 1-4 and I'm highly anticipating book 5.

The story is rich and the characters well acted, well rounded and interesting.  If you haven't played The Longest Journey or Dreamfall: TLJ then I highly suggest you do.  These games are well deserved of their status.  The story is original and engrossing, and something I'd never seen before.  The first and second game are quite different in mechanics.  In the second you are able to fight and there are things you can't miss.  In the first pick up everything even if you've placed it somewhere, as you may need it in the future.

Dreamfall Chapters is incredible.  The graphics are a wonderful improvement, the story is still amazing and the characters are what those who have played the first two games have come to love.  The worlds are in peril and I'm still not sure what role Zoe plays in everything but her story is intriguing.  While the first and the second didn't have much choice, the third takes your choices into account and molds the story in regards to your choices.

I reccommend playing the first two before you embark on your journey into Dreamfall:Chapters. If you don't, you'll have a lot of questions and you'll be missing out on the wonders of Arcadia and Stark you've missed by opting out on TLJ and Dreamfall TLJ.

reviewText: I highly recommend playing The Longest Journey or at very least Dreamfall (you can get a recap of either but Dreamfall is at least not very long or difficult) because this game's beauty, depth and worth are even more impressive if you feel a little bit at home in the worlds of Stark and Arcadia. It's been such a long, well, journey and despite the damage that hype and nostalgia can ravage on a new entry to a beloved series, this game just feels right. If you appreciate story and the unique capabilities of games this whole universe is for you, and this latest entry is mesmerizing to say the least. Now let's just get The Longest Journey Home paid for and all us crazy fans who have been following this slow and strange release of games will finally be able to die happy.

reviewText:
The story is great, however only episode 1 is out right now... and it is pretty much just an intro. It is a very good intro though... if you want to play them all at once you may have to wait a while. You do get the full game for the price, no paying more later, so thats good.

On a positive note, the characters, art direction, music, voice acting, are all really high quality and everything fits perfectly with the story.

The story telling is fantastic, but you should definitely play the first two games before this one. Not that its impossible to start with this game, it does have a little intro video you can watch that explains what happened in dreamfall. But I think the first two, being mainly story based, are still incredible experiences despite their age. And this one really does pick up exactly where they left off.

The only downside for me so far is that I crave the rest of the story and must wait. This first episode is about 3-5 hours long depending on if you stop and explore the incredible surroundings, so for me about 4.5 hours (I just have to stop and explore things).

If you have not played the first two games they are both on steam(at the time of writing) in a $25 combo pack. As a bonus to the first games being incredibly awesome on their own, maybe by the time you have finished both of them the next episode or two will be released!

reviewText:
This game really has the feel of an interactive novel with relatable protagonists.  Highly recommended.

Compellingly flawed and vulnerable characters explore and grow in this tale of disparate but connected worlds. Dreamfall mixes futuristic modernism with medieval fantasy in a melange of myths that will be sure to intrigue adventure game lovers. I was surprised at how the two (actually three) settings combined to make a narrative whole as the story progressed.

The voiceover acting for most of the main characters is top notch. (The sidekick character seemed to not match the volume and timbre of the other characters IMHO).  Each character is distinctively defined with his or her own motivations.  The choices you make playing the two protagonists are fraught with realistic angst and ethical challenges.  There is no right answer.

I liked the ability to click to see how other players decided to play each turning point--or to not click and go it without peer input.  However, I did not like that some of the decisions were timed with a very short countdown.  I was not aware this would happen at first, and some decisions were made automatically for me because I did not choose in time--not always the way I would have played it.

The game has good repeat play value because of the decisions.  If you'd like to play Kian or Zoe as harsher, more fearful, more selfless, or with a more black-and-white view of moral choices, you can do so.  The curious story of the third protagonist is a bit disconnected, but in a good way. It also has very few choices.  I am curious how she fits in with the other two in the next chapters.

I loved The Longest Journey but missed Dreamfall.  Dreamfall Chapters has massive spoilers for Dreamfall, since the story is continuous--that's a *good* thing.

A caution to those unfamiliar with games released over time: the end of Book 4 is not the end of the game.  The Steam release date for Dreamfall Chapters is listed as October 2014; however, Book 4 was released December 2015.  I bought 1-4 together thinking it was a complete set and was disappointed and surprised at the unfinished ending.  There is no epilogue to indicate when I might be able to get the rest.

Nonetheless, I would buy it again and can't wait for the next release.

reviewText:
A truly captivating story driven game that beautifully immerses the player into the lives of Kian and Zoe.

It starts off slow, running seemingly useless and boring errands, running from one side of the city to the other BUT it gets better.  It builds the foundations of each character so that the player gets a true understanding of what each character resembles. Reading the other reviews, I see that this alone caused many players to lose all hope in the game and give up after only just beginning Book 1. That's their loss.

Dreamfall chapters accomplishes something that many games cannot, to make unqiue, likeable characters. Sounds easy but it is rarely achieved. The choice factor in this game DOES MATTER. Sometimes its something silly, other times it can be the difference between your favourite character surviving or dying. It also strongly matters to the relationships between characters in the game which will further impact how the characters will interact with each other. Will they assist one another or choose not to. That is based on the players dialogue decisions.

Being such a long game, averaging around 20-30 hours for the first 4 Books it really draws out and explores everything that it can, without it seeming like a bland and boring story. The pace is just right.

SUMMARY
This is a beautiful adventure game with gorgeous visuals, logical and likeable characters, a stunning choice of music and a choice-consequence system that can advertently effect the future. Dreamfall Chapters clearly demonstrates that story driven games can still be masterpieces in todays gaming world.

reviewText: It's the third game in The Longest Journey series, the first of which was to the Point and Click adventure what Freespace 2 was to Space Sims, and Serious Sam was to shooters. The last, and the very best, example of a dying genre. To this day, the story and the gameplay is touching, bittersweet, engaging, and brilliant, unlike anything else.\n\nThe second game, Dreamfall, was produced during the Adventure Dark Ages, and was also excellent. recommended: you owe it to gaming to play this series. all of it."

reviewText:
Slightly different from The Longest Yourney and the previous Dreamfall when it comes to how the point-and-click works. You adapt extremely quickly though and before you know it you find yourself stuck in yet another beautiful game.

The fun part about this game is the fact that you feel you're watching a movie - and actually get to choose some of the plot yourself, a lot of people has criticized the story but i personally love it!  Red Thread Games just posted a great movie for those of you that either can not remember the story from the previous games, or the ones that has not played either of them. I don't feel it is a 100% necessary for you to know the story behind but it will absolutely enhance your perception of the game.

It is an absolutely stress-free game so far, and a game you can enjoy whether you're tired, up for a movie, ready for some action or just bored and looking to spend some easy time. This, combined with loads of riddles, makes it the perfect game.

A few glitches here and there as the game is still in an early stage, but the publisher is really listening to their players when it comes to reports and bugfixing etc. I still have not stumbled across any glitches that are severe enough to require a report.

As i mentioned earlier, this is yet another beautiful game. I have always favoured Arcadia and seeing the graphic quality-facelift they've put on stark, i can hardly wait for loads and loads of more level designs and hopefully lots of Arcadia. I'll be like christmas everytime a new chapter gets released. Well done, red thread games! I love it and the game absolutely lives up to my expectations.

reviewText:
Definitely worth it if you were a fan of the previous installments. If you're new to the Longest Journey saga - you might want to wait until more chapters are released. Or go play Dreamfall!

I played through the first chapter in about 4 hours. The story is immersive and richy detailed. Europolis was a beautiful example of how a cyberpunk city should look. Can't wait for the next chapters to come out.

On the downside, there were a couple minor bugs that I noticed. The characters lips and words did not always match up all that well in some of the scenes. The controls are a little different and take some getting used to - but they did away with the horrible combat controls I suffered through in Dreamfall so I can't complain that much.

Zoe was hilarious as usual. I wish there'd been more Arcadia but hopefully in the next chapters.

Definitely glad I bought.

reviewText:
Dreamfall Chapters is a very worthy successor to TLJ and Dreamfall. Once again featuring rich story-telling and world building while at the same time being completely hilarious at times it's an absolute joy to play and watch.

While the ending is a bit abrupt, that's to be expected in an episodic game release - the post game screens promise a lot of further consequences to your chosen actions during book one.

Which leads to the main (though probably fixable) criticism: DFC should really include the option to save different playthroughs (the way the Mass Effect games do for example) to see the effect of your choices in future games.

Nevertheless a highly recommended game!

reviewText:
I guess there's some spoilers in this. If you loved the previous games, then definitely get it, but if you have no idea what this game is, then first play through at least Dreamfall: The Longest Journey, and if you're ever so bold to play through an old game then play the Longest Journey as well before you play this. It will be worth it, I promise. The game will be that more satisfying. Though if you want the real experience, play those games, then wait 8 years and then play this. That way you get the full waiting game down. I guess this is more geared towards people who played the previous versions.

A second sequel to the classic Longest Journey, however one doesn't need to play the first two to jump right into this game. I highly recommend the other games as the games do have journey in the name, and while someone could understand everything from the recap they have in the main menu, I thought of it as more of the developers strumming my nostalgic strings.

While there are problems with the game, the writing, music, and scenery still drive me to explore every bit of the game. The main problems with game I have are when the characters talk and the other characters they talk to don't seem to be engaged into the conversation at all. They devolve in this reserved blank stare as they are listening to the other speak, and the other speaking doesn't seem to maintain eye contact or even shift eyes or do any other special animations. Whil this was passable for old games in 2006, this is 2014, and we have super machines that can handle all the animations, so please animators or animation director or whatever, please unleash the full vision of the writers and artists.

Other than that I also still get graphic artifacts on my screen when walking around Europolis or whatever. Especially around the hotdog stand with the communist vendor. Socialism vs. Communism aside, I saw at certain angles when I tried to give myself the movie experience were bright red faded squares of light, but maybe that's just the developers giving me a hint. Karl Marx=God

Bad aside, the music is just too damn pretty and perfect. Maybe they hired Hans Zimmer, I don't know. Throughout the game I couldn't tell if I had shed a tear for the pretty scenic colors, the writing, or the music, and you damned developers outdid yourselves in that regard. The writing is certainly better in this, it feels as though my choices throughout the game actually matters, though I fear it's too much of a good thing and I'm going to be strong along in later chapters, please don't realize my fears. Probably because you flash this choice has consequences and so and so will remember this whenever I make any sort of decision. I'm so damn skeptical and think, oh yeah sure." I'd get rid of that little text entirely

reviewText:
First off, I want to say big THANK YOU to Ragnar and his team for doing such a marvelous job at creating a serie like this. I know that I shouldn't put these things on the very beginging of my review but screw this - I first got in touch with The Longest Journey when I was, I don't know, 5 years old? I still remember my grandma who bought me it and I played it together with my sister. Then I was 10 and I could play Dearmfall: The Longest Journey. I loved it (and I still do love it) and I can say that I pretty much have grown up on this game and a fantastic world Ragnar has created. Thank you.

Getting to the very main point of my review I want to talk about technical issues first. It was quite a shock to jump from Dreamfall's Zoe and Kian to Chapter's Zoe and Kian and I think that I liked Dreamfall's version better. Crashes happend - a lot. Lack of optimalization was compensated by the cool look of the game, even on the lowest settings. It is kind of a plus. I liked the way I could control my character, I didn't hit as many walls as I did in the Dreamfall. But again - crashes in the city made my play very uncomfortable. Yes, I have to admit - my PC isn't the newest on the stock but it is not an antique either! I heard from other players that I am not the only one so maybe there is some way to optimalize so big and detailed places like Europolis? Maybe there is not, I can see that you guys have put a lot of work into this location, but not pointing out that one would be pure insincerity.

Oh, how I loved big complitated world of TLJ! And you know what? The realm in Dreamfall Chapters have not let me down <3 I can see so many links with the first part that I could cry in front of my computer - so many memories! The characters have not lost anything from their charm (my dear Kian, you are so hated by other fans but you've got me even more with your attitude against...shh, no spoilers!). I am truly amazed. RTS, you have a pat on the back from me *pat pat*

All in all, I strongly recommend this game. It was worth waiting for 8 years to see such a great production. I can see that the creators have put a lot of heart into what they were doing here, this game has a spirit, it provokes to think about some important matters like manipulation, thoughtless entertainment, 'corporialism'. What's more, this complex world and plot is flavoured with witty humour and nice dialogues between well-constructed characters.

And finally, this game has no linear plot, which makes a gamer pour a little of his own thinking into choices he makes ;)

reviewText:
Thought I would write a few lines to even out some of what I find to be ludicrous negative points to make about an Adventure game.
If you don't have a high enough I.Q to read a map and find your way around a reasonable sized area, then stick to the mindless game offerings of EA and the like. The Forums at Red Thread Games are a great way to get help if you need it.

The main draw of the game is the storyline, characters and dialog. Plus more Longest Journey is always a good thing. The 2nd book alone is longer than lot of other games. By the time all books are out, you might be looking at round 30 or more hours of game time, and thus is superb value for money.

If you like Adventure games, then DFC is up there with the best of them. I would also recommend playing the previous games.

reviewText:
Great follow-up so far to the previous games - we're only at Book 3 at this time, still got a little more to go (five books in total, I believe).  Furthers the stories of Zoe Castillo and her involvement in Wati Corp's mind control conspiracy through dreams that is happening in Stark, the world of science and order, as well as Kian Alvane's involvement in a concurrent dream-stealing conspiracy of sorts that is occurring in the parallel world of Arcadia, the world of magic and chaos. Zoe has easily become one of my all-time favorite video game personalities since she was introduced in this game's predecessor, Dreamfall: The Longest Journey - can't get enough of her.

The recently-released revamp that converts the entire game to the Unity 5 engine is a pretty significant difference. I thought the game looked great before - what a MAJOR difference in the lighting and shadowing effects this version of Unity has on offer. It's a very welcome improvement over the original iteration of the game that was built on Unity 4. Maybe it's just me, but it seems the in-game antialiasing is much more effective now as well.

If you're a fan of story-driven games, decision-making consequences affecting various environment variables (similar to Telltale's Walking Dead series), and no combat, this is a great game for you. I'm a sucker for a good story, and between the three games that make up this franchise thus far, it's a damned good story.

Awesome job Red Thread, and thanks for getting back to Zoe and this story overall, it's certainly a great one that needed some long-overdue progression.

reviewText:
(No spoilers)
Narratively this is a real joy to play. There are not many games like this out there.
One minute you're saving people from nightmares, the next you're arguing with your loved one about the dishes.
The story is rich and complex.
It was recently updated to the Unity 5 engine, and it looks beautiful.
The developers have created excellent aesthetics that fit the stories well.
An important thing to know is: it's a kind of interactive story, with puzzles,
and choices - that actually matter in this game. So don't expect 'traditional' gameplay.
Also, if you're stuck, try out every option possible, literally. Examine everything!

A few points of criticism:
- The solution to some puzzles require very specific ways to use the UI.
(E.g. at one point I accidentally apprehended the wrong person because I didn't know what a symbol meant.)
- The animations could be better. It's sad because everything else looks fine.
- Quite a few objects could use proper collision meshes. It's a detail but walking through objects breaks immersion.
(E.g. in the Pandemonium the robots on the wall have no collision at all.)

All in all, one of my favourite games. Wholeheartedly recommended!

reviewText:
As a fan of The Longest Journey and Dreamfall, Chapters has been on my radar pretty much since it became public knowledge (I cursed The Secret World for delaying it).  With such a lead-time, games generally will either fail to live up to the hype (possibly being objectively terrible [sorry Duke]) or be truly amazing.  I am happy to report that Dreamfall Chapters falls closer to that selective second category (a bit too early to tell if it'll stay there).  The music, voice acting and sound engineering are excellent, the graphics are beautiful (the landscape/background design particularly), the environmental details greatly amplify the realism of the unabashedly-surreal world and the writing, well, it's Ragnar Tornquist & company (need I say more?).  While the episodic format is a significant shift in pace from the earlier games, it makes sense on many levels (not the least of which being developer budget) and allows the content to remain fresh enough for multiple different playthroughs, which is more important in Chapters as the choice aspect is central to the way the story plays out.  The start is a bit abrupt if you haven't played the other games in the series, so I recommend playing through The Longest Journey and Dreamfall first (and in general), though Chapters does stand on its own.
Right now it's short and sweet; highly recommended.

TL; DR:
Pros: Story (writing), dialogue (writing), graphics, music, voice acting, sound editing, environmental interaction, world design.
Cons: Short (episode), heavily focused on previous story content (with brief synopsis), some minor clipping/finishing detail issues

reviewText:
Dreamfall Chapter is completing the story from The Longest Journey: Dreamfall from 2006.

reviewText: It isn't perfect, but it is faithful to the series.  Picks up right where Dreamfall left off.  Honestly, there are so many things that could have gone wrong with this, but if you were able to stomach the combat of Dreamfall and still liked the game, this is a no brainer.  Me?  I loved Dreamfall, and this just feels the same.  Story focus is largely on Zoe (thankfully), who remains a compelling, but conflicted charater.  They added a lot of swears this time, which can be a bit jarring.  That, and the opening scene ending where Zoe confronts a familiar character from Dreamfall lying in bed (no spoilers, but I am not referriing to Vagabond or any of the dream characters) is really odd and seems to come out of nowhere, given the character in Dreamfall.  So does the backstory about Zoe's dad.  It is tough to reconcile these with the previous game.  Still, these are tolerable nits.  Maybe bigger, bolder words are in order, but they would amount to the same: worth it if you're a fan.  Good luck!  And I can't WAIT to see where they go wtih this plot.  I'm very happy Red Thread elected to ease us in" with the first book.  The best is yet to come
