reviewText:
Okay, it's been many years in the waiting but in the end it was worth the wait.

On a negative side, the game still feels like a beta quality - most importantly, the performance is not really optimized and the FPS  is poor. This is partially attributed to Unity I guess but even with that in mind I believe there's still a lot of space for optimization. Also, there are hundreds of anoying and not so annoying lesser bugs. But all of these could be easily fixed before the next chapter - so no worries here. Great game with tons of bugs is way better than a poor but polished one in my book.

Other than that, things are looking pretty amazing for Dreamfall Chapters. Most importantly, so far this looks like the true TLJ game to me. The storytelling, the characters the atmosphere, the locations - all is in place and lives up to the high bar of expectations set by the original games. It seems like the team behind the game has made a solid work and clearly has an ambition of delivering the best TLJ experience possible (given, of course, the short budget they have).

So far, only the first of five books (episodes) has been released. While most players seem to complete this episode in ~5 hours, it took me ~8 with all the exploration. This btw is quite long for an episodic adventure game as most of the Walking Dead or The Wolf Among Us episodes are clocking in at 2-2.5 hours. So we can expect at least 25 hours of TLJ goodness for a fair price of just under $20.

For those of you wondering - please don't expect Red Thread Games to charge you more for each episode. You buy the game now, pay once and get the episodes as they're ready to roll.

reviewText:
THIS IS AN ANALYSIS FOR THE FIRST BOOK
Dreamfall Chapters is a very good game with stunning voice acting and graphics but unforunately it has a poorly optimization, I hope there is a fix for the fps drop in several regions and some controllers support in the upcoming updates. The story is very interesting, I haven't played nor The Longest Journey nor Dreamfall: The Longest Journey, but you kind of get intrigued with the story, also the way the story is told, reveals you what happened before so if you haven't played previous games that doesn't make so much of a difference. In the matter of gameplay it is good for the ones that like slow paced games, in my opinion it has a lot of dialogues, that many persons would consider boring, if you're looking for shooting combat, etc. this is not the game for you, it is more like point a click game with a very good story.
Conclusion
If you're looking for a game with good graphics and story for a reasonable price and you can tolerate some minor issues with the game this is totally a game for you.
9/10 would recommend.

reviewText:
Fantastic game and very active developers! RedThreadGames goes way and beyond to be there for the community, answering questions and frequently update on the progress of the chapters. It's a big leap to do the sequel to the game Dreamfall - The Longest Journey, as well as The Longest Journey. There has been many opinions about how the story is throught trough or not, if you tie ends together with the games before. I'm one of those who thinks it's a good way to continue the story from previous games and I feel like they keep the mystic feeling about that something is amiss while at the same time moving forward to an answer. Some choices seem very easy in the beginning but this game constantly reminds you to expect the unexptected. The more you play, the more you try to get the puzzle together about what is happening.

I think I did about 5 play throughs for the currently released chapters (3) and each time I got to experience something new. There are main choices that put you in an certain direction and the smaller choices in dialogues and situations shape who you are and how others perceive you.  I think the game is stunningly beautiful. especially the clothing of the main characters and how they move and talk. You are there, in the world, not just watching it from your computer monitor. When a game makes you feel that, it's a game worth playing :)

reviewText:
I have to say, I do like this game. A lot.

There is fantastic graphical update to previous titles. The voice acting is far, FAR improved upon compared to Dreamfall where I thought it lacked. The characters are witty, involving, and much more developed than they were in Dreamfall to, making this a sound development from the previous title.

The game movement is slow but then that has been consistent throughout all games, in some way it adds to the pacing of the story. Overall there are some much improved features. The decision making in this game is superb. The decisions do feel weighty, there are some really tough ones to make and the effects of them ripple through the story well.

Good style of play, harkening back to the first game. No sign of any combat which I really didn’t like from Dreamfall so that is a plus too. Overall this game really seems to have nailed what I wanted more of from Dreamfall.

Story is very good, driving, mysterious, far more engaging than Dreamfall and better written than The Longest Journey.

This is by far the best of the lot.

reviewText: The Longest Journey is back after so many years of waiting, and i couldn't be happier to experience it again, i played both The Longest Journey and Dreamfall when they came out years ago and i got hooked on the fantastical but mature story, the awesome characters and the comedy (oh my god the comedy, despite some dark events TLJ and Dreamfall never ceased being funny and witty and to a great effect.\n\nNow let's see what we have here, the long awaited continuation of the Dreamfall story, Zoe's story, i can't deny i'm a big fan of April and adore her character but Zoe too grew on me, not as much as April but she has her charm too (sadly her sweet accent from Dreamfall is absent her due to VA change but no big deal really as the voice acting overall is still fantastic), the story of Dreamfall Chapters picks up right where Dreamfall:TLJ left us hanging, and it is clear that that the graphics got a major upgrade (which is always welcome, and it was funny when i saw they called the highest graphics option Awesome" instead of Ultra or something else boring
recommended: Zoe looks a little different after spending some time in the realm of dreams but it's good to see her again and resolve her dilemma early on instead of dragging it on and on.\n\nNow the real highlight is the gameplay
hoursPlayed: gone are the clunky combat/stealth sequences from Dreamfall:TLJ and now the game actually evolved and adapted new mechanics from the best storytellers in gaming now (hint hint
voteText: yeah Telltales)
helpfulPercent: and i love they added their own spin to the mechanics
votesHelpful: first you can hear the character's own thoughts before you pick a dialog choice .. not only does it give a chance for the voice actors to further flesh out the characters but also gives us insight into their mindsets
votesTotal: there is also the fact they highlight the important critical choices that will impact the story and let you know what other players chose before you pick your choice ... also .. i was surprised to see The Witcher 2 level of boldness where they block and entire section of the game based on a choice you make early on (now that's some consequence i'd like to see more often
votesFunny: but it's probably why some people might think the episode was short)
commentsCount: oh .. and the witty humor that made the TLJ games so much fun is back .. loads of it .. Zoe now is reaching April's level of wittiness with snarky remarks and snappy witty jokes which is great since we don't get much of April in ep1 (won't spoil it more than that)
column16: IMO the length of the episode is spot on and the back and forth between Kian and Zoe was nice for sake of variety ... some people are complaining about lack of complex puzzles but i have to disagree
column17: the puzzles here are simple and story relevant in a good way
column18: so while i kinda enjoyed the tough puzzles of The Longest Journey some of them were too hard and ruined the pacing of the game when you spent too much time trying to figure out how to solve them .. i managed to finish them all without any online guides (except one early puzzle that required some pixel hunting)
column19: so i'm glad the focus is on the story this time
column20: if i wanted to play a puzzle game i'd go play Portal 2 or The Talos Principle.\n\nOh
column21: and there is that sweet surprise at the end
column22:
although only players of TLJ will know its full significance and recognize the location but either way it's still very intriguing and interesting section that i didn't expect at all .. adds lots of mystery and makes me so eager to play the next episode.

To sum it up:
+The return of one of the best adventure games out there
column23:
Telltales have a serious competitor now.

+Fantastic top notch Voice acting and music.

simple puzzles that don't get in the way of the story.

Overall i'm very satisfied with the first episode and didn't regret buying this one bit

reviewText:
Edited after the third episode is out

A great start to a sequel of one the best adventure game series.

Book one is about 4-5 hours long (depending how long you spend running around looking at the pretty graphics). Book two is much bigger about 8 hours and book three is about 4 again. With two more books to come its fairly evident this will be one big adventure.

Game is gorgeous , has a pretty good ost, great characters and great VO (shitbot!). Story is good and the first book (or episode if you prefer) set the tone for the game great introduced a lot of characters and happenings that will become more apparent later on.  There is a lot of brancing decision wise in the game so far. Small decisions will have big impact later on you will find.

Last but not least on the positive side (at least for me) is the minimalistic UI which just get out of your way so you can enjoy looking around without a permanent ui in the way. Its very contextual so mostly it's just not there and popups when there is something to interact with. Loved it. more games need stuff like this.

The technical problems the game had (some low fps in europolis) when it came out have long been fixed.


TLDR : Get it. If you like adventure games. Or good stories. Or people that actual behave in a believable manner (in a game about magic,shifters dreamers etc no less). Just get it. Its great.

reviewText:
Let's get this out of the way, you won't be satisfied with what this game has to offer if you're looking for some hardcore puzzles and amazing gameplay, but what it offers has heart.

I personally enjoy going through this game so far and I would wholeheartedly recommend it, however it is far from perfect.

The characters actually have character and are memorable, the story and script is fun and interesting, especially if you've played or at least have knowledge about the previous games in the series. There are some technical issues once in a while such as playable character disappearing if you skip dialogues too fast, or wonky camera in some parts, and the puzzles may be too simple for those looking for a real brain-twister, but I do find that most of them make sense" for the presented situations you're supposed to solve
date: and I personally prefer my puzzle being accessible than having to look up a guide for it after 3 hours of trial and error."

reviewText: I didn't have the highest expectations, but the first part of Dreamfall Chapters blew me away with its interesting and nuanced characters, wonderfully fleshed out settings, and a story I couldn't pull myself away from for it's 4-5 hour duration. Any issues with the controls from the previous game have been eradicated in favor of a simple and concise setup with no stealth or combat present. There were some stilted animations and an over-reliance on bloom in the lighting, but those issues were easily negligible when compared to the story that unfolded before me. Only time will tell if the choices I made have interesting consequences, but for the moment, this game shows how powerful a gripping story can be to a game.\n*Edit*\nMade it through book four and I'm still in love with this story. The characters, man, the ♥♥♥♥ing characters are so STRONG. Book 2 was a bit of a dip, but after that it was just fantastic. Also one of my favorite characters popped back in at book 3 and stuck around, and that's always a plus.
voteText: 5 of 10 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
It's hard to properly express how I feel about this... I have waited over 8 years for the continuation of this story that has meant more to me than any other story ever told. The wait is finally over, and it seems it has been worth it! Seeing these amazingly well written characters again is like being reunited with old friends. I would recommend this game to anyone who is a lover of good stories, even non-gamers.

Disclaimer: This review only covers impressions from book 1.

So... About the game. If you are looking for a fast paced game with a good combat system, this game is not for you. There is no combat. If you are easily offended this game is probably not for you either. It is a mature game, and characters in it reflect the wide variety of people you find in the real world. There are offensive characters. There is profanity. It is relatable. On the topic of characters, that's one area where this game truly shines! The characters you meet feel genuine, they feel complex. Real. This is a reflection of the overall fantastic writing which is revealing a thought provoking, deep and mature yet magical story. The dialogue alone had me laugh out loud on several occasions, while other moments pulled at my heartstrings. Of course this is only book one, but it is clear that great things are set in motion already.

About choices. Choices make up a key aspect of the actual game-play. They are difficult! Generally there are no obvious good vs. evil choices. Most are morally grey. But they do impact your story in important ways. To help you make the choice you will hear the PC's inner though process as you mouse over each choice. This very effectively serves the dual purpose of letting you get to know the characters better while helping you guess at what the PC will say.

This game is visually stunning. Sure, if you compare it to the flashiest of the AAA next-gen titles you might find the graphics a bit lacking. But the artstyle is fantastic and it is clear that the world has been crafted with a careful eye for detail. The two worlds of Stark and Arcadia feature very distinct styles, yet there is a cohesiveness that tie them together.

The Soundtrack is simply amazing amazing. There is one spot in Europolis where you will find a crowd of NPCs around a musician, and I found myself standing around for a few minutes just listening. But even the music coming out of radios, night clubs and the atmospheric" music is all highly effective and does a great job of underlining the impact of the story. The voice acting is also absolutely superb. Better even than most AAA titles I have played. I must admit it took some getting used to the new voice for Zoe
date: but she does such a good job I quickly got over it.\n\nTL:DR - If you love a good story and great characters
recommended: buy it. The interactions with Shitbot alone are worth it."
hoursPlayed: October 23, 2014

But the artstyle is fantastic and it is clear that the world has been crafted with a careful eye for detail. The two worlds of Stark and Arcadia feature very distinct styles, yet there is a cohesiveness that tie them together.

The Soundtrack is simply amazing amazing. There is one spot in Europolis where you will find a crowd of NPCs around a musician, and I found myself standing around for a few minutes just listening. But even the music coming out of radios, night clubs and the atmospheric" music is all highly effective and does a great job of underlining the impact of the story. The voice acting is also absolutely superb. Better even than most AAA titles I have played. I must admit it took some getting used to the new voice for Zoe
date: but she does such a good job I quickly got over it.\n\nTL:DR - If you love a good story and great characters
recommended: buy it. The interactions with Shitbot alone are worth it."

reviewText:
Review of Book One:

From begeining to end this is short...Too short and the jail area is just very poor. Game looks a decade behind the times. Mouth movement is very off and choppy. That is until you get to Zoe and her city. This looks a lot better but the game runs so glitchy. Crashed a few times on me and often the system stops to catch up to you. This has a very very poor unpolished feel. However when your standing still or walking slow the game does look very good.

I feel more interactions could have been worked into the city area. A mini map would be a god send as the city map system is very hard to clearly understand as its vague. All in all I love the story and the landscape graphics are good the people could use alot more work. I think mouth movement could be stopped all together and it create a better feel. It would be old school but at least a better old school.

I am only glad that for the money your going to get all the chapters and not have to fork over more each time. That would end things right there for me.

reviewText:
~Book Four Review~
Well, I've already decided to update this review after the release of book 5 and re-write it as a one whole review. I'd still put some of my thoughts about Revelations;
Chapters 10, 11, and even the Interlude that follows, are probably the best sections of the game for me.
The plot really gets stronger here, at last. And while the 3 previous books (which are more than half of the game!) felt like they were just a warm-up for what's coming, here things finally start moving somewhere, and fast.

I did feel rather disappointed at some points, as Chapters became a little like a walking simulator, Zoe travelled through some pretty impressive locations but had very minimal interactions with her surroundings. And no, I haven't forgiven yet to the very straight-forwards puzzles.

But book 4's plot was so strong and moving for me, and that made me satisfied of Chapters at last.
Also, I believe that only in book 4 you actually get to feel the consequences of your choices (I did say earlier that it feels like your choices are simply thrown out of the window. Well, apparantly they're not).

Hoping for a nice finale! and hopefully a better review aboutthe entire game once book 5 is released.

~Book Three Review~
I'm going to exceed the maximum length possible so I'll go short on this one as well.
Techincally it's pretty much the same as book 1 and 2, although for some reason I experienced framerate drop but I can live with that.
Anyway, Book 3 was alright, but left me rather disappointed. The TLJ universe is famous for its slow starts but then it all supposed to get amazingly good. Well in book three I got a rather thin and disappointing plot, not too deep and engaging like the first game in the series or even like books 1&2.
I really hopes throughout the entire game that it's going to finish in an impressive way but.. not, it all felt very typical and shallow, unfortunately. I still had a good time playing the three books and so I leave this as a positive review, and expecting books 4&5 to start get things going and get back to the roots of the series' epicness.

~Book Two Review~
Basically, I don't have much to add to my thoughts about book one.
I'm a huge fan of the TLJ universe and games, and I enjoyed this episode a lot, but I still can't help but have mixed feeling about DF:Chapters.

First of all, by the time of the release of book two, most technical issues were solved (about time!) and I could finally play with high graphics settings, which was really fun and nice to watch.
Marcuria is designed wonderfully and beautifully and would  cause every TLJ fan a great joy.

The story, the writing, the characters are all as good as always and are the main attractions of the game.

The choices are getting more interesting and difficult each time.

It's all nice and well, but some wicked thoughts are lingering in my mind:
1)Where is it all going? Hard to believe but we're arriving soon to the middle of Dreamfall Chapters, and instead of answering some questiong aroused in Dreamfall, we're only getting more and more new questions unanswered.

2)Why not making the gameplay interesting as well?
And yes, there are good and interesting puzzles which I enjoyed, but many times I started feeling bored, just running around from place to place, doing some errands from the goals list, until some critical moment came where something dramatic happened and you had to make a choice.
Unfortunately this game is almost entirely all about the story, and not much about the actual 'game'

3)Music
Why, oh why.. The music in TLJ and DF was so good, so memorable, and here.. it seems like not much thought was put to the subject. And speaking of good stories and tales, music is a very important addition to the subject!
In book one I though the music was fine and expected it to get better fit next time..
But book two has barely any new addition to the soundtrack. The music is mostly reused from book one and is not much felt, which is disappointing.

Anyway, the game in whole still rocks because of the terrific story, of course. Hopefully it would stay that way.

~Book One Review~

In short:

Good stuff -
*Great complex story, the long awaited continuation for Dreamfall TLJ
*Cool soundtrack
*Choices and consequences concept introduced into the game
*Graphics are cool
*Good writing and characters

Bad stuff -
*Not yet fully optimized for PCs and specifically for 32bit version of Windows (even after patch 1.1.2)
*Performance and graphics don't justify system requirements
*Game relies solely on story, not gameplay. Again.
*Still too early to tell where the game is going and whether it's going to be good or disappointing

I have good things to say about this game, but!

Unfortunately, I'll have to start by saying that technically, this game is not too good. After waiting 7 years for a sequel, when you pre-order a product full price, then get release-delays, and then you have to struggle with the game and with your computer to run stuff properly.... Well, that's a bad start. Really bad start.
Anyway, I had to buy more RAM and install a 64-bit OS on my system to run this game properly, and if I wasn't an advacned user, I would have been left feeling that I've thrown 30$ to the garbage.

Though, considering the fact that RTG is a new and small company, that they have released pretty fast 3 patches for the game by now (which improved performance but didn't solve my problems anyway), and also considering that they're keeping in touch with the fans, supporting and trying to help as much as possible, keeping the fans updated through every advancement..

Well, Red Thread Games earned my respect, despite this highly unoptimized product.

Good. So, now, for the game itself.
It's good. Pretty damn good even, but possibly because I'm already in love with the TLJ universe.
The writing is good in my opinion, as expected, and it's the game's main strength.
I really enjoyed the story and characters, both old and new ones.
The soundtrack has taken a new and interesting direction, which fits the game's new style.
Seems like the devs took some inspiration from Telltale's choices&consequences concept, which I like.
And generally, I enjoyed playing book one and the very opening really got me into this 'new' story.

Gameplay-wise, this game plays much like its predecessor. I thought that they'd polish Dreamfall's action sequences (so-called sneaking and combat) but instead they were completely thrown away and we're left with adventure-elements only and the new choices&consequnce idea. The puzzles are also rather easy (although they are more innovative than those on Dreamfall in my opinion).
I really hoped the developers would listen to the fans about this one, and would make the gameplay more challanging, engaging and worthwhile. But it seems like they have stayed with their old paths and there again the game relies mostly on story.

The graphics look beautiful and alive but are not stunning, and not they nor the game's performance justify the system requirements.

Europolis is the largest area in book one, and looks interesting at first, but later it becomes an annoyance when you have to run long distances around without any reward or encouragement for exploring, as when you do that you'd mostly find people talking about politics and basically feel like a big part of the content is duplicated over Europolis.

Despite my complaints, I did get really excited about Chapters and Book One, enjoyed it and am looking forward for the continuation.
My only fear is that Chapters has 7 long years of waiting to fill, and doesn't go humble about its ambitions. If the developers won't polish the game some more, and won't improve it's weak points, they could easily turn it into a disappointment.
Now is simply too soon to predict whether Chapters is going to be a fulfilling title or just leave us feeling empty.

reviewText:
Beautiful, exquisite, engrossing. Dreamfall Chapters continues the story of Dreamfall and The Longest Journey in a beautifully rendered, exquisitely voice-acted, and engrossingly written episodic game where your choices affect the outcome and direction of the story.

As with most initial releases, there are a few hiccups with FPS in various areas regardless of the player's machine configuration. The developers have been responsive and acknowledged these complaints and working towards fixes. I commend them for being responsive as they are, I've seen MANY companies drop the ball. I've only run into a few FPS issues (namely the intro movie) but seem to be fine going through Europolis (where lots of people have been complaining).

I do not regret this purchase in the slightest and am eager for the upcoming chapter releases. I stand by my choice to pre-order the Special Edition (since I missed the Kickstarter campaign).

voteText: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Iv'e been waiting for Dreamfall Chapters to come out since the last game ended on a cliff hanger. and so far it does not dissapoint!. (there thats for fans of the series)

For newcommers, Dreamfall Chapters is a 3D adventure game in the manner of Walking Dead and many of the old point and click games from the early years of video games on PC.

Now Ill say this now. you should play The Longest Journey: Dreamfall before you play this game (you do not have to play The Longest Journey but its got some usefull backstory and can help expand your appreciation of the world) now you do not have to in order to enjoy the game but it will have that much more meaning and you will really understand the characters and events at the start of the game if you have finished the earlier game.

on with the rest of the review:

What sets this game apart from its forebears is that it has a tree based structure to its storyline. so for each choice you make there is a real consequence. Now thats the claim from Red Thread the studio responsible for the game.
As there is only the first part of the game available, it remains to be seen how extensive this system of choices is, but after some time playing the first book and trying every choice I could make. I am fairly confident that the game will deliver in its promises with upcomming episodes.

The game uses two choice systems, one is the Balance system a set of events that have a coinflip answer, where the resulting choice greatly effects future outcomes for the character. the other is a walking dead esque system where characters remember your reactions to various events and these are taken into account with future conversations and events.
while many of the choices and events presented provided numerous choices and possibilities, there were very few choices available that had immediate results. I am greatly looking forward to the second book to see how these choices pan out.

Now, it would be remiss of me to not mention some current issues with the game:
It has some known graphical bugs and issues with resource usage they are working on fixes for.( they fixed the large framerate drop happening in Europolis and other areas)
Some people are having crashes and freezes (not me but some people are)
The save game system needs work because it just makes a ton of autosave files without any sensible naming system or organisation.(only an issue if you want to try a different response or load a non current game)


The game is mainly about making choices and solving puzzles, this in future will include things like stealth and probably some light combat. but it will be unlikely that combat will be particularly reflex intensive or action oriented.
Characters in the dream world seem to have various powers so a kind of magic is also featured in the game in certain areas.

Will you enjoy this game?
If you liked games like myst, the stanley parable, any older point and click adventure  you will love this game.

if your into combat and violence, you may still enjoy it but it will feel slow and boring due to long heavy dialogue sequences and alot of travelling.

I love what they have done with dreamfall chapters and am looking forward to the next chapter to see how far they will go.

reviewText:
After so many years of believing that I'd never see a true sequel to The Longest Journey/Dreamfall, I was very excited to see this long-awaited new chapter emerge! I 've always felt that the conclusion to Dreamfall left so many unanswered questions so when Chapters came along, I had to jump right back in and see where the story would take me.

Thumbs Up:
- A well written continuation of the events in the previous game. Zoe feels very authentic regardless of the decisions she's faced with making. I can only assume that Kian will be given the same kind of development as the additional Chapters are released.
- A fully realized environment. The layout of Propast feels filled in and lively.
- Interaction with almost everything in the enviroment. Even if Zoe or Kian can't touch or use something directly, they will have thoughts and feelings to share with the player.
- Continuity and nostalgia. So many story elements from the previous games are faithfully touched on and added to. There are a number of little tributes to Dreamfall and The Longest Journey if you know where to look!
- Every decision counts. I particularly like this feature. It makes doing multiple playthroughs worthwhile.
- An AMAZING soundtrack. So much of the score is just brilliantly done and it does a great job of conveying the story without being overbearing.
- Driven by narrative. Chapters definitely covers a lot of ground in a short amount of time. It feels like a really good book or TV show. However, as it does not feature combat (so far), this may not be everyone's cup of tea.

Thumbs Down:
- Some of the voice acting is a little hard to listen to. Additionally, the amount vulgar language just seems to be overkill. A little bit can add spice and depth to a character. Too much just makes them uninteresting.
- Some of the puzzles and goals could stand to have a bit more explanation to them. I'm not talking outright hand-holding, but a gentle nudge or exposition could go a long way. Especially if you're negotiating between two people...
- Many of the NPC are too identical. Repitions in hairstyle and clothing tend to break up the immersion, unfortunately.
- Optmization issues. Even with settings at the lowest, this game could suffer from framerate issues on some machines. The is VERY noticeable in Propast.

Overall:
This is a worthy sequel. It feels finished and fully fleshed out. I'm enjoying it immensely and I cannot wait to see what happens next.

reviewText:
It's hard to properly express how I feel about this... I have waited over 8 years for the continuation of this story that has meant more to me than any other story ever told. The wait is finally over, and it seems it has been worth it! Seeing these amazingly well written characters again is like being reunited with old friends. I would recommend this game to anyone who is a lover of good stories, even non-gamers.

Disclaimer: This review only covers impressions from book 1.

So... About the game. If you are looking for a fast paced game with a good combat system, this game is not for you. There is no combat. If you are easily offended this game is probably not for you either. It is a mature game, and characters in it reflect the wide variety of people you find in the real world. There are offensive characters. There is profanity. It is relatable. On the topic of characters, that's one area where this game truly shines! The characters you meet feel genuine, they feel complex. Real. This is a reflection of the overall fantastic writing which is revealing a thought provoking, deep and mature yet magical story. The dialogue alone had me laugh out loud on several occasions, while other moments pulled at my heartstrings. Of course this is only book one, but it is clear that great things are set in motion already.

About choices. Choices make up a key aspect of the actual game-play. They are difficult! Generally there are no obvious good vs. evil choices. Most are morally grey. But they do impact your story in important ways. To help you make the choice you will hear the PC's inner though process as you mouse over each choice. This very effectively serves the dual purpose of letting you get to know the characters better while helping you guess at what the PC will say.

This game is visually stunning. Sure, if you compare it to the flashiest of the AAA next-gen titles you might find the graphics a bit lacking. But the artstyle is fantastic and it is clear that the world has been crafted with a careful eye for detail. The two worlds of Stark and Arcadia feature very distinct styles, yet there is a cohesiveness that tie them together.

The Soundtrack is simply amazing amazing. There is one spot in Europolis where you will find a crowd of NPCs around a musician, and I found myself standing around for a few minutes just listening. But even the music coming out of radios, night clubs and the atmospheric" music is all highly effective and does a great job of underlining the impact of the story. The voice acting is also absolutely superb. Better even than most AAA titles I have played. I must admit it took some getting used to the new voice for Zoe
date: but she does such a good job I quickly got over it.\n\nTL:DR - If you love a good story and great characters
recommended: buy it. The interactions with Shitbot alone are worth it."
hoursPlayed: October 23, 2014

All in all I love the story and the landscape graphics are good the people could use alot more work. I think mouth movement could be stopped all together and it create a better feel. I am only glad that for the money your going to get all the chapters and not have to fork over more each time. That would end things right there for me.

reviewText:
~Book Four Review~
Well, I've already decided to update this review after the release of book 5 and re-write it as a one whole review. I'd still put some of my thoughts about Revelations;
Chapters 10, 11, and even the Interlude that follows, are probably the best sections of the game for me.
The plot really gets stronger here, at last. And while the 3 previous books (which are more than half of the game!) felt like they were just a warm-up for what's coming, here things finally start moving somewhere, and fast.

I did feel rather disappointed at some points, as Chapters became a little like a walking simulator, Zoe travelled through some pretty impressive locations but had very minimal interactions with her surroundings. And no, I haven't forgiven yet to the very straight-forwards puzzles.

But book 4's plot was so strong and moving for me, and that made me satisfied of Chapters at last.
Also, I believe that only in book 4 you actually get to feel the consequences of your choices (I did say earlier that it feels like your choices are simply thrown out of the window. Well, apparantly they're not).

Hoping for a nice finale! and hopefully a better review aboutthe entire game once book 5 is released.

~Book Three Review~
I'm going to exceed the maximum length possible so I'll go short on this one as well.
Techincally it's pretty much the same as book 1 and 2, although for some reason I experienced framerate drop but I can live with that.
Anyway, Book 3 was alright, but left me rather disappointed. The TLJ universe is famous for its slow starts but then it all supposed to get amazingly good. Well in book three I got a rather thin and disappointing plot, not too deep and engaging like the first game in the series or even like books 1&2.
I really hopes throughout the entire game that it's going to finish in an impressive way but.. not, it all felt very typical and shallow, unfortunately. I still had a good time playing the three books and so I leave this as a positive review, and expecting books 4&5 to start get things going and get back to the roots of the series' epicness.

~Book Two Review~
Basically, I don't have much to add to my thoughts about book one.
I'm a huge fan of the TLJ universe and games, and I enjoyed this episode a lot, but I still can't help but have mixed feeling about DF:Chapters.

First of all, by the time of the release of book two, most technical issues were solved (about time!) and I could finally play with high graphics settings, which was really fun and nice to watch.
Marcuria is designed wonderfully and beautifully and would  cause every TLJ fan a great joy.

The story, the writing, the characters are all as good as always and are the main attractions of the game.

The choices are getting more interesting and difficult each time.

It's all nice and well, but some wicked thoughts are lingering in my mind:
1)Where is it all going? Hard to believe but we're arriving soon to the middle of Dreamfall Chapters, and instead of answering some questiong aroused in Dreamfall, we're only getting more and more new questions unanswered.

2)Why not making the gameplay interesting as well?
And yes, there are good and interesting puzzles which I enjoyed, but many times I started feeling bored, just running around from place to place, doing some errands from the goals list, until some critical moment came where something dramatic happened and you had to make a choice.
Unfortunately this game is almost entirely all about the story, and not much about the actual 'game'

3)Music
Why, oh why.. The music in TLJ and DF was so good, so memorable, and here.. it seems like not much thought was put to the subject. And speaking of good stories and tales, music is a very important addition to the subject!
In book one I though the music was fine and expected it to get better fit next time..
But book two has barely any new addition to the soundtrack. The music is mostly reused from book one and is not much felt, which is disappointing.

Anyway, the game in whole still rocks because of the terrific story, of course. Hopefully it would stay that way.

~Book One Review~

In short:

Good stuff -
*Great complex story, the long awaited continuation for Dreamfall TLJ
*Cool soundtrack
*Choices and consequences concept introduced into the game
*Graphics are cool
*Good writing and characters

Bad stuff -
*Not yet fully optimized for PCs and specifically for 32bit version of Windows (even after patch 1.1.2)
*Performance and graphics don't justify system requirements
*Game relies solely on story, not gameplay. Again.
*Still too early to tell where the game is going and whether it's going to be good or disappointing

I have good things to say about this game, but!

Unfortunately, I'll have to start by saying that technically, this game is not too good. After waiting 7 years for a sequel, when you pre-order a product full price, then get release-delays, and then you have to struggle with the game and with your computer to run stuff properly.... Well, that's a bad start. Really bad start.
Anyway, I had to buy more RAM and install a 64-bit OS on my system to run this game properly, and if I wasn't an advacned user, I would have been left feeling that I've thrown 30$ to the garbage.

Though, considering the fact that RTG is a new and small company, that they have released pretty fast 3 patches for the game by now (which improved performance but didn't solve my problems anyway), and also considering that they're keeping in touch with the fans, supporting and trying to help as much as possible, keeping the fans updated through every advancement..

Well, Red Thread Games earned my respect, despite this highly unoptimized product.

Good. So, now, for the game itself.
It's good. Pretty damn good even, but possibly because I'm already in love with the TLJ universe.
The writing is good in my opinion, as expected, and it's the game's main strength.
I really enjoyed the story and characters, both old and new ones.
The soundtrack has taken a new and interesting direction, which fits the game's new style.
Seems like the devs took some inspiration from Telltale's choices&consequences concept, which I like.
And generally, I enjoyed playing book one and the very opening really got me into this 'new' story.

Gameplay-wise, this game plays much like its predecessor. I thought that they'd polish Dreamfall's action sequences (so-called sneaking and combat) but instead they were completely thrown away and we're left with adventure-elements only and the new choices&consequnce idea. The puzzles are also rather easy (although they are more innovative than those on Dreamfall in my opinion).
I really hoped the developers would listen to the fans about this one, and would make the gameplay more challanging, engaging and worthwhile. But it seems like they have stayed with their old paths and there again the game relies mostly on story.

The graphics look beautiful and alive but are not stunning, and not they nor the game's performance justify the system requirements.

Europolis is the largest area in book one, and looks interesting at first, but later it becomes an annoyance when you have to run long distances around without any reward or encouragement for exploring, as when you do that you'd mostly find people talking about politics and basically feel like a big part of the content is duplicated over Europolis.

Despite my complaints, I did get really excited about Chapters and Book One, enjoyed it and am looking forward for the continuation.
My only fear is that Chapters has 7 long years of waiting to fill, and doesn't go humble about its ambitions. If the developers won't polish the game some more, and won't improve it's weak points, they could easily turn it into a disappointment.
Now is simply too soon to predict whether Chapters is going to be a fulfilling title or just leave us feeling empty.

reviewText:
Beautiful, exquisite, engrossing. Dreamfall Chapters continues the story of Dreamfall and The Longest Journey in a beautifully rendered, exquisitely voice-acted, and engrossingly written episodic game where your choices affect the outcome and direction of the story.

As with most initial releases, there are a few hiccups with FPS in various areas regardless of the player's machine configuration. The developers have been responsive and acknowledged these complaints and working towards fixes. I commend them for being responsive as they are, I've seen MANY companies drop the ball. I've only run into a few FPS issues (namely the intro movie) but seem to be fine going through Europolis (where lots of people have been complaining).

I do not regret this purchase in the slightest and am eager for the upcoming chapter releases. I stand by my choice to pre-order the Special Edition (since I missed the Kickstarter campaign).

reviewText:
Iv'e been waiting for Dreamfall Chapters to come out since the last game ended on a cliff hanger. and so far it does not dissapoint!. (there thats for fans of the series)

For newcommers, Dreamfall Chapters is a 3D adventure game in the manner of Walking Dead and many of the old point and click games from the early years of video games on PC.

Now Ill say this now. you should play The Longest Journey: Dreamfall before you play this game (you do not have to play The Longest Journey but its got some usefull backstory and can help expand your appreciation of the world) now you do not have to in order to enjoy the game but it will have that much more meaning and you will really understand the characters and events at the start of the game if you have finished the earlier game.

on with the rest of the review:

What sets this game apart from its forebears is that it has a tree based structure to its storyline. so for each choice you make there is a real consequence. Now thats the claim from Red Thread the studio responsible for the game.
As there is only the first part of the game available, it remains to be seen how extensive this system of choices is, but after some time playing the first book and trying every choice I could make. I am fairly confident that the game will deliver in its promises with upcomming episodes.

The game uses two choice systems, one is the Balance system a set of events that have a coinflip answer, where the resulting choice greatly effects future outcomes for the character. the other is a walking dead esque system where characters remember your reactions to various events and these are taken into account with future conversations and events.
while many of the choices and events presented provided numerous choices and possibilities, there were very few choices available that had immediate results. I am greatly looking forward to the second book to see how these choices pan out.

Now, it would be remiss of me to not mention some current issues with the game:
It has some known graphical bugs and issues with resource usage they are working on fixes for.( they fixed the large framerate drop happening in Europolis and other areas)
Some people are having crashes and freezes (not me but some people are)
The save game system needs work because it just makes a ton of autosave files without any sensible naming system or organisation.(only an issue if you want to try a different response or load a non current game)


The game is mainly about making choices and solving puzzles, this in future will include things like stealth and probably some light combat. but it will be unlikely that combat will be particularly reflex intensive or action oriented.
Characters in the dream world seem to have various powers so a kind of magic is also featured in the game in certain areas.

Will you enjoy this game?
If you liked games like myst, the stanley parable, any older point and click adventure  you will love this game.

if your into combat and violence, you may still enjoy it but it will feel slow and boring due to long heavy dialogue sequences and alot of travelling.

I love what they have done with dreamfall chapters and am looking forward to the next chapter to see how far they will go.

reviewText:
I bought this when it had a lot of negative reviews, and boy am i glad i did !
This turned out to be one of the most awesome games i have ever played and truely in the spirit of the TLJ and DF:TLJ.

The game is very beautiful visually and is very story rich. Music is really awesome but i have mixed feelings about the voice acting since in some cases like zoe its really good and in some others... well it isnt.

The change of scenery in the game is really great and very much like the original games. You will experience all sorts of environment from the typical dystopian steam punk to a narnia like land of magic and more (i dont wanna spoil anything).

My only suggestion to you is that if you like adventure, or if you liked the original series go and get this game. Dont pay attention to the negative reviews. This game is an EXTREMELY satisfactory answer regarding the many many unanswered questions that you might have had in the previous games and the answers are not half baked or shallow.

Thank you red thread. but be aware that one" book is not going to cut it. we want more !"

reviewText:
Quick summary:  save your money.

I'm highly polarized on this game so far (through book 3).  I really appreciate the episodic installments as an idea but don't believe the creators have hit their stride just yet (the pacing is slow and at times the material is trivial).  In general, I'm not a point-n-click fan but this story is rather epic and I love that.  Is the story enough tho?  The answer is no.  The game-play is laborious.  I almost feel as if it would be better without the puzzles as the pacing is rather slow and with the puzzles added in I feel like I'm lagging behind.  This is a negative impact on enjoyment obviously.  Perhaps it has more to do with the fact that I prefer RPG's but this game is not satisfying for me.  And this is where I'm polarized; I love the ever-evolving story but hate playing through it.  Cycling through the past two games (via walkthroughs) did add an appreciation for the entire story arc and helped to draw me in.  But this is a case where the amazing writing is overshadowed by the Gumby game mechanics.  I feel that perhaps just leaving this one as a QTE game would benefit it as less time would be spent on slow environmental interactions and more time on the part I love.  In fact I'm wondering if they should even bother with the pretense of a game on this one and instead simply allow the audience to click through the chapters like a DVD book.

I hate to say it, as I really want to support this team, but this one is probably best experienced through walkthroughs with the current going rate of $30 USD.  Knock that price down to half and it's still better through walkthroughs.  Yeah, the gameplay is really not enjoyable for me.  :/  As refreshing as the Books" idea is
date: I just can't ignore the gameplay.  It really makes this experience not fun.  Who want's to run back and forth or around in circles multiple times for a triviality?  Nobody a**holes.  Nobody.\n\n"

reviewText:
Dreamfall Chapters is a game that can be apreciated for what it sets out to do. It was successfully funded on Kickstarter, and it is clear that the team at Red Thread Games is passionate about the Dreamfall franchise. This however, does not change the fact that Chapters (atleast in it's current state) is a bad game.

So what exactly do i mean by this? Well to start off with, the game runs like crap, and without the graphics to back its poor performance. Despite the game having recently been upgraded from Unity version 4.x to 5.2.3, I still struggle to maintain 60 FPS on my current rig(i7 2600K/GTX 780sc).
But what about the game itself? Well. To be fair. It's also very weak. Chapters LOVES to waste your time. It contains tons of illogical puzzles, and pixel hunt-like item scavenging. And when you aren't walking around a large level looking for pointless items, you're likely walking from point A to point B, just to be sent back to A again. Overall the game manages to drag out what could've been a nicely paced 2 hour per episode experince, into a tedious 5 hour walkathon, with very little exposition.

As such, I really cannot recommend Dreamfall Chapters, as it is simply a bad game. I will however recommend the previous title in the series, known simply as Dreamfall, as it is arguably a much better game.

reviewText:
I realize the creators of this game don't care what their fans think. I guess when there are always more positive reviews than negative, it's easy to think you have succeeded. That is unfortunate. In light of Star Wars hype, they pretty much pulled a George Lucas(while I respect what Lucas did with the prequels, they do suck). If this is all they can offer us, then I have lost faith in their future games as well. Sure, the budget was much lower than previous games, but given that fact, they must have been in over their heads. The mechanics of this game is ridiculous and insulting to play. They design the game as if to give life to each plot, but the punches, the jumps, the climbing look so lifeless and lazy, I'm just shaking my head while forcing myself to play. They tried to do too much with so little and it feels like wasted potential.

I'll give Book 4 a bit more credit than the previous 3. It had its moments and some of it was rather entertaining. But that was a brief window out of the entire game that feels like pulling teeth to get through. As a whole, there is nothing in this game that makes me want to hold onto it. That's sad because the previous games had a certain tone, mood and music that affected you as a person. This game is like a passive puzzle, a phone app more like. After I'm done playing, I don't give a rat's droppings about it. I really hope the creator's don't think this is their best game yet. No offense.

Having said that, I'm not even going to bother waiting for book 5. With the way it's been going, they can't possibly do anything else to change my mind about the game. Things are already tainted and even if the story becomes more interesting later on, it still does not make this a good game. I would compare the experience of playing this game to that of some mindless flash game that has no value or depth.

reviewText:
Dreamfall. I've waited a long time for this game. Sadly that it is an episodic (books) release like TellTale games, but still - the first book didn't disappointed me.

Pros:
The story so far is interesting, a little bit on a dark note, comparing to the other games.
Voice acting is superb and graphics are pretty good (I didn't expected much, because it is Unity, but they actually managed to amaze me and make me press F12 many times).
Characters are interesting and catchy. They all have their personalities and even from a little time with them - you start to feel and emphasise (at least I did).
Decisions are hard. Like really. Even in TWD or TWAU it was easier to pick what you like. Here, before making any decision you can listen to an inner insight on what it actually means to character. How she or he interpreters the meaning of this choice or another. And they do matter. I've completed the first book only once, yet I've already heard that depending on some decisions you can get a different job, which means different characters. You can be confident or unsure. You can cling to your past or throw it away and live a new life. I like it.
And soundtrack. Soundtrack is awesome.

Cons:
The first book is short. It took me about six hours to complete and I tried to explore and got lost in the city more than once. (although, this is relevant. Modern games (full games, AAA titles) tend to have no more than a ten hours of content. And this is just a first book. I suppose for non explorer it would take about three hours to complete the first book. They said it is the shortest one and there's four more to come. So in all - that's above average playtime. Still sad though, comparing to dozens of hours it goes into completion of the original TLJ).
The game engine is... well. Unity. There's one particular area (a city) where almost everyone has a serious framerate problems or even crashes. In any other area performance is great, the frame rate goes to infinity and beyond, but in the city? 20 fps or less for me. 5 for some players, judging by forum. It was playable and still enjoyable, but yeah. It is a problem. I'm sure they will fix that in upcoming patch.

I do recommend this game. As well as to play two other ones. Because they do matter and in the first book there's NO exposition of previous events. You do need to know at least plot of Dreamfall.

reviewText: I don´t know how to put my first impressions except: I want Book Two released right now!\nI still remember coming across the Longest Journey as a demo version on a CD of a gaming magazine. It took my heart right away and so I of course had to get the game. The characters, the idea of two parallel worlds being connected by dreams and the whole story swallowed me completely. And, of course, when Dreamfall - The Longest Journey was released, I needed to know, how the story went on and was hoping all my questions would be answerde. Well, a lot were but the most important ones, that keep the whole world together, were still left open, though loads of hints were given. Well and now, there is the third part Dreamfall Chapters. I just played through Book One and am flashed. It starts of as intriguing as Dreamfall - The Longest Journey ended. The gameplay is pretty intuitive, not much of a tutorial needed, everything just flows. Yes, there are still some graphic bugs but honestly, I so don´t care. I got so wrapped up into the story, that I mainly just got glimpses of the bugs I read later about. They don´t have any effect on the story itself. So, well, here I am, left with a lot of ideas and hints (and still missing Crow, though I am kind of wondering why the maps are all shown by Crowboy" - reminds me of The Longest Journey and April meeting Crow the first time) and just can´t wait for the rest of the episodes to be released. Though I fear a bit
date: that a great and awesome story will come to an end at the end of this journey I am still looking forward to it.\nWhat I also love very much is making choices having an effect on the story

reviewText:
Dreamfall Chapters is a great dystopian story-based game where choices really matter.  This game is similar to games like Life is Strange.  The choices you make will determine the outcomes of events or relationships with other characters.  Sometimes a walkthough is helpful.  In one part of the story you're in a futuristic city.  In the other part of the story you're in a medieval town.  If you've played Dreamfall: The Longest Journey (which I advise you play first) you'll know what I'm talking about.  If you're into adventure and trying to figure out what a shadow corrupt government is up to you will love this game.

Pros
- Very story rich.
- Choices determine game events.
- Gives you a choice to see what other gamers chose on important choices.
- There are several books" to this game
date:
hence the name.
- Futuristic and medieval environments.
- Go against a shadow government.

Cons

- Lense flares.  You can turn it on/off but I had to turn it off.  The lense flare visuals are very annoying."

reviewText: Having played and very much enjoyed the two prequels, I knew what I was hoping for but wasn't sure what to expect with this one, however I'm happy to say that I was not disappointed, in fact I was pleasantly surprised by how true it stayed to the others. Much like its predecessors, Chapters is dialogue and plot heavy, focusing on building a unique, believable fantasy atmosphere that really immerses you in its universe and characters. In addition, certain parts of the game were surprisingly open, allowing you to explore at your leisure should you so choose. It also appears to implement something new, different choices that the player can make when prompted which will have consequences later on as the game progresses, which remains to be seen. I only discovered one glitch, a couple of small, hard to find spots in a level that I clipped through completely by accident, and was afterwards able to run around in regions of the level where you're definitely not meant to be. The graphics are nothing short of amazing and subsequently might require a bit of a beefy computer to handle, and luckily I was able to get the full benefit of them with smooth performance. While the previous games will definitely help explain a lot of the events in this one, much of it is explained in this game alone, but I definitely recommend the trilogy as a whole.

reviewText:
This game borders boring.

I really like the original Dreamfall and before that The Longest Journey, but this game fails short in quite a few ways. For one, it has no clear ending, these chapters just roll on and they are vague and not really interesting. Dreamfall had a clear start, middle and end, it was a great visual and entertaining adventure from the go, however this is quite plain and leaves allot of choices to the player, which can be a bad thing. I never really found any resolution to any of my actions, nothing that really made any real difference, it all felt under the rug and just... uninteresting? The tasks throughout the game aren't really overly fun, and it just doesn’t have that I actually care" factor about allot of the missions.

Visually it's pretty

reviewText:
Cool adventure game with a very well-realised world.
Book 2 is unfeasably long for an episodic game -something like 6 hours long on its own.
Wouldn't be surprised if the complete game comes in around 25 hours.
Quality voice acting and interesting dialogue.
Pretty flexible in terms of Witcher 2 style branching choice within a broadly linear narrative.
The environments have real personality.
Refreshing willingess to engage with real-world politics albiet in a slightly simplistic way.
I've waited 7 years for this game (not really, I mostly didn't think about it but I always hoped it would come out) and so far it doesn't disappoint.
Won't be everyone's cup of tea but for those who like this kind of thing, its great.

reviewText:
Boy, oh boy, do I LOVE this game!

If you loved the Choose Your Own Adventure books as a kid, this game is for you! Dreamfall Chapters is the third in a series of games (including The Longest Journey and Dreamfall The Longest Journey). After playing and really liking the first two games, I was excited to try this latest addition to the trilogy.

The graphics of this game are so beautiful, and the story is so compelling, playing truly takes you into another world. You really end up caring about the characters in the game (you play as two different people, switching as the game goes on). But my favorite part is that throughout the game, you're faced with a decision that will change your character's circumstances, as well as the hearts and opinions of the others you encounter.

Buy it, play it, love it!

P.S.--In case you haven't played either of the two previous games, there's a quick video in the game which can get you up to speed with the story :)

reviewText: I held off for a long time on buying this game because I just didn't know if it was for me.  Then I saw that The Longest Journey, and Dreamfall: The Longest Journey were on sale and just decided to hell with it.  I have to mention that I'm a stickler for details, so the first game kind of annoyed me, but the story was great which in turn made me want to find out what happens to April and the rest. Second game introduced me to Zoe (took me a while to warm up to her) but then within minutes I was once again captured and played the game all the way through. Now, Dreamfall Chapters comes along and just rocks my world, I love the choices and concequences you have to live with and the story once again is riveting, I can only recommend this game and the first two, especially if you love a good story.  I know this turned into a rant, but hell, it's worth it, trust me.  AMAZING GAME, graphically as well as Gameplay :)

reviewText: Dreamfall Chapters, simply put, is the BEST episodic game I've played. Lush, wonderful story and characters, lengthy and meaty episodes, and rewarding and fullfilling. reviewText:
I can't recommend this game highly enough.  I'm an avid gamer and trend toward games with a rich storyline.  This is the most awe-inspiring, emotional, story-driven game I've played in a long time.  It's likely that people returning to the series will get the most out of it since it picks up where the others left off.  HOWEVER, I think that the game world is good about filling in the most relevant gaps (thanks to an optional recap at the beginning).  The game world is magical, and the characters are so three-dimensional that it inspires you to laugh and cry right along with them.

I cannot WAIT for the next chapter.  10/10

**MINOR SPOILER with no specifics**:


Just as a heads-up, it ended on a bit of a cliffhanger.

reviewText:
Thus far Dreamfall Chapters is a thoroughly enjoyable adventure title with a choice and consequence style gameplay and stunning visuals. It stands as the third in a series of story rich games and benefits from the player having experienced those adventures. (The Longest Journey & Dreamfall: The Longest Journey)

The story telling in this and the previous games are second to none, with the developers going to great lengths to provide a strong history and back story to the characters and worlds they have created. This series really draws you in, and the choice and consequence element to this game ensures that the player truly feels involved with the actions of the protagonists.

The Story telling in Dreamfall Chapters is wonderfully enhanced by the quality of the visual representation of two unique worlds, and a solid soundtrack.

I highly recommend this game to everyone, but the players who will get the most out of this title are Adventurers who enjoy playing games driven by an original and compelling plot, involving genuinely likeable and relatable characters!

Although the series is not complete, this game sets the stage for an intense crescendo of an incredible journey.

I can only hope people enjoy playing this as much as I am.

reviewText:
I have waited years and years for this game. I am a huge fan of the Longest Journey and Dreamfall. They both hold special places in my heart, and I fell in love with April Ryan, Crow, Zoe, and even Kian. The story that is told between both games, even though Dreamfall is not exactly a sequel, is my favorite story I've ever played through in any game. And I've played a lot of games. Yes, I was highly anticipating Dreamfall Chapters.

So far only two books have been released, but I'm totally enchanted. The problem is, my enchantment gets suspended for a little too long between books. If you're an impatient fan like me, you should buy the season pass and play as each book gets released. If you're patient, I highly recommend waiting to play the game until it's complete. The time between books really ruins the flow, as both books have ended on cliff hangers that leave you craving more... and then so much time passes that you start to forget about the sense of urgency that you were left with.

The story:
10/10! It starts out very slow. If you played Dreamfall, this won't be a problem because you'll understand the bigger picture and know why the slow parts of the story are important. If you haven't played Dreamfall, you might think the story is too thin and confusing for a while. So go play Dreamfall first. Dreamfall Chapters is wonderful, because it picks up right where Dreamfall left of: with Zoe's coma. We get to know a lot more about Zoe in the first book. In the second book, we get to know a lot more about the world she's living in in Stark - it's complicated, detailed, and intriguing. We also spend a lot of time with Kian in Arcadia, which is turning into less of a fairy tale place as the story progresses. The story with Arcadia is big, haunting, rich, and still building. I really want to know more!

The gameplay:
WAY better than in Dreamfall. So far there's no combat, just puzzles and progressing the rich story. It's smooth.

The graphics:
The game looks great. It may not blow you away with incredible detail that requires two video cards and an overclocked i7 CPU, but it looks very good on any decent middle power computerr. It's clean, has a beautiful artistic style, and you will get sucked into the story because of both the graphics and the great story telling.

The puzzles:
Overall they're good. There's a couple that felt weak, tedious, or just too long. I've not disliked any of them yet. The game is mostly story so far, but the puzzles blend right into the story and progress it well.

The Choice and Consequence system:
It's haunting. Did I choose the right choices!? When you get hit with needing to make a choice, you'll find that it's actually really hard. You really have to think through what kind of story experience you want. Should you let that character die for the sins he or she did, or do you think it's worth saving the character because that character might be useful? Should you disobey orders to do something better, or is disobeying too risky? You just have to chose an option and hope for the best. Yes, I will be replaying the game in order to choose the others choices, because I want to see how the story is affected!

Conclusion:
Go play The Longest Journey and Dreamfall. Your life will be better for it. Then buy this game and play it! Even if you're not an adventure game fan, you can't deny that this series has an amazing story and characters. You're missing out by not getting to know these characters.

But honestly, I feel like everything else just trumps that aspect. This is a classic adventure game - revamped - and well worth the experience.

reviewText: If you have any fondness at all for the TLJ franchise, tis is a must-buy.\n\nIf not, please know that this game and its franchise is the home of some of the best writing in video games. The story is epic, and the character writing is on par with the best of Bioware. Dreamfall Chapters is a gorgeous game that goes to unexpected places and spins a captivating yarn there. I would suggest playing Dreamfall first, which is another game well worth your time, because a prior investment into the story elevates Dreamfall Chapters from a good time at the games to a great time at the games, but if you enjoy getting to know deeply sympathetic characters in a vibrant world (two vibrant worlds, actually), this is a game for you.

reviewText:
Here we have the character from the second game with the vibe of the first game, which had a lot more cyber punk theme going on.

Might be the best game as far as decision making goes. Reminds me of The Witcher, in a sense that you do feel like every decision is very important and does really make a difference, unlike mass effect, for instance. Of course, we will have to wait and see how the other parts of the game ends, but so far, the game does it even better with the dialog and the way it presents the choices and making you feel the responsible for them.
Reload? Funny.. there's no saving around, you do stuff and live with it.

Feels kinda buggy sometimes. If you click around too much it'll play many recordings at the same time making it impossible to understand and thus annoying once in a while. It's minor though.

All in all, maybe it needs a little polishing, but so far it exceeds expectation for someone who has been waiting for a sequel for years.

reviewText:
At long last, the continuation of the Dreamfall story which left us all hanging for nearly a decade.
I am truly enjoying the exceptional storytelling offered by this Adventure game and it's gameplay mechanics.
I'm quite glad that the frivolous and immersion-breaking combat of the original Dreamfall is not making a return from Dreamfall Chapters.

Was able to play through Book 1 with a mid-range 4-year old GPU and a first-gen Intel i5 CPU. With the latest patches that give us better graphical quality control, you can disable shadows and a few other settings to make it playable on even less powerful platforms. I was able to run the game on a Surface Pro 1st-gen (Intel Integrated GPU); albeit there were some problems with the lens-flare effect blocking out the screen (I think the latest patch allows you to disable lens-flares though).

Anxiously awaiting Book 2 and beyond~

reviewText:
I am a big fan of the series, however after the 1st chapter I am not impressed. I only recommend this game because it is promising so much, but the first chapter is quite short (4 hours) and unconvincing.

I remember how after minutes of the Longest Journey demo (back in 2000) I was totally absorbed by the game, it grabbed me from the beginning - the talking tree, April, everything made you care or curious right from the start.

In Chapter 1 we start where Dreamfall ended, which is good, because I always felt that Dreamfall ended abruptly. However, I found the politics plot of this Chapter quite boring. In April's times, Stark had also funny parts (remember the detective or the rubber ducky), but this time it is just dark, dystopian and dull, it doesn't surprise with anything.

I am sorry to say but after the 1st chapter I don't feel anything for the characters, which is a big letdown, TLJ series made you feel involved. Even the choice/consequence system, which is a great feature, doesn't make me feel more involved. The story so far is thin and the characters sketchy. The only character I liked on Stark in this chapter, worthy of the series, was the lady on the boat.

I also don't like the fact that most characters swear a lot, unnecessary a lot.
The part that I liked was the Arcadia bit. That's the world I want to see more, that's the place that made me love the series, not the dull slums of Stark. So I am hoping to see more of it.

The graphics are quite good, but the drawback is that you need good hardware to play this game which started as a point and click adventure. Also, I don't like the interaction system, it reminds me of action games and it just gets in the way of exploring the details in an area. Which brings me to the quest/goals system.

The action is linear, you get a quest (goal) like in an role playing game and you go from here to there like an errand boy (girl). So much for exploring. You don't need to explore and interact when everything points you towards your goal. The 1st chapter ended much to quickly. I finished the game after four hours, and my reaction was like come on
date: that was all"?\n\nI know that more and more games are using episodes to deliver the game
recommended: but in Dreamfall's case it is a bad idea. The time between episodes will just disconnect me from the story
hoursPlayed: it feels like spliting a movie in 5 and watching a bit every month."

any who, i love this series and if you are open minded and want to have a good experience while getting a great story told to you, while you puzzle around fixing problems, this this is most likely for you.

reviewText:
This is unlike most point and click adventure games where your inventory is full of items and you have to try every combination to make the story progress.

This is what you should expect:  50% movie with an interesting story, 25% choose your own adventure (without the quick death), 25% exploring.  Every 'puzzle' made sense.   Most actions have consequences that will eventually catch up with you.

I for one, enjoy a good, well written story.  I've played The Longest Journey and Dreamfall:  The Longest Journey.  When I was done with both, I wanted more.   As I finished Book One, I was more than happy I contributed to the Kickstarter.

I hope to see the ****bot again

reviewText: Book One of the dreamfall chapters is wonderful reintroduction to the worlds of Stark and Arcadia. Although you might think there is not much to be done and the chapter is quite short it prepares ground for the future events really well. I became soon again interested in game characters and I´m looking forward to the next chapters. The visuals are nice and although not necessarily next-gen the presentation is rich with an attention to detail. I really think the Unity gave developers a lot of hard times and the performance varies from machine to machine. RTG is trying really hard to squash the bugs and my gameplay was pretty much bug free.\nAlso I must compliment the voice actors. I played Dreamfall right before chapters to recap the events and I must say that I missed the original cast a lot. It took some time to get used to the new voices, but I must admit they did terrific job. As a long fan of The Longest Journey and Dreamfall I´m very happy.

reviewText:
Games like this are a rare gem.

The story will pull you along, rarely frustrating you with overly-difficult puzzles and charming you with beautiful and soothing graphics.

I spent an hour or two just wandering the streets of Europolis, occasionally marvelling at the sights of the city. Rarely does a game leave me distracted and oblivious to the main story. It was a like a dream-vacation.

When I finished Chapter 1, I felt as if I had just returned from somewhere marvellous. I can't wait to go back.

reviewText:
My rating for Dreamfall Chapters, Book One - Reborn: 85/100

This title promised us amazing mixture of medieval fantasy world and dark cyberpunk sci-fi reality set in year 2220. Also it was about to show various choices and everywhere-present consequences. Three worlds, two stories, one destiny. Lets see the realisation in detail.

Story is pretty rich, even more due to two main characters - Zoë Maya Castillo and Kian Alvane. Their choices and decisions are shapng the world around them and even himself/herself and also other main character. There is also a possibility to remind you what happened in previous games, so you can be well informed. There are a lot of aspects to solve, with the dark feeling, that something is coming. Joy and happines is well balanced with sadness and despair, even anger and revenge. For every choice, there is a consqeuence, you just have to find out.

Characters are strong and abundant in their personalities. Zoë is changing from scared and happy-go-lucky teenager to a responsible and courageous woman, what brings here one of most positive elements. Strong female protagonist. Also Kian is transformed from zealous religious fighter to the defender of weak and opressed. Episodic chracters are helpful and specific. For me, the strongest one was Teta Queenie (czech word for aunt), who forced us to make very serious statement.

Visuals are nice and realistic, art is catching and graphic is set to support the story and background in the game. Moods  and acts are reflected very accurately. However, there were some funny glitches, but it nothing disrupting the gameplay.

Soundtrack is composed by Simon Poole and truly said, it is a masterpiece. Piano, reasonable amount of remix and other instruments with dramatical choirs are goind right under the skin and makes you feel like you were in another world. Exactly there this game takes you.

Gameplay was heartwarming, it is mostly adventure with puzzles to solve. Quests are not easy, but solvable, you have to earn your success and sometimes try a bit harder. Game provides you a huge number of various interactions, commented with thougts of main characters. By the way, you can even control a baby here! Choices are differed to lesser and main, second one have balance" symbol next to them
recommended: how your friends and rest of the world decided. In the end
hoursPlayed: all your decisions will be sum up with commentary what you can expect in the following episode.\n\nTo sum it up
