reviewText: Although I can't see this game getting mass market appeal It was my best game of 2014 and I would recommend it to anyone. Also just the first chapter provides a ton of gameplay and is longer than the first chapters of many other episodic games, a.k.a. the walking dead games and so on. The game is packed with unique features and has AAA voice acting that is crazy good. The writing is quite possibly some of the best in any game ever. It is very much a story driven game however; the game is in your choices, although it does have some little puzzles that were fun. I've heard people complain about the lack of challenge to I’d say: you're missing the point entirely. Just think of it as a really detailed interactive film and you're closer to understanding what the game is about. I can't wait to play the next episodes; I've played through book 1 twice. It has some replayability but like I said before that's not really what this type of game is about. Fantastic game, I'm predicting that it will be one of my top 10 games of all time upon the release of all the episodes. 10/10 would buy.

reviewText:
This game is fantastic, a great game to play with your girlfriend or wife.

The developers were able to take all the loose ends (and there were many) from the previous game and somehow tie them all up into a coherent storyline.  If you've played the previous games, don't hesitate to purchase this one.

Pros:  Girl/Guy friendly.  Two stories entertwined, one with a girl protagonist and one with a guy protagonist, one in the past, one in the future.  There's a little bit of everything here for most individuals.  Book 1 was slow getting started, but Book 2 is much better.  Highly recommend you play this with somebody!

Note:  The game is somewhat demanding of system resources and if you are not over the minimum system specs you might not be able to play.  If that's the case, feel free to watch our let's play

reviewText: As a fan of the series, I am disappointed to write that I have been less than thrilled by Dreamfall Chapters. Apart from the obvious bugs and other problems following the first chapter's launch, the overall feeling of the game remains unpolished and, in some areas, downright sloppy. While the environments, character models, and animations are visually stunning, there are several moments throughout the first two chapters that weren't given the attention they deserved. For instance, there are many dialogue sequences throughout the game that feel unnatural or devote camera focus solely to a single character. It's possible that this is because the developers did not have enough time to fully animate the other characters in the conversation. This sort of oversight removes the player from the immersion they would otherwise feel while living through each character. In summary, the game looks great but feels tragically rushed. The complete lack of challenging puzzles makes the game feel more like a piece of interactive fiction than it's adventure-oriented predecessors. I would still (cautiously) recommend this title to any fan of the previous games.

reviewText: Dreamfall Chapters is quite the return to the series and being I'm no constructive judge on this game I'll just say if it connects to you then it is definitely worth it, if it speaks to you then it is well done. Ragnar Tornquist never once has failed to tell a good story granted Zoe isn't as excitable, witty and animated (girl next door) as April Ryan was but they she's got character of her own that shines in a way that leaves you crossing your fingers for her, you don't want her light to go out, she is a character worth caring about even as the festering world (the villains) looks for a variety of ways to kill her or at least finish her story for her. Finding her memories is the most important thing for her because otherwise she will lose what she has gained including everything she is and become a hopeless vegetable like the dream machine addicts which is the name of the story, the story keeps you gripping for every moment wondering what waits around the corner of mystery. She intended to live a pointless and mundane life instead of a boring and empty existence as in Casablanca yet her story will guide her to an eventful and colorful life so that she is at least worth mentioning by Lady Alvane as she tells this tale to the kids from the first longest journey of a time when Stark and Arcadia were divided instead of one whole world called Earth where Lady Alvane and the kids are living. However Zoe's life isn't the last tale of the twin worlds for her life likely merely set into motion events that would propel towards the 'War of the Balance' as Crow chimed in at the closing of the original longest journey yet someone eventually educated the Starkers in the tale of the two worlds and the underground living Sentinel (which I suspect the madame by the river market is secretly one of the Sentinel who knows of the twin worlds as well) this of course is a tale that may come later and at the same time it may not, this is after all Rangar's story and we can only speculate.\n\nThe busy ♥♥♥ city is a bit irritating graphically just to move around and it doesn't help that red thread themselves resorted to next-gen graphics standard settings even as they haven't used next-gen graphics literally. I got into Zoe's apartment and that's when things hit an all-time high in lag, the mechanics are still a wee bit wonky but what can you do, except wait on a patch to get that puzzle back into the picture frame? It is true what Cortez said about true art, it speaks to the deepest part of you and leaves a mark on your subconscious that you won't forget in time for that is what Dreamfall Chapters is to me as is the entire longest journey saga. The controls are secondary compared to the graphics, characters and storytelling, good thing there is only a few for the basic interaction instead of like 30-40 of them for various different purposeful or simply meaningless functions. Also this game makes the achievements not mandatory and there is no next-to-impossible task that gives you one either since this game isn't designed on challenge but more on your thinking abilities to solve puzzles and overcome obstacles or hurdles in the story in order to progress. Also according Mr. Tornquist he will make The Longest Journey Home continuing April Ryan's tale and bringing it full circle to a close and doing the fans a favor in keeping it passionately in the theme it was introduced in but evolving it to not feel alienated from Dreamfall. I suspect that in time Dreamfall Chapters will evolve in story to set the stage for the finalizing installments or installment of The Longest Journey, no Ragnar will not wait 8 or more years before the next one for that was Funcom's ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t prioritization that created that pattern. In any case The Longest Journey gives video games the great soul and universal power that all entertainment deserves called art!

reviewText:
I got into this game because I was looking for titles with strong female lead characters. So, being someone who has not played the previous titles of the series I quickly found myself surrounded by references and lore I would have to look up. I was afraid it could scare me off. The fact that it didn't shows the true splendor of this game. It got me invested in its story lines, invited me to immerse more and more and make decisions without knowing what the possible consequences would be.

The First Book was a bit of a let-down considering the mechanics and especially the adventure parts where you'd have to combine x and y in the only way possible to solve a puzzle. But so far Book Two made up for it.

Can't wait to see more of this, so far I'm really loving it. Check out my Let's Play of it here to clear up remaining doubts:

reviewText: As a fan of the series, I am disappointed to write that I have been less than thrilled by Dreamfall Chapters. Apart from the obvious bugs and other problems following the first chapter's launch, the overall feeling of the game remains unpolished and, in some areas, downright sloppy. While the environments, character models, and animations are visually stunning, there are several moments throughout the first two chapters that weren't given the attention they deserved. For instance, there are many dialogue sequences throughout the game that feel unnatural or devote camera focus solely to a single character. It's possible that this is because the developers did not have enough time to fully animate the other characters in the conversation. This sort of oversight removes the player from the immersion they would otherwise feel while living through each character. In summary, the game looks great but feels tragically rushed. The complete lack of challenging puzzles makes the game feel more like a piece of interactive fiction than it's adventure-oriented predecessors. I would still (cautiously) recommend this title to any fan of the previous games.

reviewText:
So far, I'm struggling. Even with the video turned down to low specs, it's very slow and there are a lot of scenes to sit through. The saved points are too far apart, and I'm going to have to redo the first puzzle yet again when and if I decide the second puzzle is worth trying again.

I'm not keen on the interface. You don't have any use of a cursor to move around - you can only use the mouse/trackpad for viewing. If you're lucky, you'll find something to click on. Movement using the WASD keys will take you in the direction you're looking at.

The music, sound effects and voices are good but I haven't reached any pretty parts yet, still being stuck at the beginning.

I enjoyed The Longest Journey and I was hoping for something on those lines. I guess I'm just stuck in the past, wanting more games like The Dig, The Longest Journey, Loom, and Broken Sword. I'm disappointed.

I'm hoping that some walkthroughs will come out that use words, not video, so I can flick through quickly and find what I need. Until then, this much awaited game is on hold.

reviewText:
EDIT: Before you even read this, note the kneejerk and attempted bullying in some of the 'developer responses.' That should tell you all you need to know. Ragnar has fallen so far, I don't even understand how it could've happened.

This is going to be long, as I want you to understand, to see if you'll agree with me about this game.

I'm not regularly critical about games, I like games, and I wanted to like this game. It began with The Longest Journey, which to me was a legendary affair, it still is. I remember so much about it, how it touched my imagination and inspired wanderlust. I recall much -- from the flying creatures that passed down stories in their own tongue, to the awakening of Venice. I approached it with wide-eyed wonder, it spoke to both the child and the adult in me.

So it was with that wonder I looked onward. I recall, again, at the time when friends and I chittered excitedly about Dreamfall. What would it hold? We wanted to think that our Ragnar would be brave enough, bold enough, to let the barrier between worlds fall. And that the dragons themselves may realise their error, and allow this to pass. And what would follow? An amazing epic about the trials and tribulations of two worlds colliding, perhaps with chaos taken to the brink and then to become better than either had ever been.

Dreamfall wasn't that. That was fine. It was okay. It was a little overwrought with awkward drama and unnecessary bouts of ennui to be edgy, but it was... all right. Of all the things it might have been, it wasn't memorable. It didn't leave a mark on me the way The Longest Journey did. It felt like Ragnar had left the child by the wayside, picking up an angsty teenager instead. One with dyed hair and a gruff attitude, a shallow, one-dimensional creature that was so desperate to be edgy, to be cool. The wonder had died. It was an intrigue, but it wasn't amazing.

I'd hoped that Ragnar would turn to the child's wonder again. No such luck. The teenager was running rampant now, lots of new hormones as puberty set in. Rage against the machine, man! Stick it to the man, man! And it's a little embarrassing. The teenager holds the reigns, believing that ham-fisted writing, that beating you over the head with cheesy, kludged attempts at emotional manipulation, and overdone twists in an effort to be clever, and unnecessary amounts of Dark & Edgy...

Now, you may play Dreamfall Chapters and disagree with me. Keep playing.

The first episode is okay. It is merely okay, much like Dreamfall which preceded it. It's okay. It's not going to stir your spirit, it's not going to ease your soulsickness, awaken your wonder, or give you that pleasant sensation that runs down your spine as your jaw falls agape in appreciation for just how much raw creativity a person can have. The Longest Journey could do that. This won't. But that's not a crime, Something can be just okay. And being just okay may not be quite worth the lack of a recommendation. Okay is fine, right?

Well, then the second episode hits. Ragnar gets bored and leaves the teenager at the typewriter. Suffice it to say? This goes about as well as you'd expect it to, and it ends about as well as you'd expect it to. It's trashy, embarrassing, silly, and edgy. It's the sort of thing you see when a teenager writes a fan-fiction about their favourite TV show, except they try to make it dark by having people die and/or suffer. You have to feel my pain, man! Do you feel my pain? DO YOU???? Do. You. Feel. My. Pain?!?

Embarrassing.

I felt genuinely awkward. I was worried someone would see me playing it. And this isn't a good thing. After the first episode, I was expecting better. I wanted better. I thought... okay, Ragnar is hitting his stride. The Longest Journey took a little bit to get off the ground, it had a slow start. Perhaps this does too? And that's about as far as my faith went. For all intents and purposes, I think it's fair to call Ragnar a one-trick pony. He had one trick -- The Longest Journey -- and he's been riding that wave ever since. Preying on nostalgia in the hopes that no one will notice that he's unable to actually write anything decent any more.

He shouldn't have let his inner child grow up into that obnoxious teenager. He really shouldn't.

And the thing is is that I can no longer trust him, nor can you. He hasn't written anything really good since The Longest Journey, I'm not sure why I was expecting him to start now. I gave him a chance. This was his last chance. If you're an intelligent, well read person with an appreciation for literature, this is so bad it'll make you want to go and find a corner to curl up foetal in. You'll want it to stop being so very bad. It doesn't stop being so very bad. It continues being so very bad until you can't take it any more and you crack. It's really very bad, then, yes. Very bad. In fact, at the risk of sounding like Sewer Urchin, I'd say it's very, very bad. Yeah.

So bad. I need to stop writing those words, but I can't. Good grief. I've been exposed to an angsty teenager and I want to point you in a different direction so you won't have to sit awkwardly through what I did.

Okay. Okay. I think I have what I need. There's a character in there who fires quick and fast ableist slurs at the mentally disabled. So edgy! The writer felt that that was necessary in order to create a shock response. It was exploitative, cheap, nasty, and as ham fisted as anything else in Chapters is what it was. If he'd had a black person being attacked by someone flinging ethnic slurs, he'd never have gone through with it. He played it safe, he chose a group who're regularly victimised and chose to pick on them. Sounds edgy, doesn't it? Picking on the easiest group like a giant yellow-bellied coward, I mean? He could only have sunk lower if his target had been furries.

What, exactly, happened to you, Ragnar? I mean, what?? How do you go from The Longest Journey to... this pile of drivelling brain rot? Christ. So... don't buy this. Move on. Forget it exists. Just forget it exists. Go and play The Longest Journey again. You don't need this much angsty teenager in your life. You really don't. Off you go.

reviewText:
I loved the first two games, but I'm so very disappointed in Chapters. I've only played up through the first part of Book 4, so I'll update my review if the rest of Book 4 or 5 somehow make up for this trainwreck of a game.

Everything I loved about the first two games feels like it's missing. The characters are bland, the puzzles are a joke and practically nonexistent, the environments feel strangely empty, the dialogue is sooo awkward (seemed quirky/funny at first, but now just annoying), and the story has become dull and lost all momentum.

The one element I do really like is the descision system and getting to see what choices other players made at the end of each book. However, it is a bit annoying how it's constantly waved in your face as you're trying to play. It really takes away from the immersion when giant blocky text pops up in the middle of conversations telling you that You Have Altered Your Fate.

I'm not even playing for enjoyment anymore, I'm just hoping for some closure after Dreamfall: The Longest Journey.
voteText: 6 of 14 people (43%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Chapters is certainly a logical continuation of The Longest Journey. All the effort and love that's gone into bringing the world to life would be hard to miss. The shamelessly colourful storybook artwork is as great as ever at setting the atmosphere. It seems nice to have some closure after Dreamfall's abrupt cliffhanger. I felt a slight giddyness starting the game up for the first time.

But it doesn't take long for it to get back to the old tricks. The puzzles are simple but tedious, usually taking you on pointless jogs from one edge of the map to the other, or relying on you to catch that one hint buried in the awkward and long-winded dialogue. Other times it's just about finding the exactly right sequence of messed-up dream logic so you can do the bleeding obvious. All business as usual to those who played adventure games in the 90s, but unfortunately the world has moved on and the design feels decidedly out of place with the otherwise very decent production values.

All in all, I'm not sure that I can honestly recommend buying Dreamfall Chapters unless you have a high tolerance for frustration or a positive outlook on the previous parts in the series. Maybe grab it from a sale, and take the experience as it is, and you may find yourself enjoying the good parts.

reviewText:
Based solely on Book One: Reborn, I would not recommend this game to people unfamilar to the Dreamfall series' rich story. As a fan of the Dreamfall series, I find that Chapters, thus far, has created more questions than answered. Therefore, if you don't already know what the original questions left from the prequel, this game will appear confusing and perhaps unforgivingly tedious.

However, if like the Dreamfall series or if you are patient and/or an optimistic gamer, I have a feeling you will see potential in this first episode.

Regardless, I stand by my opinion, I would not casually recommend this game.

reviewText:
Shockingly bad performance still, although it's patched to playable levels by now, so there's that. I wouldn't call that a plus, but at least they tried.

Much of the game feels very lifeless and artificial. Sure, many NPCs roam the streets, but they got no life to them, nowhere to go apart from walking the same old circles, or to stand around and repeat the same sound clips ad infinitum.

On top of that it takes forever for them to release the episodes. So what little traction the story might have gotten, it's completely vaporized in the long downtime.

The game does have its merits, it has some nice touches here and there, but they mainly stand out because it's not that hard to rise above the averageness of the experience.

I might be revisiting my opinion once this is actually a complete product, and advise everyone who is still interested, in waiting till all episodes are released. You have nothing to lose, and everything to gain.

reviewText:
I really really WANT to like it. It does have some very good voice acting and a cool story. But there's some things driving me nuts about this game and if you're an impatient ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ like me they'll bug you too.

Performance is crap first of all...sure we don't need 60+ FPS in an adventure game but I get insanely low framerates during certain scenes (Psychiatrists Office comes to mind about 15-20 FPS) which is rather unexplicable, it's not graphically intense, nor are there any crazy physics happenings.

The animations / character movement have not improved one bit in the 10 years since Dreamfall: The longest Journey. Watch some youtube footage of cutscenes and you'll see what I mean here. Everyone is a robot.

Lastly - and this is my BIGGEST gripe - at every single point in the game so far I've felt as if I'm just stumbling around completely lost until I somehow get lucky and trip over the thing I needed. There hasn't been any cool eureka" moments with the puzzles / objectives...I've felt like just a LITTLE more direction would've been helpful at nearly every point. NPCS offer almost no help whatsoever as to how you're supposed to accomplish things.  And "Oh
date:

reviewText:
Gameplay-wise, it’s a point-and-click interactive movie thing with shallow and predictable characters. Think 3D visual novel, complete with writing that would only appeal to 13-year-olds, but without the frustrating story flags that end up killing you and all your loved ones because you made the wrong choice somewhere back in the second chapter. There are very few ways to really screw up in this game. It has very few puzzles (if you could call them that), and they mostly consist of finding and combining items or putting things in the right order. On the positive side, it still manages to make me curious about how things are going to play out, and there’s a little value in replaying the game to see how your choices influence what happens to individual characters (they generally make no difference in the grand scheme of things). The voice acting is quite good.

I give it a 3.5/5 there. Entertaining, but far from a masterpiece.

Where things really start to crumble though is the technical side. I’m not going to beat around the bush here, this thing’s a MESS and it tends to absolutely ruin the immersion. Graphically, the game looks comparable to titles released in 2006, only with slightly higher texture resolution, a lot of post processing, awful lighting, beginner mistakes (depth/alpha testing failure and z-fighting for instance), distance popping, broken shaders, and rigid, almost robotic character animations that are not timed or positioned correctly most of the time. But it needs a very high-end CPU and gigabytes of RAM to pull this off at acceptable framerates. And even if you have lots of RAM, at some point (roughly 4 GB), performance just falls off a cliff as the garbage collector struggles to deal with all the memory fragmentation because someone thought they didn’t have to care about memory management with a game written using .NET. Nothing could be further from the truth. This seems to happen with a lot of Unity-based titles, so future gamedevs take note—GC’d languages are not a silver bullet. VSync is dysfunctional (probably due the unstable framerate; didn’t attempt to pin down the cause), mouse grabbing does not work properly (cursor leaves the window if you move it too quickly). The list goes on and on. In two hours of gameplay, I hit the “Report Bug” button about a dozen times (as of version 4.1.1). It’s frustrating, to say the least.

I still give it 2/5 points here because at least it hasn’t crashed so far, so it’s not totally unplayable.

Overall, I don’t think I can recommend this game as it is. I might have reconsidered if the developers had fixed some of the major technical flaws (instead of just the symptoms, like Propast completely wrecking performance in earlier versions), but apparently that is either not very high up on their list of priorities, or they simply lack the expertise to do so.

reviewText:
I was a fan of the original Longest Journey and (to a lesser extent) Dreamfall.  This game is a long-awaited finish to what is am amazing story.

I've finished it, and found that they did a great job painting the atmosphere and story.  This game is all about the story.  The graphics were good and the voice acting was top-notch.  I'm very curious to see where it goes from here.  If you would like a unique story and don't mind a game that isn't button-mashing, you should like this.

The only complaints I have is that it's terribly short.  I finished the first book in under 5 hours.  I know it's episodic, but I really exptected more to start.  Also, the animations are a bit stiff.  Character movmement just doesn't look quite right.

The last thing remains to be seen.  I'm not sure if buying in gets you all of the episodes or if they will be charging for the rest of the game.  $30 is way too much if this is all you get, and you have to buy the others.  If you get at least 2 or 3 more books, then the prices is about right.

reviewText: So far, this is a wonderful experience. The graphics aren't exactly up to par with current PC and console games, but for me it's the story, seemingly forever unfinished and constantly unfolding, that keeps me coming back to the bridged worlds of Arcadia and Stark. After eight years of waiting for a cliffhanger to be resolved, it really feels like things are finally coming together. Even though only Chapter 1 has been released at the time of this review (and I admittedly seemed to whisk right through it, but I just couldn't stop playing) I cannot WAIT for the rest of the story. I'm so happy this was made, and I remain a fan of this series who finds themself immersed in the story, environments, and characters and I just want more and more.\n\nBring it on~

reviewText:
The feel of this game is really weird compared to the other two in the series. The sort of 'telltale' format of this game just doesn't seem to mesh with the world for me.

When I was informed by the game that Zoe no longer worked at a certain job due to my actions in the game, I was really thrown out of the immersion of the story. It's not like I was fired or something, I was just informed out of character, that a fact about the world was different because I'd chosen to talk to a few people before going to work.

I haven't finished the game, some parts of the presentation are quite nice, but I've had a hard time getting back into the game for more than a half hour here and there.

At the moment, I think it might not be worth it.

reviewText:
So far my experience with this game has been more negative than positive (ch.2). I WILL finish it, because I loved TLJ (and Dreamfall to an extent) but it is NOT a good game, IMHO.

Do you like fetchquests in hard-to-navigate cities? Do you like easy quests, where the difficulty comes from NAVIGATING THE DAMN MAP?
The game works so much better when it's confined, but usually you're forced to wander in the big-♥♥♥ city, where there's hardly anyone to talk to, or anything else to do, really. It's a pretty prop, but it's so empty! You can visit places from TLJ, but there's nothing to gain, no new insights, nothing,

As you can tell by my writing, I'm definitely not a critic, just a disappointed fan.

reviewText:
The story and setting has a lot of potential, but the way it's told drags the game down. It's a series of cliffhangers and slow controls.
I've glued my shift key down so the characters can run all the time. I've never found myself wishing they'd walk instead of run, but I certainly wished they ran with more spirit!
It's not just the characters that are slow, it's the story too. We spent one full chapter in the daily life of Zoe, and how she buys dinner or prepares dinner, or gossips with some guy or another. Is this really the epic story we want to see? It's just fluff that could easily be removed or replaced with something a tad bit more interesting.

As it is, most of the game is padded with fluff to make it take way more time than it needs to. Speed up the running, make the animations more fluid, clean up the boring story parts, don't force me to run from A to B to A to C, and the game will be a lot more enjoyable.

reviewText: A beautiful storyline, gorgeous and immersive environments and great artwork at every corner. This game is a true continuation of the longest journey series, and it brings out the best of it. The wit and humour even in the face of ominous circumstances and mysteries. The minutely conceived environments, where every poster on a street corner reveals something interesting about the characters and their world. The great voice acting! And most of all, the respect the game pays to the players' intelligence - that you're part of the game, and that the game is a story or a movie: entertaining, but not overly pretentious.\n\nI highly recommend this game if you want to experience a world and a story that you will remember forever.
voteText: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I'm totally stunned. I've found Dreamfall : The longest Journey 2013 in steam summer sale, and thought I should get it and have a try, could be nice - within 10 minutes I was totally fallen in love with the game. this year I bought and played The longest Journey (14 years old, pixelated graphics, but such an epic story, I couldn't stop ^^ ) and I literally screamed of joy when I saw Dreamfall Chapters was available to buy (after a long wait on my wish list) and I was so happy to finally start playing.
Those graphics feel so epic, in my very own opinion, they can surely be a patch on other AAA Games released in this year (Despite some little bugs, which are in EVERY game !)
Right at the beginning you're fully pulled into the story, you feel along with the characters, it feels for me as I would be in this world by myself.
Still, it's just the first book with two chapters, but I knew from the first minute (as I am such a big fan of Zoe), that I love this game, and yes, I do. I'm really curious about how it goes on.
For everyone, who likes the first and / or the second title of the series it is a 100% must.
For all others, who like adventures, there is no way around this game - but I still recommend the first and the second title, first to know the story ( otherwise you'd be having some big question marks in your head) and second, they are fun too, doesn't matter how old they are.
I rate this game 10/10 and it is my personal Game of the year 2014

reviewText:
Wonderful writing and a lot of great details (street musician, for example) make this feel like a very competitive conclusion to the first two titles.

The episodic system is unusual of course, but it works very well for me. First two episodes have given me ~12.5 hours of gameplay (with no replays), which is *way* beyond what I'd expected, and the story isn't showing any signs of winding down yet.

On the mechanics side, there are none of the issues that got in the way for Dreamfall.

Highly recommended.

reviewText:
Let us be honest: This game is nothing like the first Longest Journey, it has optimization problems (yep!), puzzles; well there aint any puzzles actually just some minor distractions that kinda easy to handle, a well designed big city but not much to interact with. Even with my lingering, wandering around aimlessly its finished at 3.5 hours. Now you hate this game arent you well dont because this game is awesome.

The most important thing for me in the game is atmosphere; city is awesome its dark, there are junkies around, there are machines looks like eating human soul, leadership is about the turn dictatorship, local mobs, black markets and then suddenly you can hear a middle eastern melody when walking next to a carpet seller! next to human organs; this is awesome; city is magnificent, its big well designed you feel inspiration and joy also under the constant pressure of danger same time, its hard to give this feeling.

There is one or two bad voice actors actually they look like they kinda make it lame because they are lazy but othre then these guys rest of the cast is perfect, characters are well designed and interesting (even they dont speak a word- serious) game also is for matures and reminding this to you a lot also another good thing.

Buy this game people or at least try it once, it has tweaks, it should be longer, more things to intereact with, more dialogs and some puzzles -seriously this  is the sequal of an adventure game-.

Note: Zoe is the closest character that has been created in a game like a real woman so far. Ragnar you impressed me

reviewText:
The story may be rich, but many of the missions/puzzles are designed in such a silly way that they ruin all the fun of the game.

For example, in Book Two, when Zoe walked out from the home, she was stopped by a robotcop, asking her who and where she was going to meet. If Zoe selects to resist, then most of the streets will be locked down. As the map system is terrible and I was not familiar with the streets, I spent two hours trying to find a route to get to the mission location (i.e., Dr. Roman's apartment) but just in vein. Eventually I had to give up and restart the mission all over again and change my response to the robotcop so that there would be less streets being locked down and so I could find the way to Dr. Roman's apartment. I was really pis*ed off by this route-finding" mission.

Furthermore
date: at the beginning of Book Three
recommended: what's the point to ask the player to collect the 9 drawings hidden everywhere in the house? What's the fun about it? Has anyone really enjoyed spending a couple of hours wandering around every room of the house for I-don't-know-how-many-times just to search for those well-hidden pieces of paper?\n\nStupid things/missions like these keep making me to think whether I should continue to waste my life on this not-fun-at-all game. At the moment
hoursPlayed:
I barely found all the 9 drawings by following the hints given in the Boork Three Walkthrough. I have a feeling that I will quit playing this game very soon.

---

I just realized that after finding all the 9 drawings
voteText:
the next mission is to attach them on the wall in the "right order". How the hell can I know what is the "right order" when no hint at all is provided in the conversation?

The design of the missions/puzzles really drives me crazy!
Not recommend this game at all. 3/10

But since this is a point-and-click adventure with pretty boring puzzles, so far all that's happened is some girl has been told to save the world and has talked extensively about an adventure she previously had which surely would have been more exciting than this, and some guy has walked to the top of a tower while holding conversations that hint cryptically at him having discovered a secret.

reviewText:
First of all this rating is up to book 4 since the 5. and last book has not been released yet.

Do I recommend this game? Well, yes I do. But you should consider a few things before buying and playing this.
Dreamfall Chapters is the third game of the series which started in 1999 with The longest Journey".
So in order to properly enjoy and understand `Chapters` you must have played at least the second title of the series `Dreamfall - The longest Journey'. Because it ends with a cliffhanger and `Chapters` picks up where `Dreamfall - TLJ` left off.
But actually you should have played `The longest Journey`as well. Because it`s a good game. And it does contribute to `Chapters` storyline. Now lets take a look at the game itself. Chapters is a game which is all about it`s storyline and characters. The gameplay is pretty much boild down to a walking simulator. Something that may annoy a lot of people who are playing or will be playing this game is the objective mechanics. In most cases it is not too obvious where you are supposed to go and what you are supposed to do. Solving most of the `puzzles` does require a lot of exploring
hoursPlayed: talking and patience. I enjoyed that. It forced me to explore the world which got me much more immersed in the games world(s). But the "trial and error" mechanic this game heavily relies on can be really annoying from time to time. Also the game is really
voteText: really slow paced. All the running around can get dull from at times. The design of the worlds themself is like in it`s two predecessors top notch. Immersing and beautiful. The graphics quality is okay. Could be better but they do look well enough. One major issue I had with this game are the characters faces. Sometime they look like puppets with no emotion. Thats one big atmospheric killer. On the other hand we should keep in mind that this games development is still in progress and it is beeing made by a handful of people. And they put together an amazing game. And despite some issues I had with this game i still loved it. The storyline behind all the Dreamfall games is really good. Could`ve easily been a real book.\nSo. To draw the circle back to my first question. Do I recommend this game? Yes
helpfulPercent: I do. To everyone who enjoys a good story and good solid characters. If you have patience and don´t expect action cutscenes a la Final Fantasy you`ll probably enjoy this one. And if you don`t mind a few minor bugs
votesHelpful:
some stoned faces.
And please do keep in mind that this game is developed by few people. It is not perfect.
But it surely is a very good game.

reviewText: Dreamfall Chapters is a great continuation of an immersive story. It's the type of game that puts characters and plot points first. The dialogue and character interactions rivals that of top name games like Mass Effect and Dragon Age. One of the strongest points of the game are the choices that players make. Choices by the player affect the gameworld and have far reaching consequences on characters in the game. Gamers interested in story driven sci fi and fantasy should definitely check out Dreamfall Chapters.

reviewText: Being from Europe, I was amazed by how the developers have done their homework.... even language as insignificant as Czech (in terms of those spoken by larger amounts of people) made it to the game's design - it is in the announcements in the background.... I do not like the Communist vs. Fascist nature of the politics in the game, however, it makes a very interesting plot :) The only thing I disliked is that the first episode was very short.... I hope the next ones contain more story.... the part of the game, which was previously most interesting - the story, is still the most intriguing :) I hope there is more of that and more games like TLG - Dreamfall Chapters.

reviewText: Fantastic follow up to the previous games, very excited for upcoming chapters. The characters are interesting and well developed and each choice to be made makes the player think. Most impressive of all is the world, Prospast is a fascinating totalitarian regime city and feels like the kind of place that could exist. Mercuria was interesting and look foward to learning more lore as the game progresses. My one gripe is that the larger maps can sometimes be confusing to remember and on occasion I did find myself having to rely on guides or wandering aimlessly to discover my goal. Overall though fantastic game Love it.

reviewText:
Friend, do not give up at the start. If you are looking for an impressive hook, it fails completely at it. Do you recall Zoë? If you do not, many things in this segment will confuse and potentially upset you, as they did me. I took the time, after understanding just about nothing, to play Dreamfall:TLJ. I had played the original eons before, sparking my interest in this little thing, but I never got around to playing its sequel. To get a good grasp of Zoë's story, I'm afraid you need to. And if you have played the game, as I did, it will still frustrate you, as it should.

Dreamfall: TLJ is perhaps the greatest example of blueballs I have ever seen immortalized in video games. The first half of the story establishes the character and the story, the next fourth sets the stage for the climax, and then... the final fourth of the game shows you just how horrifically rushed the game was. We rush through so much character development, so much of the climax (we effectively end on it), and the denouement is nonexistent: perhaps one story thread finds an actual resolution in the game, while many--such as Zoë's depression and feelings of aimlessness--are left open in the air. Completely unanswered, without so much as an indication of left or right.

Here is where Chapters enters in and leads us on our journey. We meet Zoë again, and we expect the same old girl. And we do get it, in terms of the voice acting: the delivery of the lines is close, as well as her actual diction. She sounds like the same character, and certainly seems to see the world similar to her earlier version. Of course, she also suddenly has MAGIC DREAM POWERS to give the player something to do through our first chapter... because it, in itself, spends a lot of time TELLING US the resolutions to last game's questions. The dream sequence is not too terrible of an offender, beyond that it introduces us to a 'past Zoë' that never existed. Perhaps there were dialogue paths in the predecessor that I missed, but at no point was she a conceited, self-absorbed ♥♥♥♥♥. I'm not really sure why the first chapter ends with us 'accepting' this old Zoë that was just have to accept exists. Maybe she was a jerk before she quite her studies. Maybe the developers totally weren't trying to introduce some canned drama to the mix of an otherwise completely boring chapter.

Kian Alvane is the other focal character of the game, and he is something of a tabula rasa. Let's be real, for a second: his character was an expense they just had to let go of in D:TLJ. All of his development was clearly supposed to come in the rising action and climax of the game where YOU KNOW WHO gets the spear, but it is so horribly rushed and his character shifts his ideologies so radically and so unrealistically... does a word of what he said in that game matter? The only thing of real importance would maybe be his affection for YOU KNOW WHO, but in this game he has deer girl. So really, nothing again. Here's the thing, though: this is good. In fact, this is great. Not at all understanding who Kian was from the predecessor did not really impact his story in the least, and I was so much more drawn in by it than Zoë's. Kian's story, in the first and the second book, is comprised of many different tropes all strung together in the unique canon of TLJ. It is, however, done -well-. The characters are fun and interesting, and though Kian is a fairly predictable character, that does not really matter. Honestly, his voice actor carries the role. The dilemmas he is put into are interesting, and the character's responses feel believable. Unfortunately, the first chapter rushes you into this dilemmas and spoon-feeds you tension, giving you only a few points at which to get a feel for the world or for however you would prefer to play Kian. While I was much more interested in his story than Zoë's at this point in the game (and playing D:TLJ does not change this), I still found it incredibly boring and insultingly similar to the telltale games formula. And there's no escaping this: every time you see 'CHARACTER WILL REMEMBER YOUR ACTIONS' flash atop the screen, you should be mildly frustrated at how horribly lazy that approach is.


That is, of course, until the final chapter of book one. Its introduction is fairly bad, I will admit. A cutscene that would make metal gear solid rolls across, that TELLS THE PLAYER DIRECTLY THE ANSWER TO ALL OF THOSE PLOTHOOKS THAT WERE LEFT HANGING. This enraged me so much that I put the game down for a couple days--it is downright lazy storytelling. Zoë speaks to a counselor about what's happened to her, what she recalls, and what she does not recall--as well as the effect of her lengthy coma on her personal life and beliefs. Honestly, the consequences of that are fairly interesting--especially how her relationship with her father becomes more muddled (and this is one of the few instances where playing the earlier game changes something's impact). The problem is that we see none of them, and we are told absolutely every last one of them. Her therapist's office is also terribly boring, really emphasizing just how incredibly boring all of the talking angles are: someone stands in perspective, their head sometimes moving to 3/4ths as their eyes move around randomly. Sometimes they show emotion, but honestly the voice acting carries this ♥♥♥♥. So. Hard. Think Bioware level of 'model behaves awkwardly,' and tone it down just a little and you're here.

This all changes the instant you talk with the doctor or head out onto the street, and I mean this to the depths of my heart. The dialogue with the doctor is fun, believable, and Zoë's thoughts, presented to you before you make a decision, are honestly entertaining. The worldbuilding of Stark is incredibly visual, with a definite cyberpunk aesethetic revealed. And when the characters are used as tools to further the worldbuilding--describing, for example, the role of the EYE--it's done in a completely believable way. The characters are not looking at the camera and winking with a grin; they're living out their days. You are allowed to roam around a city's section and get acquainted for yourself with the nuances of the future. Given how closely the game modelled the incredibly restrictive and boring TTG model to this point, this caught me completely off-guard. And I almost had a heart attack when my seemingly inconsequential choices--you know, beyond the incredibly tacky YOUR CHOICE HERE WILL MATTER sign--actually altered the way that the plot progressed. This is perhaps what won me over the most at this point. Little details have considerable impacts. Yes, the direction of the overarching story does not change, but the stuff inbetween is altered. Characters take notice of your actions, and there are consequences in how they regard you. They also have different value systems--some prefer being lied to, while the others enjoy a brutal, hard truth. It's a refreshing touch to a genre that increasingly takes every effort not to create branching dialogue trees. My one complaint with the Stark sections is the journal: it tells you important things about what's going on in Zoë's life, and while they are interesting... they are also not really in line with Zoë. It's pretty obvious that somehow April Ryan is writing your notes, because they're written in the same eccentric way. April's diary in TLJ made sense and fit her character; Zoë's sortof sticks out like a sore thumb.

Book two really won me over. Chapter 3, that last bit with Zoë, showed me potential: cool worldbuilding and realistic dialogue. When we start book three, we start with Kian. And this is really all I need to talk about: Kian's shot at a nonlinear environment. It's great. Characters are tropes, but excellently done tropes. I am out of space. Give this game time, and you will not be disappointed. It has flaws, but  weather the storm and you can be sure to be entertained by your choices' consequences.

reviewText:
I’m so horribly disappointed by how this game doesn’t even come close to the excellence and the magical otherworldly atmosphere of The Longest Journey. This is something that Dreamfall:TLJ, the second game, suffered from, but not to such an extent; and at least, it didn’t suffer from such weird pacing and writing issues.

The Longest Journey sometimes frustrated me by how arbitrary the solutions to puzzles were. Dreamfall Chapters takes this annoyance and dials it up to 11. There is also no explanation for your powers in the Dreamtime world; they’re just there, they’re not explained, and the game has to point to you through dialogue in a really hamfisted way that you have to use this “slow time” power on characters before doing another action in order to progress.

Show

reviewText:
Ok, here's the thing...I actually do recommend this game. It's wonderful, everything anyone ever could've wanted from the sequel. The story is brilliant, the characters are brilliant, the UI is a wonder of streamlining and intuition. The puzzles from the last two games are nonexistant, but that's ok.

But the problem is, the distribution format, of releasing a 'chapter' at a time, is awful. I got through the first one in five hours (mostly because I suck at adventure games, normal players could probs do it in 2-3). I loved every second of it, but now I have to wait until the second chapter to see how many of my minute choices and actions unfold, half of which I've already forgotten, play out. And it's not like I can go back and play it again; i want to see how my choices from before played out, the ones I made in a split seconds decision before I had time to really think it out. The chapter format seriously interupts the storytelling.

I understand the developers thought about this and were originally going to go with one big release, but they ran out of money and so had to go with the episodic format. So I'm not knocking them. But the chapters' release dates are spread so far apart (the second one might not even be released until next year) that it's basically pointless to play in such small measured doses, especially when the emphasis is on watching the story unfold and not gameplay.

Basically, take away is wait until all the chapters are out before buying it. It's not worth the frustation.

reviewText: There are two very engaging plot structures at play in this game; a mystery construction of pipes in the magical realm and an epic political/corporate conspiracy in the technological one, and the desire to see where these went (coupled with some fond memories of The Longest Journey) was what kept me playing. And then it ended quite suddenly, without any form of denouement or resolution, which is solely the reason for my 'not recommended' -- the feeling that stuck with me as the credits rolled being was that it?". The nature of episodic content is to string you out as long as possible so I wasn't expecting everything to be laid out in front of me
date: but I was expecting something.\n\nThere are also a bunch of design decisions that didn't sit well with me. Zoe (one of the main protagonists) is an incredibly well rounded

column37: so you have the option of buggering off somewhere else. It's okay
column38: they'll wait for you. You can even work your way around and approach them from the front -- but the game then begins its cutscene with you running up behind them.\n\nThere are some profoundly interminable cutscenes
column39: invariably of people talking to each other - I was playing on a laptop and there were several times where the screensaver kicked in due to the lack of input
column40: which made me wonder a bit if the creators would have preferred to make a film. It's also distinctly tonally inconsistent. Sometimes it's lighthearted and funny
column41: sometimes it's serious and drab and sometimes there are bits that make me think 'really? was that entirely necessary?'.\n\nThere are some interesting moments
column42: and it's possible that once it's complete I'll revisit it with a different opinion
column43: but as it stands I don't feel it a story worth the time it takes to tell."

reviewText:
[I backed the game on kickstarter, which means I'm positive in advance]

I always considered The Longest Journey and Dreamfall the work of art more than a game. Judging by the short 1st chapter that is available now, Ragnar and his team still have this narrative and artistic power over the game that most other developers lack.

As with the previous game, most of the game you're looking for a way to find/hear/watch the next piece of the story. No you won't be shooting bad guys, you won't build tanks, but you'll experience a very beautiful story staged in a very exciting world.

reviewText:
Overall it was a fantastic first book/episode.
Voice-overs: Superb. Loved the VO for Zoe and the other main guy.
Music: Gentle and emotional. Also liked that guitar guy song in the city very much.
Art: Fantastic. Really beautiful and detailed Europolis city and Storytime + Character models.
Story: Certainly Has a Soul. Also a lot of plot for just one of five books. If we get so much content with each book it will really be an epic saga. I like how it feels at the moment. Deep and complex.
Dialogues: Really entertaining and witty, some bad language but it fits perfectly. Making decisions is fun and I like how you can hower above each option and hear character's inner voice. Also there is a lot of optional talking which is pretty awesome.
Game-play: There are some puzzles but very easy to solve. The only strange one was one with the wine and I lost my sense of direction a few times in the city so thank god for the Crowboy.
Setting: Full of life, almost each object has a story to tell.
Bugs: None that I can see. They even postponed the release to squash some bugs to give us the perfect first experience.

If you like Telltale games you will probably also like this one. Only this one have better graphics, art, more choices and a ton of other content to get immersed into. Maybe it lacks non-stop action and sense of anxiety but it possesses far better, more original, complex story and setting than those titles.

reviewText:
Full disclosure: Possible backer syndrome.

That said, this is the way to make a modern adventure game.

Funny, touching, beautiful, expansive. As others have said, if you're familiar with the previous games you'll be on board with this from the first seconds. Otherwise, if you've any interest in adventure games at all you owe it to yourself to check this out. It's only the first few chapters of the story so far, and it starts off slowly, but once it gets going you'll find yourself in the largest, most free form open world environment I've ever seen in an adventure game. This isn't the tiny rooms of the Walking Dead, we're talking huge cityscapes.

You have the choice and consequence of modern adventure games, and the best of dialog and inventory puzzles from the classics. You won't be hauling masses of stuff around with you, but you will be combining items. And, while we've not seen the outcomes of many decisions as yet, there's at least one major character who you can entirely miss depending on your choices.

And, most importantly, it absolutely lives up to the writing of the classics. There's more dialog then you'll ever hear in one play through, often with escalating jokes hidden away behind examining items multiple times, incidental background events and internal monologue. Zoe has matured into a witty and engaging heroine, and you will relate to her problems and struggles as you wander her world. It's a game that genuinely deserves to call itself mature, because of the themes it fearlessly explores, not the amount of blood it splashes around.

Pleased to have backed it, and hope it sells a ton.

reviewText:
Red Thread did a fantastic job with this continuation. I immediate reconnected to the characters, and was drawn into a world I found myself wandering around admiring the details.

Reaching the end of one combination of choices, I found myself immediately wanting to retry the game and see the alternate paths my choices would provide. But more importantly, the wish that all books were available now!

I will have an excessively hard time waiting for the future books, but will do so none the less with baited breath.

A MUST PLAY for anyone that is a fan of the genre or of Dreamfall.

reviewText:
Be advised o ye potential newcomers, there are four issues with this game as of October 2014. First, be advised that there is only one 'book' available in chapters, i.e. one episode, so you're only getting roughly 4 hours of gameplay out of this. Second, you're going to want to have played both The Longest Journey and Dreamfall completely before picking this up or you're going to feel like this game is an acid trip. (Frankly if you haven't, they're incredible games worth the money.) Third is that the graphics are a little unoptimized so it will make even some rigs capable of running Glorious Star Citizen cry in pain. Unfortunately, this is not helped by the fourth concern, that the character models animations are a little sub par and that does cheapen an otherwise brilliant and immersive experience.

That said, there are a ton of positives. The setting is fantastically designed and believable. The writing, dialogue and choice system are on par with anything put out by Telltale. Zoe's internal monologues are plastered all over the game and are reflective of the choices she (ahem, YOU) will make, Effects on the storyline are VERY noticable and yet seamlessly woven into the game. It appears that quite a lot of effort was put into making the consequences of actions matter, at least in the short term with Zoe's attitude.

TL;DR - I like where Tørnquist and RTG is going with this. This is what TLJ/Dreamfall fans -- as well as fans of the adventure games genre -- have been waiting for. I recommend a buy after more chapters have been put out there. (And FFS, if you haven't played TLJ and Dreamfall, drop everything and do that right now.)

reviewText:
Score: 10/10

Controls:
The controls worked great on an xbox 360 controller. I personally had zero issues. I've heard mouse and keyboard works great as well.

Visuals:
I mean some of the guys look a bit to cartoonish, but beyond that minor gripe this game is current gen. The lighting is truly  where it shines. The atmosphere it creates feels correct.

Sound:
I bought a copy of the first two games on GOG even though I had them on steam just to get the soundtracks after I had beaten both games. This game is no exception and it may actually greatly surpass them by the time all five books release. The voice acting is spot.

Gameplay:
No odd fight sequences so far thank god. The gameplay feels very natural as you explore the world considering it is an adventure game and adventure games have yet to truly find solid ground on what it means to be an adventure game in todays gaming scene. Though because Dreamfall Chapters is not your standard point and click adventure game of days gone by so some old schoolers may have gripes on the amount of puzzles and difficulty of them. You will not be relentlessly bombarded with inventory puzzle after inventory puzzle involving a duck, but they do exist and they play out quite elegantly in the world.

Story:
It's basically what the game is about so if you want explosions and gun fights similar to a 90s action flick go buy Marlow Briggs. The story is very incomplete beings it is only book one, but if this sets the tone for future releases you can expect the most atmospheric story game in history so far. I've heard if you read the journal entries the game makes more sense if you haven't played the past two titles, but I would imagine you'd be confused unless you play them honestly.

reviewText:
It’s impossible to talk about this game without talking about its predecessor, Dreamfall, and Dreamfall was a terrible disappointment.

Dreamfall featured a relatively incoherent plot about new characters it never convinced me to care about. The graphics were pretty but only mediocrely designed, the writing was clearly trying to be interesting but failed due to incoherence, and the whole thing felt like a chore to play. I finished it out of a sense of loyalty to The Longest Journey, which remains one of my favorite games of all time.

I’m happy to report that I have good news and great news about Dreamfall Chapters.  The good news is that it is noticeably superior to Dreamfall in every aspect. The great news is that, with some effort and additional work, I think I could be convinced that it’s a worthy sequel to The Longest Journey.

Dreamfall Chapters is beautiful, yes, but the thing that stands out about it is that it’s very intelligently directed. There’s an economy of the frame at play here, with dramatic shots being reused to communicate additional information and enhance drama, that just wasn’t present in the previous game. I’m excited to see the game designers thinking carefully about the camera in the cinematic scenes. I can’t help but think of some of the iconic scenes in the first game -- the wizard’s castle, Flipper’s den, the Dragon’s ledge in the beginning -- and I see that the direction of Dreamfall Chapters is an attempt to get closer to the stationary-camera-style visual density that The Longest Journey gave us. Of course, it’s not the same, but the narrative and cinematic tricks that we can do now almost make up for the lack of lush detail you could find in pre-rendered 2D backgrounds. And I’m encouraged by the way Zoe can engage (wittily!) with many details of the environment, making it feel as if what details are there are thoughtful and intentional.

I’m also impressed with the writing. I found myself caring about Zoe and Kian for the first time, even though they were introduced in the previous game. This is where the series really benefits from the episodic structure -- where the previous game felt rushed and ineffectively communicated, Dreamfall Chapters takes its time, and does so to great effect. We can breathe as each character takes one of many asides, explaining her motivations and feelings, and it fits just as if you’re watching a film. I can’t help but compare it to the original game, where we’d get the same narrative, but the screen would be still (we’d be looking at a “room” in an adventure game, after all), and the only character movement would be April’s swaying idle animation; If you see these as parallel structures, it’s pretty exciting to imagine the power of the engine of the new game in terms of storytelling capability. There’s just so much more available to the creators here than there was in TLJ, and it’s good (and it could be great).

But whether it amounts to greatness remains to be seen. The team working on Dreamfall Chapters is already fighting an uphill battle, trying to save an IP they know is great from the failures of its unfortunate sophomore iteration. They must use characters that I (and maybe I’m alone) didn’t really care about, but it looks like they’re doing a good job of salvaging them and repairing the damage. They have to figure out how to take the narrative structure their audience fell in love with during TLJ and shoehorn it into a first-person 3D interface, and it seems like they’re doing better than they did the last time. For the first time since TLJ, I’m excited to see where this is going.

As a sort of personal aside, I think that the story trajectory is now my biggest problem with the game. One of my favorite things about the original was how it was founded in the technological world from the beginning -- this helped create a base for the main character and helped center the narrative, allowing the magical side to feel more like fantasy and embellishment, almost as if it lacked rules. It was a dream, and it felt dream-like, and returning to the technological world brought with it real narrative consequences. When things in the dream-side had narrative consequences, that became interesting because it was a transgression of the dream idea (as if a dream shouldn’t have narrative consequences but did anyway), but that was a rule to be broken and not something that happened often. It helped reinforce the magic of the game. Now, we have entire political plots in the magical realm, and I’m struggling to care. I’m still kind of bored with Kian. I can’t muster interest in the political intrigue of Arcadia. This part of the story does not feel magical and it does not feel like a dream, which is the way I was taught to see it in the original.

Regardless, maybe the story will eventually prove me wrong. Dreamfall Chapters left me eager for more, which is much more than I can say for its predecessor.

reviewText:
Graphics and user-interface are mostly the same as in Dreamfall, just with a few improvements here and there. The fight system seems to be gone. Sneaking is still present, but toned down and only used in a single situation. One new addition in Chapters is the choice&consequence system, similar to what Tell Tale is doing. Hard to tell how that will pan out, as so far there hasn't been much consequence for the choices you make.

On the negative site, the performance is at the moment pretty bad, but patches for that are incoming. The choice&consequence system is also a little obnoxious, as it gives large on-screen indicators whenever there is a choice, this really should be toned down and be pretty much invisible. Animation are also a bit lacking, as it's still the old hand-animation stuff, not the fancy motion-capture that is used in most other bigger titles.

As for story, not that much happens in the first book, a few new characters are introduced, you revisit a few old places, but nothing big is so far driving the plot. I personally like that, as it gives you time to familiarize yourself with the world and the world itself looks amazing. Chapters has easily one of the best representations of near-future sci-fi you'll find in gaming.

Puzzles are, as in Dreamfall, still rather streamlined.

Overall, this is the Dreamfall sequel I have been waiting for, it doesn't radically change the formula and continues right where it left of. If you liked Dreamfall, get this game. If you haven't played Dreamfall, play it before you dive into Chapters, as Chapters doesn't bother much with retelling what happened in Dreamfall. Playing The Longest Journey couldn't hurt either.

reviewText:
As it stands, I cannot recommend this game.

I was wary when I first heard Red Thread Games was releasing Chapters in installments rather than a full-fledged game. I had backed it on Kickstarter and at that point, they were talking about a single game, not vignettes. I wasn't particularly happy about it, but I put my faith in the team that had brought us TLJ and Dreamfall (though I felt much more strongly about the former compared to the latter) and decided to wait and see.

The result is a 4 hour tutorial that does absolutely nothing to advance the plot. Sure, we get to Europolis, but the sidequests there cannot be finished. That's right—you go through these tedious find this thing and bring it to this person" quests
date: but there's no resolution. Each one is a dead end. You don't actually fulfill any of the quests you set out to complete.\n\nI felt like there was way too much fluff injected into this one
recommended: as well. Minus the opening sequences with Zoe and then with Kian

reviewText:
I played 'The longest Journey' a long time ago and I loved it. I also played 'Dreamfall' - not as good as 'The longest Journey' but I liked it. Thus I really was looking forward to play this game.

Although there are things that left a good impression (I liked the dialogs) I completed book one less than four hours and the game (from my point of view at htat time) suddenly stopped, indicating that I need to wait for part two. This was both unexpected and realy disapointing. I agree that this information might have been provided somewhere (I haven't read the description before the purchase), so I dont' blame anyone for that - my fault. But honestly, book one is - from my personal point of view - not much more than the tutorial: there is not much development of the original story and the riddles are way to easy for an serious adventure game. Instead there is a strong focus on the decision making component of the game and on the introduction of the basic mechanics. I simply expected more.

Although I decided that I won'trecomment this game at the moment (11.11.'14) , I will try out book two. If book two catches up with the intensity and the atmosphere of the predecessors, I will update my review.

reviewText: Dreamfall Chapters is very rich in both atmosphere an storyline.  The enviroments such as the cyberpunk city and dreamtime have suprisingly good graphics. The storyline begins where dreamfall : the longest Journey left off and the plot begins to thicken an evolve as you play through the first book; Reborn.  The puzzles throughout the game are somewhat complicated and incorporates some adult psychology in order to help some of the dreamers escape their nightmares that have been induced by the dream machines.  The game is in its own class.\n\nThe length of the first book reborn is about 4-5 hours long.  Just as I was really starting to appreciate the game it ended and I was left very dissapointed.  However, there are 4 more books that come in the form of downloads in the upcoming months.  The budget for this game was limited given it was funded 1.5 million from kidkstarter.  I'm assuming that is why it has been broken into 5 books.  If I had known that I was only receiving around 4-5 hours of playtime I would have waited until the game was finished in it's entirety.  Overall, the game itself is one of a kind.  Although, I do feel I was ripped off given I paid full price 29.95 and recieved only 1/5 of the game.  I would only recommend this game to someone upon its full completion. I'd give this game a 3.5 out of 10.

reviewText:
*Note: this is only a review of Chapter 1. To be updated*

Summary: Dreamfall Chapters is a story and choice focused game with minor puzzle elements; heavily borrowing mechanics from The Walking Dead. It has a lot of great aspects, such as good atmosphere, interesting characters and great voice-acting. However, poorly designed puzzles, as well as a long and drawn out section towards the end of the game left me bored. The game has a lot of promise, but after playing the first Chapter I cannot recommend buying it yet.

Long version: Dreamfall chapters is the sequel to The Longest Journey and Dreamfall. Like The Longest Journey it has a great setting and rich backstory in the technological world Stark and the magical world Arcadia. Unlike The Longest Journey however, the Dreamfall Chapters is NOT a puzzle game. Rather it is a story and choice focused game which happens to have some puzzles thrown in from time to time. Very much reminiscent of The Walking Dead in that respect. This move away from puzzles and focus on story is neither good nor bad, it just means it is a fundamentally different game from The Longest Journey and will appeal to different people. The Dreamfall Chapters offers up a wonderful world and good characters which are well-written and well-voiced. The choices are a fun aspect to the story, though I do not think they will make me want to replay it, and it is sometimes a bit unclear that you can actually make a choice (which made me accidently leave someone to get tortured… my bad!).

My biggest problem with Dreamfall Chapters is pacing and the puzzles, however. The great thing about The Longest Journey was that it managed to combine intricate (sometimes ridiculously complex) puzzles with a good story and interesting characters. The puzzles here are very bare bones and feel disconnected from the rest of the game which focuses so intensely on the story. The puzzles, on the other hand, feel like they are getting in the way of the story, slowing it down rather than adding to it. And as soon as I was stuck on a puzzle the wonderful façade that the game had painted started to crack. What looked so good when I was exploring suddenly contained nothing to interact with, no people to talk to even in a crowded marketplace when the goal is to buy something, no hints as to how to progress. You eventually find the solution, more by the absence of alternatives rather than any brilliance on your part. In a real puzzle game the puzzles themselves are the point and there are usually other puzzles to solve if you are stuck. In the Dreamfall Chapters there is nothing but a story which is not progressing.

This problem is compounded by the deliberately slow pacing of the later parts of the chapter. The city you find there is at first lovely and looks to contain endless details to explore. However, that quickly turns out not to be true. The number of things to interact with is incredibly limited and the snail pace movement of the main character and the absence of a fast-travel system, quickly turns moving around the city into a grind. As I was finally running Zoë home after a day in her life, I completely understood why she did not want to fight with her boyfriend. I was very bored of running back and forth on the map where I had already seen the sights and heard the conversations, watching Zoë awkwardly zigzag after my keyboard commands that obviously should have been controller commands.

I was sure I would be recommending the Dreamfall Chapters after the first 1-2 hours, but after finishing the first chapter I am concerned. The lazy puzzle design and the dragged out city section really distracted from the story and left me feeling bored rather than interested in what will be coming next. It is a shame, because the game has a lot to offer and a lot of potential, but right now I cannot recommend buying this game.

reviewText: I really want to like this game. It's beautiful, it's interesting, the plot is fantastic, the writing is great but... I basically have no idea where to go or what to do at any given point. I know what my objectives are but when I'm stuck in a futuristic city with no direction on WHERE to actually go at any given time, it is very frustrating. I got to the point where I was having to search online for where in the world to find X person or place at such a frequent rate that it became impossible to immerse myself within the game.\n\nEssentially this game is like being from a farm in Russia and being sent to New York City for the first time and being expected to find a single lady named Nela restocking her supplies somewhere in the city. Somewhere. That is your only hint. GOOD LUCK!!!!!!!

reviewText: It pains me to say this, but this game is nothing short of terrible. I've been a devout fan of the Longest Journey Saga for agest, and Dreamfall (the old one that is) sits tall and proud in my favourite games list. However, Dreamfall Chapters is a resounding disappointment. In essence, it's a mere TellTale Games clone (pick any of those to compare it to, they are all boring in my opinion). You get to play as a semi-depressed / fully apathetic Zoë Castillo, who aimlessly walks around a metropolis doing mundane chores, such as following a silly (and awfully unfunny) robot around. When it comes to dialogue, it's all about the TellTale system, aka you have a number of options to choose from and an unimmersive and unnecessary HUD tells you that Character A will remember what you said". There is also a section where you get to play as Kian Alvane

reviewText:
Based on the video, images, and reviews, I honestly thought I would love this game.

Ha, NOPE!

Almost 60-minutes in and I am literally pulling my hair our ranting about this game to my boyfriend.  Not only is it extremely linear, but it is mind-numbing.  I have learned absolutely nothing about the game nor the characters.  All I do know is that it's very one-way.  Do this.  Do this.  Do this.  DON'T THINK ABOUT EXPLORING--It's not happening!  Or at least it hasn't yet.

Oh and tutorials?  What are is this thing you speak of?  They don't exist.  I have no idea what I'm doing to the point where I, in frustration, button mash with the hopes of magically clicking on or doing the right thing.

Seriously though, it doesn't explain how to interact with the world.  Yes, in theory, it's straightforward.  But in reality?  It's harder than it looks.  For example, right off the bat, someone is falling.  There's no tutorial to show you how to use your powers.  There's nothing that says, HEY

reviewText:
Back in the 2006 Dreamfall ended with a cliffhanger, that, I suppose, was meant to be tackled way sooner than it was.  Now, 8 years later, Dreamfall Chapters picks up from where Dreamfall ended, continuing the journey of Zoe Castillo, who's narrow shoulders carry the balance of two wolds, the world of magic Arcadia and the world of technology Stark.

This first part of the story starts by picking up the threads of Dreamfall. You see how the actions taken in the previous game have effected and this serves as a starting point for a new adventure, where Zoe needs to find her way again. Red Thred Games, consisting of the original developers of the Longest Journey and Dreamfall, have done an admirable job with this first chapter. It might not be the most adventurous part of the story, but it serves as a nice piece of groundwork for the things to come.

The story also has different branches, as your actions have an effect to the world.  Depending on how you choose for an example effects on what kind of story is told when Zoe awakens into her new existence. It doesn't only effect on how she dresses, but where she works for an example.

All in all Dreamfall Chapters is a promising start for a hopefully fulfilling tale of the worlds of balance. Chapter 1 delivers a promise of greatness and if Red Thred Games can keep that up, it could end up as one the best adventure titles of recent years.

With only Book One out currently, I cannot recommend this game. The plot feels like it's only barely starting to go somewhere. That said, if you have not yet played Dreamfall, you MUST play it first. The enjoyment I drew from Book One came from knowing who these characters are and wondering where they will go. I don't see a player new to the series enjoying the game very much.

Dreamfall is easily one of my favorite games, Yes, The Longest Journey comes before it, however if you play Dreamfall first, like I did, it still works well. The Longest Journey can be played as a pre-quel and there's enough separation between the two that you won't feel lost starting with Dreamfall instead of from the beginning.

We'll have to wait for the rest of the game to be released to make a final recommendation, but this is an exellent time to pick up Dreamfall and play through it.

reviewText:
As a huge fan of 'The longest journey' and Dreamfall I was really lookign forward for the release of this game.
Unfortunately the game has one huge issue (which renders it unplayable for me):

It is performing terribly even on recommended hardware. I own a i5 760 @ 3,6 Ghz and a GTX760, System runs at High Performance setting, so no throttling.  With this setup I am able to play most games at high settings in 1024p resolution. Bioshock Infinity, Tomb Raider, Watchdogs, Farcry, Shadow of Morder - no problem. This game though is very choppy. For instance the Title Screen is completely fine, intro is choppy, first area seems to run somewhat fine, then framerate crashes in second chapter. Inbetween massive framerate drops.

Many users already reported that problem. Even after three patches it has not been resolved. Developer states that the game graphics are 'demanding' and they can't do much optimization as they are limited with the Unity engine. Sorry that is a poor excuse. FAQ in their forum to solve this problem doesn't help at all.

As long as this has not been issued I strongly discourage you from purchasing this game. A pity because let's plays on this game look great! (Only way for me to enjoy the game.. by watching others play it)
