reviewText:
This game was a disapoint to me. even trough keeping in mind the fact that it is only one chapter the game looks unfinished in the details. more then once i come across rooms where the objects where misalligned. The puzzles are a bit odd to say the least. the game is an increadible slow boild.
an excample of a puzzle that was odd would be, and i got to spoil here:
in the harbor you have a robot called kit robot, you need to remove some barrles from the river. one barrle is unmovable by the robot. the other is. but the secence you need to complete the puzzle is strickt. remove barrle one, then you can get the robe, then ring a bell. what fustrated me was that their was no need for the stricktness. their was no reason why you could only get a robe after the first barrle was removed.
for the story wise, might be that i never played the previous game; i did not get the story. for what it was worth it seemed alright, some intresting characters, memorie loss and other ideas that might just involve in an intresting story in the next chapters.
yet the game does not make me intrested in playing the next chapters or the previous game to get the story. the game pulls out some nonos in story telling by telling most of the story instead of showing, having some unrelated scenes to this chapter that take a huge amount of time.
for example, another spoiler here.
in onepart of the game you play in the past and need to escape. even trough you had no fighting scenes it was prity intense for an interactive story telling. but the tension was not build propperbly, it consists by walking around a lot trying to find a way to open the next part of the game. now the set up as a prison riot would make you think you have some time limit, but no. another missed chance. after that you go back to Zëo in a futuristic world. that point this game grinds to a hold and leaves the hand breaks on for the rest of the way. get dinner for boyfriend, get to work, and do some volentairy work.
only towards the last part of the game I get to some plot relevant ideas. everything in the middle is jsut filler.
One more point that grinds my gear is the way the choice system is set up. the choices you make will be remembered for the next chapters. the outcome depends on what everyone who played the game made. and that is where i feel the choice system falls appart. i don't care what other poeple choicen, i want to see my play trough, my choices to come to conclusion.

to conclusion: it might be an intresting story burried somewhere in a game with the lack of good puzzles and unfinished level design. Trough the graphics are good, it falls part with the attension to details and keeping some tension in the plot going up.
I would not recomend the game at this point, maybe with the second chapter it will improve, trough the first chapter is the chapter that should have drawn me into the game to the point i can't wait for the next chapter.

reviewText:
Worst in the series. Not because the game is bad itself, but because how the developers treat gamers.
I have always been the biggest fan of the Longest Journey (the original). And I’m still. When I played Dreamfall in year of 2006, I was looking forward for the next game. When I saw developers were collecting money on Kickstarter, I immediately pledge at a word.
But now, I am starting to hate Dreamfall the Chapters. This game is the only game which runs with artefacts on my computer (just imagine character’s eyes with laser beams like the Superman).
What else? It took five months to release Book two. Chapter 5 in that is the shortest. And I have spent only a little time playing it from the beginning to the end. As one can see, the developer’s efficiency is questionable.
In addition, I was heartily sick of the developer’s Tolstoy-like “novels” that I was getting every time before a release date by email explaining which event on Mars stops them from releasing.
No one should play it until all the books has been released. Otherwise, keep something calmative nearby.

reviewText:
*Updated for Chapter 3*

I spent hours exploring and interacting with the wonderful dystopian city they managed to create.  In a landscape filled with fantasy games, this was a breathe of fresh air.  The protaganist of the future portion of the game is Zoe.  She is easy to become attached too emotionally.  Witty and charming with great writing and voice acting.  All of it was so well done I wanted to spend all my time there!

The game is split up into the future and also ancient history.  The past portion of the game I was far less interested in but this is partly because of bias of setting.  Kian is easily the less interesting character of the two, but the supporting cast around him has been interesting so far.

Some puzzles are a bit annoying but overall the story and presention has been fantastic so far.  I can't wait to see how this story unfolds

reviewText:
Disappointed.
I've played both the predecessors, loved both, but this game wasn't the pickup right where the last game left off sequel I thought I was getting.

The sequel portrays Zoe very differently from depressed undergraduate, to hero trapped in the dream realm saving people from dream machines gone haywire stuck in a coma. Now I actually liked this change in pase, although some of the nightmare puzzles were a little annoying, the classic dreamfalls humor and gorgeous artsy visuals made it enjoyable.

I didn't mind the intro, but when they did a time lapse, gave the protagonist amnesia and briefly went over the fates of  some of the previous characters it really irked me; Cherry on top, you are put into a new city with no recollection, stuck in a game tutorial for the rest of the first installment. I had to drag myself through this gutt wrenching beginning missions hoping for some plot, but before I knew it the game had ended prematurely and on a cliff hanger.

This was not the best foot forward. Not how I imagined TLJ series to make a comeback, but I really hope they bounce back with better installments, hopefully longer and with more substance.

reviewText:
I am very sorry, but as a fan of 'The Longest Journey' and as a Kickstarter backer I can't  recommend this game for now. Yes, 'Dreamfall Chapters' does promise a great story - but those good sides are rather obscured by episodic releases, while all the bad sides are already clearly evident:

- Bad language. Too much of it - 'DC' has more bad language per square millimeter of gameplay I have ever seen in a computer game. I have no idea what the developers wanted to say. Why, we have ladies present here! Wait... OK, those ARE the ladies who are using that much of bad language. Well, call me old-fashioned, but I prefer ladies who do not swear all the time for no apparent reason.

- The graphics. It is not so bad, but even 'Dreamfall' of 2006 did not look much worse. Dark and gloomy Dreamworld, dark and gloomy prison, dark and gloomy Europolis city... And not a sight of the sunny Arcadia.

- The bugs. The game is obviously not optimised - FPS is jumping back and forth, and even powerful PCs have some trouble running it without any crashes.

So - there is not much sense in buying the game for now (if you do not already have a Kickstarter backer's code).
And I still hope that I would be able to recommend this game after it will be released completely in a year or so!

reviewText: There has only been one chapter released so far but that's enough for me to pass judgement! This long awaited sequel seems like it will live up to expectations! If you're unfamiliar with the series allow me to direct you attention to 'The Longest Journey' first. It's a classic point and click adventure game (roughly 15 years old now I think) and it's one of my absolute favorite games of all time. You can jump into this game before playing 'TLJ' (and its sequel 'Dreamfall') but you would be doing HUMANITY a great DISSERVICE. PLAY PLAY PLAY!

reviewText: Pretty much everything a Dreamfall fan ever wanted; engrossing plot spanning the two worlds of Arcadia and Stark, facinating main leads of Zoe and Alvanna that drives the game forward during the slower moments, and choices and consequences mechanics popularised by Tell tall games implemented effectively so far. Between this and life is stange, episodic gaming is here to stay.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Excellent game... not only beautiful to watch, but play is seemless and voice acting is believable.  My only wish would be there were more side adventures to get into, the game only has one straight path, thought it says, like the TellTale Games, you can make choices that affect later decisions.

Even if you have not played the Longest journey as April Ryan, or played Dreamfall, it honestly does not matter that much, you can watch a short video (tab choice) that explains the past two stories and how you have come to this point.  But, of course, both prior games were also a lot of fun, just be prepared for the very low texture characters and scenes from the very old The Longest Journey game, I believe the game came out a decade ago.

The designers of Dreamfall Chapters did an amazing job of bringing the game into the 2015's and it is so beautiful, so is the soundtrack and the puzzles, though pretty easy, are not so bad as to be was too easy.  Keep in mind that just like TellTale Games Dreamfall Chapters is just that, only the first chapter has been released and will last you about 5 hours if you take your time.  Can't wait for the 2nd chapter to come out tomorrow.

Thanks for reading the review, definetely a 8 out of 10.

reviewText:
We've had a long sad history of waiting a decade for another instalment in a gaming franchise, only to see our hopes shattered by the unbelievable ♥♥♥♥♥iness of said instalments. However, Dreamfall is here to rectify that. Dreamfall Chapters fully lives up to the excitement of the first two games in the series,
At the time of writing, only part 1 of the story has come out, and while it does not go particularly deep into the overall story, I have no doubts the rest of the parts will be equally enjoyable.

A word of caution though: This game does offer a brief recap of the story so far, but that mostly serves as a reminder to those of us who haven't played the other games for many years. If you're new to this franchise, then this is probably not the game to start with. It will most likely leave you too confused about the story unless you play at least Dreamfall first, and preferably also The Longest Journey.

reviewText:
A great, wonderful, amazing piece of art!
Immersion is spotless.
I thought that I was playing the best Assassin's Creed in a cyberpunk setting.

It seems that all the original mood, acid humour and fun from the first games is somewhere around the corner..
Far too many useless interactive assets that don't add to the story or are not properly given enough dialog lines. Maybe they will at some point, but it's pointless to keep the player busy with them for now.

It felt a bit short, but it's just the first chapter so this may end up being a long jouney ;)

Keep up with the stunning visuals and music score, but don't forget about the story, the playability, the characters, the fun and the players!
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
This is my first taste of this game series and undoubtedly I was attached.It's a unique journey,a mysterious fancy,and a magic and attractive world.
Compared with some AAA games with the highest level picture quality,Dreamfall Chapters's world is rather dreamy than realistic.But still,you'll be amazed by the colorful,fascinating world.There are tow worlds in this game:a magic one, and a near future city,which has reminded me of Transistor.Both of them are full of surprises.
Since I'm addicted to voice performance in games,I can't help but want to praise the voice acting,especially Zoë's.Through all those characters's voices you can feel their emotions and thoughts.What's more,when you click something more than once,Zoë won't repeat only one sentence----much better than some other games.
In this game,you'll have to make choices,as the brief introduction says.But I'd like to say that this kind of choosing not only concludes talking chioces,but also includes actions which may bring total different consequences.So think twice before you step out.
Just finished Book one.And can't wait to play the next book.

reviewText:
Pros:
Beautiful worlds
Interesting relationships
Not just a game for kids

Cons
Episodic release
A bit prententious
Requires a lot of running around clicking on things (a flaw with adventure games in general)

I was a fan since I played the Longest Journey back in 2002 (originally released in 2000) and I donated to the Kickstarter campaign for Dreamfall Chapters without regret.

If you are intrigued by this game start with the Longest Journey, then Dreamfall, then play Dreamfall Chapters.

The Longest Journey is one of those really special games that stays with you way after you're done playing.

I still remember reading Split Infinity  by Piers Anthony - and then to find a visualization of this in the Longest Journey and Dreamfall was so rewarding.

I look back on all that sci fi and fantasy that helped me grow up with great fondness.   I have a very deep resonance with this idea of bridging the two worlds and merging the two kinds of imagination.  It is only now that I am (much) older that I also understand how easy it is to lose your imagination - whether to intrusive technology or to ideological intolerance.

I think video games of this type still have a long evolution in front of them.

Many story based games struggle with pacing.  Dreamfall Chapters is no exception ... it is a healthy struggle.  We are just learning how to tell and participate in stories in a new way - immersive story based video games are maybe 30 years old.

I am very grateful that this work is being continued in Dreamfall and if there is another Kickstarter campaign to finish April Ryan's story - I'm in.

reviewText:
I would argue that what makes the TLJ universe so compelling is the interplay between Stark and Arcadia. Both the way they depend on each other and in the experiences and actions of the characters who are shaping or trying to shape the future of this interplay.

It's too bad then that DFC starts out playing these elements extremely close to the vest for a long time. To me the game just doesn't put its best foot forward.

Still I very much enjoy my time with the game experiencing these fascinating worlds, and I also feel very confident that the payoff will be quite large indeed.

reviewText:
I've been waiting for a squeal for years. It was apparently crowd funded and I'm sorry that I missed it.

As with the ones before, this adventure game's charm comes from the dialog and settings more than the puzzles. One of my favorite lines of dialog comes when the main character is speaking about checkpoints where passes are only issued on the other side, Kefka would be proud."

The puzzles are native to the story and generally non-intrusive. They tend to be difficult to get on the first try. Through penalty-free trial and error
date: none of the puzzles take too long to solve.\n\nIt is worth warning that this game is "Book 1" of a longer series. Expect about 5 hours of game play to hit all the achievements and not much longer than that to have seen everything. I've played other games (I'm looking at you FPS) that were shorter
hoursPlayed: and cost me more money. The take home message here is that the story isn't complete and you should expect DLC.\n\nI look forward to the next release."

reviewText:
When in 2000 I played The Longest Journey I was blown away by it. Not by the graphics but by it’s story. It was so superbly told it was only later I realised the audio, voice acting and world in which it all took place, were beautiful also.
It took much to long before it’s follow-up, Dreamfall arrived. Somehow it was not what I was hoping for, but the story made it worthwhile.

And now finally the latest instalment of the Dreamfall saga arrived. And I have to say, the graphics are nice. Not the best there is, but after some time I saw the beauty of it. It’s about what’s there to see rather then what is missing. In other words, I got used to it and it made my fantasy render the world nicer than most games do because most important, atmosphere, so often overlooked,  is so much present.

Then there is the audio, most people tend to forget about it, hardly notice it, but in Dreamfall Chapters it so beautiful done. Take some time to listen to the great soundscapes, they mingle perfectly with the world surrounded by it, enrich it. And like in its predecessors voice acting is great. Zoë just wouldn’t be Zoë without that voice.

And then there is the story, in all honesty, it took me longer than expected to be struck by it. But once it did, it just didn’t let go. It’s (game) storytelling at its best; how I could only hope for all games should be told, but so few are.

So, for me, Dreamfall Chapters is in my top 3 of 2014 and after looking what games are still to come, most likely also in 2015.

voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
As a big fan of the Longest Journey, I was so delighted to find out about Dreamfall chapters. I loved the story telling and the beautiful graphics of the original series. I still get the similar feeling from Dreamfall chapters. The graphics are not really top notch compared to the other blockbuster games but the scenery is there. Very creative places and settings. I also found it's even more focused on the story telling than the original series; which is not a bad thing. I feel like I am actually watching an interactive TV show. It still has puzzles and stuff but it's not as difficult. I remember the original series has so many tricky puzzles - or maybe I just grew old and the puzzles are not as difficult anymore. lol

Anyhow, I am taking my time to play this game so I can enjoy it longer and manage my time as well since there are only two books out and it seems like there's a significant wait time for the next ones.

The bottom line is I am so happy about this game and can't believe the sequel to the longest journey series is finally here. It's not a usual adventure game that you have to grind so much just to follow some silly story. This game is more philosophical and deeper than most of the games out there. Probably that's why there are so many people who have been longing for the sequels. I wish there were more than 5 eps. I actually hope it has seasons" and come back again some day.

"

date: but they are very much bits and don't result in a lot of "do-overs".  This game is more about choices
recommended: much like a choose-your-own adventure book.  It seems there are many different mays to reach your goals as you play.  There is some puzzle-solving
hoursPlayed: but most of it is fairly simple... but it *can* occasionally be obtuse and difficult to figure out what to do or even where to start

reviewText:
The gameplay is mediocre at best and tedious at worst. But I don't care about that at all.
The strong point of the series is the storytelling and the characters. For fans of the series, that is all that ultimately matters.

If one hasn't played the prior games of the series, then start there first. Otherwise you will be missing parts of the the story, and that is like starting to read a book right in the middle - you start out without any emotional attachment to the characters and the events that happened before. And I don't think this series can be played in reversed chronological order either, you'd miss out bigtime.

reviewText:
Pretty awesome game, to compare with Telltale Games (I haven't got around to playing much other than the first chapter of GoT) the graphics are much better, the story is much better, and the choices feel like they matter a lot more.

I never played the previous dreamfall/TLC games (although I'm now conidering it), but this one is engrossing, even with two worlds and two main characters. I like that the game tells you when choices have affected an outcome you're currently experiencing, it reinforces the idea that choice matter for more than just short term dialogue.

One con: Sometimes it doesn't feel quite as open ended as I would like. There are usually a good variety of responses, but sometimes there's a nuance that I'd love to be able to express. I hardly feel like I can blame the game for this though,  just an unrealistic wish.

reviewText:
I'm going to try not to dissolve into a puddle of tears and hyperbole while describing my love for this game. But I flippin' love this game! First, I'll just get out of the way the fact that I waited 10 years for it to come out. I played Dreamfall when it came out on XBox and was devastated that it ended the way it did with no new development in sight. The world building was rich, I love playing as Zoe, and the story was great. Solid writing, fantastic voice acting, and a female protagonist with agency. I'm a long time PC adventure gamer, and I felt like I'd been waiting for this game all my life. I went back and played The Longest Journey and loved that too. Then I played Dreamfall again just to appreciate how well the fleshed out the world, and how aware you are of the passage of time and it's affect on both places and people. There was also always wonderful diversity in the characters, and I don't just mean the magical races. This series was hitting all the right spots for me.

When they announced the Kickstarted for Chapters, I flipped my ♥♥♥♥. I couldn't back it fast enough. But of course I was on the edge of my seat, wondering if it would be worth the wait? What if I waited all this time and it was a total disappointment?

Having finished Book 3, I can say emphatically that this game is excellent. Zoe has deepened as a character. The changes that have happened in the world between games have deep impact. This game is taking on huge themes - militarization and fascism, racism, politics, revolution. But it all feels very personal as you get to know the characters living through all this. My heart has broken over the people and places that have been wiped away by the conflicts (no spoilers, but there are some deaths that happened between games that I found profoundly tragic). With all this going on, I'm delighted that the quirky, meta, snarky sense of humor that has run through this series has remained. It feels well balanced, and never takes itself too seriously, which I really enjoy. Especially when they make nods to previous PC adventure games, or lampshade a particularly obvious trope.

TL;DR if you like PC adventure games ala Monkey Island and old Sierra stuff, but you want something a little deeper and more conscious (cheesy as that sounds, I mean it) you have to check out this series. Start from the beginning and work your way through. You will be rewarded for your exploration. It's just lovely.

reviewText:
I love both TLJ and Dreamfall: TLJ and have been waiting for the follow-up for a very very long time. Dreamfall Chapters, like its predecessor, is a heavily narrative-driven game. If you like games like The Walking Dead, The Wolf Among Us, Heavy Rain, and Beyond: Two Souls like I do, I believe you are going to enjoy Dreamfall Chapters.

All the endearing trademarks of the TLJ franchise are also back: funny, witty dialogue, interesting characters, exotic locales, fascinating but mind boggling mysteries :P, great soundtrack, and fantastic voice acting. I also love the new internal monologue game mechanic. It allows you to weigh conversation options in a more organic way because you get to literally hear what Zoey or Kian is thinking.  The choice and consequence mechanic is also pretty intriguing and adds replay value. Book 1 starts out slow but I actually love the pacing. It gives you time to get acquainted with Zoey and, to a lesser extent, Kian and their present situations. Book 2 moves into more traditional adventure gaming territory with more quests and puzzles. The story in Book 2 also picks up considerably and ends with an unexpected and surprising bang".

One gripe is that the game is really taking its time reintroducing our favorite characters from past games. The good news is that we'll be seeing Crow in Book 3. Another gripe of mine is that fairly prominent characters from the previous game seem to have been unceremoniously written off. After 8 or so years of waiting
date: that was a bummer :(. I am hoping that there will be lots of surprises in store for us in the last 3 chapters.\n\nAll in all
hoursPlayed: then I highly recommend Dreamfall Chapters."

reviewText:
*** SPOILER-FREE SECTION  ***

For those who have played The Longest Journey AND Dreamfall, this is a must-play.

It's hard to write a comprehensive review for a game that is not finished, but I applaud the work that has gone into the game so far and the responsiveness of Red Thread Games (RTG).  As an immediate Kickstarter backer, very excited for a conclusion to the trilogy, I was initially disappointed with Chapters.  It wasn't clear from the outset when you are making critical choices, and I wish there was an easier way to replay specific scenarios instead of entire chapters to see the branching impact on the story.   Book 1 started strong, 2 slumped a bit for my taste, and 3 kicked it off again with major plot developments.

The story overall is a familiar continuation to Dreamfall, which itself was a strong thematic sequel to The Longest Journey (TLJ), one of the best adventure games of all time.  Dreamfall was plagued with some questionable technical decisions in gameplay, and unfortunately, that extends into Dreamfall Chapters.  The game is pretty in still shots, but runs horribly on many PCs.  I've been fortunate - running a Core i5 with a recent midrange GeForce, it runs acceptably.  It has gotten better since the launch of Book 1 and may be dramatically better by the end of Book 5.

I've heard that RTG is getting a lot of bad press after book 3, but it was my absolute favorite so far.   It seriously advanced the story beyond 1 and 2, and was also in many ways a return to form of the original Dreamfall and TLJ.   It is much better than the overly-long book 2 that feels padded with fetch quests and spends too much time in Propast, the dystopian future city that has a lot of atmosphere and yet manages to be boring beyond a few memorable characters.  I much prefer time spent in Marcuria, although I would like to see more of Arcadia overall.  Sometimes the downside to making a modern game is the sheer amount of work to pull of any new environment -- this makes me wonder if we will ever truly see an updated version of TLJ due to the insanely larger scale of that game.


** SPOILERS BELOW **


I want more magic!  I hope that Zoe in Marcuria/Arcadia is used beyond where she was in book 3 as a stranger in a strange land.  She's been there before, and I'm sure she can be of use to the resistance.
I wish Kian had shared about the purpose of the pipes and tower (maybe he did, but it wasn't discussed on camera) so that Zoe can go to the magical hub under the city (from previous games) and we can hear more of her story.
I really don't care if Kian is gay, the writers can do what they want with that, but I'm disappointed that he has the potential for two love interests and the player can't choose either to pursue.  Yes, my Kian kissed Anna.  And her revelations at the end of Book 3 were good at establishing her character.   Enu is much more interesting overall, but is likely too young for Kian anyway.
I'm very excited to see Ge'en finally, and am crossing my fingers that Captain Nebevay (TLJ) survived the Chaos Storm and will be there!
I'm not giving up on April Ryan either.  Ragnar seemed pretty certain she was dead, but Dreamfall Chapters has already established that dreams can be used to shape reality.  It's a longshot that she'll return, but Saga's story recap of TLJ through her illustrations drove home that the authors want us to remember April.

reviewText:
Note: This review is for Book One to Three

I recommend this game to anyone who's into beautifully crafted stories and characters, and who enjoys diving into a detailed, fantastic world once in a while. DFC does everything right on these parts. I fell in love again with some characters I've been missing since TLJ Dreamfall and I'm thrilled to finally learn about the countless complex mysteries of both worlds, Stark and Arcadia. The only major downside at this point is that you have to wait quite a bit for the next Book. And the one after that. And the... ugh. This is an exercise in patience.


Some more detailed notes/impressions:

- DFC is not an Action Adventure. It's not fast-paced. You don't run around guns blazing or jumping from roof to roof. Thankfully you also don't have to endure wacky stealth sequences anymore, or actively punch the bad guys on the nose (like in the predecessor). What you do is solving puzzles, exploring, making decisions, and watching a lot of cutscenes and dialogue while the story unfolds and things get complicated. If the latter's your thing, this game is for you.

- The tone swings between drama, suspense, and sometimes totally unexpected comedy. It's all there. There's a lot of lighthearted stuff going on while drama and mystery keep you hooked at the same time. Great mix.

- The game starts out quite slow, linear, and even depressing in Book One. Personally I came to a point when I got pretty bored. Just play through the first 2-3 hours and there's a good chance you'll get into it. Book Two and Three became real page-turners quickly. Book Three especially.

- While I enjoyed most of the puzzles, this game also made me pull out my hair from time to time. Excessively running around in a fairly big open world just because you've overlooked that one darn item that isn't even hinted at isn't always fun. Oh well. There have to be these parts in any game, I guess.

- KB+M controls sometimes feel a bit clunky. I have to get accustomed to them anew every time a new book is released.

- DFC has a keen eye on diversity and tries to be as inclusive as possible. This is a good thing.


Conclusion: Great game with minor flaws. Recommended for everyone who's all about story and characters!

reviewText:
I've been a fan of The Longest Journey since I came across Dreamfall: The Longest Journey and it left me in a state of emptiness after I finished it, like the feeling you get after you finish a book. I found out about The Longest Journey and played it as well and ever since, The Longest Journey and Dreamfall are one of my favorites games of all time. This game was a gift to me, and it remains to be the best gift I've ever received.

When I learned they would be making a sequel to my favorite games I was so happy but frustrated that I would have to wait so long, but it was worth the waiting! If you're into fantasy, cyberpunk, adventure and story this game will have you come back to it's universe Stark and Arcadia over and over again to meet some of the best told and designed characters in amazingly made two different worlds.

Previously, I recommended this game to my friends but I told them they should play the previous games before this one to understand the story and love it, but as I progressed, I saw that this game alone has so much to offer even if you don't know much about the universe the story keeps introducing new characters and shows how the old ones changed as the worlds kept changing. So, even if you haven't played the other games I totally recommend it and I believe it's worth your money.

If you've played the previous games I doubt I need to say more because this game takes the story where it left off. As soon as you start the game and see the opening cutscene, the game says ''this journey is not going to be an easy one''.

The game has one of the best stories I've ever heard, read or seen and it NEVER lost its magic for me, I was never bored in any part of the game, there was always something else to be curious about something else to explore and understand and try to figure out. The moment you start your Journey, you should be ready to be surprised by anything because this universe is anything but boring. I enjoyed every single moment of it. Exploring the world in Dreamfall: Chapters was especially amazing because of the improved graphics. Every place you wander will have it's own magic with their own colors and a theme unique to them. The game has a fantasy side to it but not in a universe that is filled with Elves and Orcs or Angels and Demons. It introduces so many races with their unique cultures, designs and stories. They beautifully fit in the games universe and they shape it into what it is. The cyberpunk side of the game doesn't look as unique as it's fantasy side, but it brings humans from different cultures together and you will be seeing how they blend in the futuristic world of TLJ. The voice acting is great dialogues are not dull and if you take your time to interact with objects around yourself the protagonist will comment on the objects and Zoë tends to have interesting things to say about pretty much everything. I like her style. Her voice actress is different from the previous game but she does a great job as well. And as I said the story is amazing but I loved how it pulled me in and at some point I was so mad at something that happened I decided harshly and the consequences were so awful it made me feel horrible. So, yes the decisions you make, so far, have great effects, makes you consider the tiniest things over and over again. I hope the fifth book will live up to my expectations and my decisions will affect how the game ends. Though, I'm not sure if I can handle it if it ends badly because of my poor decisions, I will be crossing my fingers.

Yes, I really love the series and I really love this game but I do feel like I must complain about some things that made me frustrated. The controls are bad, sadly. And when you run, you're basically not so much running. So, the exploring part gets a little bit too slow. I'm not saying I don't like exploring, I would've ran around my favorite places over and over again. Well, running is more like fast-paced walking and the animation seems like it as well so I guess it fits. Puzzles are not enough challenging compared to TLJ but considering I was, at some point, randomly clicking on everything trying to find something that works in TLJ maybe this is for the best. Some animations look a little funny but the scenery makes up for it greatly.  Some objects are hard to interact with, you need to hover your mouse on them a few times before you can interact. There are some collision problems and I hate not being able to go up some stairs just because they're not important. They're stairs, they're right infront of me, they're wide open for me to walk on, but the game just won't let me. Yes, it is pointless to go up those stairs but I want to.

reviewText:
I'm changing my stance on this after having played it a bit longer.  That said:

The Longest Journey is still one of my absolute favorite games.  Combining a rich story and challenging puzzles, it should be in every adventure game fans collection.  The sequel, Dreamfall, didn't quite equal the first's success as it ended up being a lot of set-up without a satisfying pay-off and fans would have to wait almost a decade to see this.

While I'm only in the second chapter and am intrigued to see where the story goes, I find myself less compelled to play again each time I exit.  The puzzles can be a bit of a grind when you are often given a task only to have to do another task to get the original done and it's not always clear what you're supposed to be doing.  There's also a lot of emphasis during play on your choices, particularly in dialogue, and you can see how others decided, but I won't know if it really makes a difference unless I go through a second time. I do like the story, but I don't feel like I'm playing" so much as "watching" events unfold.

Overall
date: I am enjoying it despite the flaws.  I guess this is more of a soft "not recommend" since I don't feel people who are adventure games fans will enjoy it
recommended: but if the premise sounds intriguing and you do like the more story-focused games (like Heavy Rain)
hoursPlayed: you will probably enjoy this.  If you haven't played the original
voteText: do yourself a favor and pick it up.  Otherwise
helpfulPercent: it's just not the game that it used to be."

reviewText: Amazing, what an interesting game. It's more of a storybook but you get to move the characters, 3D and make decisions to affect how your story progresses through the chapters. There are puzzles to solve and I have to admit I had to Alt-Tab out to find some of the solutions as they really do not give any hints. However be vigilant and not only see, but LISTEN to what the NPC's are saying they might have a key phrase that helps to figure things out. Other times it is just click all combos until you get it. But there were only 2 puzzles that seemed to work that way. This is a very clever game, beautiful to view. I can't wait for Book Five! I screwed up Kian though so make sure you find the infiltrator and remember some of the smaller details of a task are probably very important to be completed because they will have repercussions. This took several days, probably about 30 hours if you include some of the exploring I did in the cities. Well worth it!

reviewText: If you are reading this right now, you probably know what this game is... it is part 3 of a trilogy" so to speak that started many years ago with TLJ in 1999... I fell in love with the 2nd game... then played the first one because I absolutely HAD to (with a guide cause i suck at puzzle game)... then I worked for 2 years with the creators of this game on Secret World (mmo)... always hoping we'd get to work on this amazing serie after it was done. reviewText:
I'm changing my stance on this after having played it a bit longer.  That said:

The Longest Journey is still one of my absolute favorite games.  Combining a rich story and challenging puzzles, it should be in every adventure game fans collection.  The sequel, Dreamfall, didn't quite equal the first's success as it ended up being a lot of set-up without a satisfying pay-off and fans would have to wait almost a decade to see this.

While I'm only in the second chapter and am intrigued to see where the story goes, I find myself less compelled to play again each time I exit.  The puzzles can be a bit of a grind when you are often given a task only to have to do another task to get the original done and it's not always clear what you're supposed to be doing.  There's also a lot of emphasis during play on your choices, particularly in dialogue, and you can see how others decided, but I won't know if it really makes a difference unless I go through a second time. I do like the story, but I don't feel like I'm playing" so much as "watching" events unfold.

Overall
date: I am enjoying it despite the flaws.  I guess this is more of a soft "not recommend" since I don't feel people who are adventure games fans will enjoy it
recommended: but if the premise sounds intriguing and you do like the more story-focused games (like Heavy Rain)
hoursPlayed: you will probably enjoy this.  If you haven't played the original
voteText: do yourself a favor and pick it up.  Otherwise
helpfulPercent: it's just not the game that it used to be."

reviewText:
Quirky puzzles, (funnily) self-deprecating characters and even the slightly sluggish camera add up to an awesomely nostalgic feeling, making the game a great addition to the Journey saga. While other games try to include more extra points, coins and stars to be had per frame, Red Thread breathes fresh air into Chapters and isn't afraid to patiently flesh out the world skimming the brink of becoming long-winded, but never boring. It's not only the nostalgia that makes it a great game. No element is heavily repetitive making it anything but monotonous -- Chapters has a lot going for it deciding against multi-action-combos in the era of cashing in on user and playerbases as fast and much as possible (good on you, crowdfunding). It is ultimately an earnestly retro game, in a sense where you will get a lot out of it over time, if you let it.

[mild spoilers]
Sarah Hamilton's (April from TLJ) voice comes through clearly especially in the end of Book IV, adding a totally different but complementary vibe to the voice acting of... well, Ellie Conrad-Leigh or Charlotte Ritchie or whichever actress speaks Zoe. Astounding performances on par with ex. Ashley Johnson's Ellie in the Last of Us (where, obviously, much more than a small development team were involved +acting +more time +huge sound departement etc).

reviewText:

Cons:

- Story's less interesting than in DreamFall
- Low FPS in the most of areas
- No combat at all, the one in the previous game wasn't so great but i'd have liked an improved one
- Every new chapter took many months to be released
- Some quest objectives are a bit confusing at first
- The river puzzle is just stupid

reviewText:
I can not fully recommend this one:
I love The longest Journey and it will be one of my favourite games forever!!!! But Dreamfall and Dreamfall chapters are not that good. Don't get me wrong the story is awesome and it's worth checking out but the gameplay?
There is none.
Almost none. I never liked episodic games and I played quite a few. I love point and click and I hate it when they change what made the game so awesome just because it's not popular anymore.
In Dreamfall you just walked around talking or interacting with things/persons to get thing A and than to put it with thing B you do the same steps again. There was so much backtracking.
Dreamfall chapters is just the same but you can make decissions which may have an impact of some sort but some of those decissions are really weird or the reactions you get are not fitting.

Spoiler example:
Decission: Torture a man or just question him
-apparently torture makes him more reliable (which is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t!)
Decission: kill him or don't kill him
- kill him and you'll make one of your teammates really happy
- I didn't kill him because Kian is a rebel now, not a warrior and not an azadi. He becomes your spy which is not at all what I wanted and leaves me very unsatified.



Also YOU SHOULD play the first and second game.

reviewText:
Characters are surprisingly interesting and funny given the large and diverse cast they've got going. I was a little cautious at reading about it and I hadn't played the previous games but I rapidly found my feet and fell in love with the characters. Not much game mechanic beyond choice/consequence but I honestly don't mind that much as it is so interesting. The different settings really break it up while carrying over common themes and characters.
There has been an annoyingly long wait between books but I don’t think I’ve ever hit a bug or major issue with the game from a technical stance
In short, I love this game and would thoroughly recommend it. If you’re a fan of story and character driven games, give it a go. However, if you are more into challenges, mechanics, puzzles and shooters then best give it a wide berth.  (Written before book 5)
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
I cannot recommend this highly enough.  The story, sound design, graphics, and gameplay are all absolute hallmarks, and what other games in the genre should aspire to be.

Of course, there's nitpicks, little things that bother you here and there, and I would be lying if the few crashes I have had (mostly during saves, where the save would go through fine, so I'd just have to double click and go) weren't annoying, but they're entirely forgivable in my book because the story is just so, so good.

If you're looking for a story where you can take part, there's nothing better than Dreamfall Chapters, and the entire world of The Longest Journey.
